<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Making decisions under uncertainty:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>At the beginning of any new client engagement, we were expected to develop a “Day One Hypothesis.” Based on the high-level facts that we had learned within the first 24 hours of the project, we were forced to develop an early hypothesis of what the solution to the client’s problem was.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How you develop your hypothesis is a combination of good problem solving skills, pattern matching, and intuition. We were also often encouraged to “get smart” about a particular area by reading 3rd-party analyst research, or interviewing industry experts. But the expectation was that within your first day on the project, you should come up with your early hypothesis about the right decision to make. Then, you can always gather additional data to refine your hypothesis over time. You should be open to changing your hypothesis as you gather additional data, but you should start out with a hypothesis on Day One.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong>The reason why this approach is helpful is that after Day One, you always have a decision that you can stand behind at any point in time. You may try to gather additional data, but based on the data that you have already reviewed at that point in time, your current hypothesis is your current decision. This approach works best when you don’t know how much time you have to make a decision, but you could be called on at any time to make it. </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source:  <a href="https://medium.com/lessons-from-mckinsey/making-decisions-under-uncertainty-c1d1dfbb02b2">https://medium.com/lessons-from-mckinsey/making-decisions-under-uncertainty-c1d1dfbb02b2</a> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^woot I did that with AiFi! :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^however, I didn't do that on my first engagement. I realized... when more senior colleagues asked me what I thought would be the "right" model out of the choices I was creating, I said stuff along the lines of "I don't know", "well given X, it would be X2, but given Y, it would be Y2", ETC. The right answer, as I saw RB do, is to give an answer. This will also structure my approach and thinking in my workstream. The bolded text above articulates an amazing reason why.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>-strive to have the right direction (i.e. +, neutral, -) and right magnitude (i.e. 1M, 10M)</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>What do you have to believe?</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^I did that in my last engagement too! Awesome tool. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Writing clarifies thinking</strong>:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>@Me: practice dot dashes!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Framing. Some important framing questions include:</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>What is the problem we are trying to solve?</li><li>Why is this an urgent problem for us to solve? Why now? What happens if we don’t solve this problem?</li><li>What are the important issues that you think deserve the most attention?</li><li>What are the goals of our solution?</li><li>What is in scope for the problem? What’s explicitly NOT in scope?</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> Synthesis is summary plus insight. Anyone can summarize data, but synthesizing requires you to interpret the data and understand what it is actually telling you. Writing down your ideas and arguments will hopefully get you thinking more about what the impact of the data is, rather than just summarizing it. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This also makes so much sense:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>With limited words and space in your document, the act of writing forces you to make your argument more concise and persuasive.</strong></li><li><strong>Writing will cause you to internalize your argument. The next time someone asks you about your idea, you will have your talking points ready and you will sound very structured when you communicate.</strong></li><li><strong>You have potentially created a work product (Google doc, presentation) that can now be easily shared.</strong></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As you get into the writing habit, the next step is to push yourself to sharpen your language. Edit down your language to make every word count. This will take your writing—and thinking—to the next level. You can even ask for feedback from your colleagues or friends who have good writing skills and an eye for editing.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Finally, be prepared to write stuff that doesn’t see the light of day with others. I firmly believe that even the process of writing will help you develop your thinking, and even if you don’t actually share the document with anyone else, you will be more confident in your own thinking.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^on that last paragraph, I believe this is why I feel like I grow in certainty of myself each time I go through a big application (i.e. scholarships, college, etc)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Communication strategies:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> effective communications separates leaders from the pack. And it’s something that one can continually work on to improve. Over the years I’ve read a number of books on communications such as books on writing, storyboards, logic, presentation construction, visual design, and verbal delivery </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Problem solving with <strong>heuristics</strong>? </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Frameworks / structuring:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":4} -->
<h4><strong>Frameworks give you freedom</strong></h4>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When you have the outline of something – presentation, argument, journey – it liberates your mind to focus on the details without the fear that you will wander too far off the path. You know the boundaries. Consultants don’t necessarily know the answer, but they often know where to look.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":4} -->
<h4><strong>Clients are notoriously bad at this</strong></h4>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Clients often know the answers. They often have trouble putting words around it, backing it up with data, and simplifying the complex into a comprehensive narrative. Simply put, they cannot tell a story.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Like a trunk of a tree, look for the thick branches that support all the smaller limbs, leaves, flowers and fruit. Call it a framework, paradigm, skeleton, straw-man, storyboard, or template. It will keep you out of trouble and often help you find your way. Group your ideas and continually distill your thinking until it is 80 proof. Use MECE to tell a clean story that makes sense to executives and makes your client look great.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>BTW high level consulting ppt templates:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>link:  <a href="https://www.consultantsmind.com/2015/12/11/consulting-templates/">https://www.consultantsmind.com/2015/12/11/consulting-templates/</a> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>ALSO TO WORK ON:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>creating excel models:  <a href="http://www.consultantsmind.com/2012/11/13/good-excel/">http://www.consultantsmind.com/2012/11/13/good-excel/</a> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>amazing breakdown:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image -->
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://www.consultantsmind.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/excel-level-maturity.png" alt="Good Excel Model - Excel Levels - Graph" /></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Some excel pointers to add on to my excel sheet:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> Keep the data separate and clean (no subtotals, no blank columns between data) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Reference the same source cells (so that 1 change affects everything) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>" The goal here is to make the model both easy-to-use and also easy-to-audit. After spending 40-50 hours putting this monster together, spend a little time cleaning it up. You don’t want half-baked, left-over calculations everywhere. "</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^more reasons I need to complete my things... I think another key is to give myself <strong>deadlines</strong>. And to <strong>complete things </strong>within the deadlines.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Client-ready:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>-what this means, in terms of my work and in terms of my persona... i.e. probably when I was sitting on the ground at the client site and the client walked in and GS was like get up XD</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>on excel:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> Create a dashboard on the first page that shows all the major metrics and status. Ideally, this is the only thing they look at because it is so comprehensive </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong>A client-facing excel model is like a yacht.&nbsp; It has all the bells and whistles and is very refined. A lot of the models made by investment bankers or valuation specialists are like this. Each font color has a different meaning (e.g., black = input, blue = calculation), and the excels are formatted for easy navigation without a mouse. Note: investment banking analysts pride themselves on the fact that they don’t use a mouse. All keyboard. </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^yup learned about the keyboard, no mouse thing from my last study :P</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>More tips:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Document the assumptions (data sources, links etc) so it is easy to audit</li><li>Take out unnecessary data sheets or things unrelated to the model.&nbsp; Just like an appendix of a book, put all the boring data tables and reference stuff in the back</li><li>If you have analyses (charts, tables), put them in the front of the workbook</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On gathering data / how clients' data often is:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> So, as odd as it sounds. . . consultants need to be thankful that the client’s data is usually a mess. It means more work, projects, billing and money. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong>Good data is hard to find.&nbsp;</strong>In my experience, the larger, the more geographically dispersed, and the older the company = the messier the data. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^this reminds me of my final ISE senior project... We did this kind of for P Investors</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>XD interesting stories:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>On my first consulting project, I spend several late nights alone typing shipping data from paper invoices into an excel spreadsheet</li><li>Just a few months ago, we consolidated data from 60+ separate emails into one excel.&nbsp; How can you look at trend data when it is sitting in 60 daily reports?</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ask any analyst, and they will have their own hazing story of collecting data in some manual and crazy way. As long as companies don’t take the time or the effort to do this, they will continue to pay $$$$ / hour for this mundane task to get done.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here's a theme I've heard in org / agile studies: " <strong>Figure out clear roles / responsibilities.&nbsp;</strong>Who’s job is it anyways?&nbsp; If it is everyone’s job, then in effect, it is no one’s job. "</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>v insightful!:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Lack of data requires consultant creativity.&nbsp;</strong>Sometimes, consultants have to uncover, create, cleanse, triangulate or even create data to answer key questions. Creativity is needed here. It is also a great way to “wow” the client.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Creating data is not sketchy or unethical.</strong> Some of consulting tools used to find new data include: surveys, <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2012/11/04/consultant-interview/" target="_blank">interviews</a>, focus groups, workshops, financial comparisons, observations, estimates, simulations, business models, <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2012/06/10/best-practices/" target="_blank">benchmarks</a>, <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2012/07/01/maturity-model/" target="_blank">maturity models</a>, and others. More on surveys in the next post.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On <em>how</em> to dig deeper into data:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong>Analysis</strong>: Get off the couch and dig deeper into the data. <em>Link it to other data, group it differently, run regression, look for outliers, find the “a ha” insight </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>--</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>More explanations of this job:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong>“Oh, you are so good making pretty presentations.” </strong>I have heard this more than once and it drives me a little crazy. The “pretty” part of the presentation is the equivalent of choosing the garnish for a plate of pasta, or the jacket design for a book. Are clients paying $250-$500 per billable hour for presentation jockeys? Doubt it. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong> the end result is a presentation</strong>. There is no glory in showing the client all the gory details.  You need to really boil it down to its essence. Apply the <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2012/10/27/using-averages/" target="_blank">80/20 principle</a>, and give the client only the good stuff.  Harvard Business School essays <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://www.hbs.edu/mba/admissions/application-process/Pages/written-application-introduce-yourself.aspx" target="_blank">have a limit of 400 words</a>, which is damn tough to do. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image -->
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://www.consultantsmind.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/busy-executive.png" alt="Powerpoint - Graph" /><figcaption> Often times, the executive sponsor of a project will really only commit 10-12 hours of total time for a 4 month project. The client project lead will be working with you on a day-to-day basis, but you have to remember that <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970204642604577215013504567548.html" target="_blank">executives are short on time</a>, and long on opinion.  &lt;- this makes sense when I look back on my FM proj</figcaption></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This makes a lot of sense to me too:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image -->
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://www.consultantsmind.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/communication-is-the-goal1.png" alt="Powerpoint - Graph" /><figcaption>As a consultant, being mindful of articulating a view so that client can articulate it to their stakeholders... coaching them through it... " Often times, pieces and parts of the presentation are used by the client to <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/actiontrumpseverything/2012/07/22/how-extremely-successful-people-sell-their-ideas-internally/" target="_blank">“sell” the recommendation to other people</a> – the boss, peers and others. "</figcaption></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Woot these are visual tools (aka archetype frameworks) that I got to work with in my project:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Stage-gate process – narrowing down of options, projects, investment ideas</li><li><a href="http://consultantsmind.com/2012/04/28/dmaic/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Phases of a project</a>&nbsp;– start, middle, and end</li><li>Venn diagram – the overlap of 2 distinct things</li><li><a href="http://consultantsmind.com/2013/09/21/what-is-an-s-curve/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">S curve</a>&nbsp;– the evolution, growth, and plateau of a function</li><li>2 x 2 matrix – simple X vs. Y axis</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:image -->
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://www.consultantsmind.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/powerpoint-diagrams.png" alt="Powerpoint - Graph" /></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Reason why: Graphs, tables, lists, groups, diagrams all help to convey a lot of information in a concise way. Each of the shapes below can help convey meaning.   </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>At compiling presentations:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong>Most people are terrible at it. </strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"Full of text, no narrative, no takeaway. They are essentially a compilation of facts, or a copy/paste from a document.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Big win for consultants. As long as people are crappy at distilling complex problems into easy-to-follow, logical recommendations that are easily communicated to executives."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>THUS to do in my presentations:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>visual, yes narrative, yes takeaway</li><li>insightful, not just a compilation of facts</li><li>easy-to-follow, logical recommendations that are easily communicated to execs (boiled from a complex problem)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>==</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>interesting things learned about mck:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>What many people don’t know is that prior to 2009, McKinsey printed most of their client charts in black and white. Color and graphics can help, but are not required. Unsurprisingly, <em>content is king</em>. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> McKinsey idea is that each slide and/or graph makes 1 point. Ergo, graphs should be simple and as “in your face” obvious as possible. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also each slide should be able to stand on it's own.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>==</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>ppt tips:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>source:  <a href="http://www.consultantsmind.com/2012/04/30/ppt/">http://www.consultantsmind.com/2012/04/30/ppt/</a> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Great reminders! incl: *use of a red box to highlight something</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong>Appendix</strong>: Don’t fall in love with your work. If the slide is informative, but does not have a compelling point. . . worst case, move it to the appendix.  <em>(informative slides without so-what often are in appendix!)</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>this makes sense, on ownership - when I own a doc, this is what I have to do!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong>Combine the pieces, and the final 20% should be done by one person.  </strong>In the final days, hours of the presentation. . . 1 person needs to be accountable and take ownership. All the words, shapes, colors, font needs to be standardized and smoothed out. Sadly, it is a 1-person job. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>==</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>@me on my next study:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> Get a team mate to<a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2013/05/05/6-reasons-why-consultants-are-revision-crazy/" target="_blank"> proof read</a>, get it close to perfect &lt;- do ask teammates for feedback if I'm nervous or not sure it'll be 100% </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>---</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In the future, I may pursue this: Walk with client back to their office after a meeting! (I have seen my senior colleagues do this... walking with a client to continue talking after a meeting... sometimes taking time before a meeting too to just chat... makes environment funner and better)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Clearly, some of the best conversations you have with clients are the ones on the way back from meetings. Trust me on this one, when a meeting finishes, ask your client if it is okay to walk them back to their office. Walk and talk.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>You have their dedicated attention, even if only for 5 minutes</li><li>It is authentic and personal; it’s how friends and colleagues relate to each other</li><li>It is often a great follow-up to the meeting you just finished</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Often, the key things you want to say to a client are personal, and can easily be conveyed in a few minutes in an informal setting. It does not deserve an email, phone call or a meeting. Walk them back to their office.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A few&nbsp;other ways to have impactful, and brief interactions with clients:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Share a coffee or a meal together</strong></li><li>Offer to help with a simple task (create graph, draft a communication)</li><li>Send over an analyst report or benchmark study</li><li><strong>Type up meeting minutes, or interview notes and send over</strong></li><li>Connect your current client with other people in your network</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>===</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Soft skills for working with clients:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Saving face: don't disagree with client in front of others</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>- It’s a very Asian business culture concept of harmony, and it is super-applicable to consultants.  &lt;- interesting!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Some phrases to use in a kind way to get to same purpose:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>In my experience. . .</li><li>Maybe it is just me, but. .</li><li>Yes, I agree, AND. . .</li><li>Makes sense, do you think that its possible that. .  </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also these reccs are super great:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Recommendation:&nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Win-win.</strong>&nbsp;Build on the analysis that your client has already done</li><li><strong>Emphasize&nbsp;the headwinds:&nbsp;</strong>&nbsp;Make it clear that the current problems have many factors (of which some / many) are out of the client’s control</li><li><strong>Gain trust early.&nbsp;</strong>The sooner that you gain the client’s trust and&nbsp;become an adviser, the sooner you can push-back appropriately.</li><li><strong>Ask for feedback too. &nbsp;</strong>Ask the client what areas you can improve and get better. &nbsp;They should not be the&nbsp;only ones who improve.</li><li><strong>Let your clients present. &nbsp;</strong>Don’t take credit. &nbsp;Let your clients present the results to their boss. Make them the heroes.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Communicate, if I were to hire for a PM, one thing most important is alignment with mission and long-term thinking. Because that stands out. A PM that is in it for the long run... to see through the impact years down of actions today.</p>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Tactical tips from default choices:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>#4</strong><strong>.&nbsp; In sales, use the assumptive close.&nbsp;</strong>A well-known, and proven tactic in closing the sale with a client is called the “assumptive close.” It goes like this.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You have vetted the client, know their needs, and believe in good conscience that your product/service is needed. The client is hesitant or just indecisive. Judging on the situation and your selling style, just proceed as if they agreed to buy. Essentially, you are giving them the default choice of buying from you – unless they tell you otherwise.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As strange as it sounds, it works.&nbsp; In a previous life, I was a stockbroker and there is nothing as raw as selling stocks.&nbsp; “Mr. Smith, sounds like this is a good fit for you, and you are interested in XYZ.&nbsp; I will put you down for 100 shares at the market price, okay?”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>#5. Beware of default choices.&nbsp;</strong>As a consultant, a good part of your job is to see past the default choices that the client’s organization has convinced itself of over the last 50 years. They have oral history, precedents, and institutional memory. Things we hear:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>“We can’t do that, we tried that before”&nbsp; [default choice]</li><li>“They VP will never agree to that” [default choice]</li><li>“We have never done that type of project before” [default choice]</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>--</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>love this: Viewing career at a company as a S-curve:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image -->
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://www.consultantsmind.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/consultantsmind-career-s-curve.png" alt="Consultantsmind Career S curve" /><figcaption>Considerations when joining a new company:  <strong>Where is the group in its S-curve? </strong> The same life-cycle question applies to companies and groups.  If you are joining a start up within a large established company, which culture is going to be more important to you?  Stability and process? Newness and ambiguity?  How big is the group, is it growing or shrinking?  How does the group map up to the C-suite (operations, finance, marketing, sales, HR)?<br>What’s the context of the company vs. their competitor? </figcaption></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Point for self if I become a EM:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Timing is important. &nbsp;</strong>Choose your battles. &nbsp;How much you correct depends on depth of the relationship, urgency of the deliverable, and basically, your mood:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>With 1 week before the deliverable, there is enough time to “rev” the document several times, each time, layering on feedback until they take a hint</li><li>Night before a deliverable, you have to be blunt, and get the changes made; take over the work if you have to, make it learning by example</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:image -->
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://www.consultantsmind.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/coaching-environment.png" alt="Consultantsmind - Coaching" /><figcaption>my takeaway from this image is: all the black words are needed to have a conducive coaching environment</figcaption></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>v important pt I think: <em>being likeable</em>:  <a href="http://www.consultantsmind.com/2014/06/02/likable/">http://www.consultantsmind.com/2014/06/02/likable/</a> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>WHY</strong>: Unless the client can connect with you – intellectually, emotionally, or otherwise – you are just another salesperson peddling product.  As a consultant, one of your most important jobs right out of the gates is to have a connection, create some common ground.  Give them a reason to like you, make it easy to build <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2013/05/23/consulting-skill-building-rapport-quickly-can-save-you-143/" target="_blank">rapport </a>quickly. Ultimately, be yourself. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>the <strong>HOW</strong>:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Be competent.  </strong>Know your stuff. Be useful.  Be a resource for other people.  In a business setting, if you are not competent. . . well, nothing really to like.</li><li><strong>Be dependable.  </strong>Keep your promises to your client and your team.  In a <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2012/07/01/maturity-model/" target="_blank">maturity model</a> of professionalism, this is level 0, the ground floor.  Not dependable = fail.</li><li><strong>Slow down.  </strong>We are so busy that we constantly multi-task and sometimes do things poorly.  In an effort to get things “off our plate” we cut corners, don’t listen, and run roughshod over people.  When you are fast (but sloppy), it’s hard to be sure of the quality of the work.  I tell consultants to “stay frosty” and self-aware.</li><li><strong>Give.  </strong>Realize that life is not about you. (deep <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://www.amazon.com/The-Purpose-Driven-Life-Earth/dp/031033750X" target="_blank">Rick Warren thought</a>). Give your time, your energy, your passion, and your empathy to others.  Ask the question, “Is there anything I can do to help you with your work?</li><li><strong>Be self-deprecating. </strong> This is a big SAT word, but basically be willing to make fun of yourself, when needed.  It is disarming, and vulnerable.  It shows that we are all not perfect, and lowers everyone’s guard.</li><li><strong>Think relationships.  </strong>Think in terms of people, not transactions.  Put yourself in their shoes.  Realize that clients have a “day job” and are not fully dedicated to the project like your and your team are.  Ask for help, rather than demanding it.</li><li><strong>Be easy to understand.</strong>  It’s no surprise that people tend to like people who are like themselves – in speaking pattern, disposition, educational background etc.  For all the talk of diversity, most people are surprisingly socially insular.  As such, make it easy for people to “get what you are saying.” Write simple and direct emails. Mirror your clients’ speaking style.  If they speak slowly and quietly, you won’t be a likable character if you come in speaking quickly and raising your voice.  Be yourself, but apply different communication styles when needed.</li><li><strong>Be yourself. </strong>It’s a crazy competitive world, and the gap in quality (actual and perceived) keeps shrinking.  Unsurprisingly, there are lots of vendors, products, and people who can solve your client or prospects’ problems.   That said, you are unique, and that is appealing.  Be the best you there is.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>another few words on building rapport quickly: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Why </strong>it's important: fundamentally, people like to help <em><strong>people</strong></em> (not just another person in a suit).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>What</strong>: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Rapport:&nbsp;</strong>Being able to build rapport quickly is a huge asset.&nbsp; It’s a mix of friendliness, approachability, optimism, courtesy, and likeability.&nbsp; You become a magnet.&nbsp; Essentially, people are attracted to you.&nbsp; You become worthy of their attention, time, and effort.&nbsp; I think there is a correlation between consultants and good looks, but I am biased.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Example:</strong>&nbsp;On my first project, I failed in the task of getting some data from the client.&nbsp; The administrator said it could not be done.&nbsp; My manager went into that admin’s office, talked about sports for 20 minutes, and got the data as if had been lying on the desk.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In consulting, it is a combination of hard and soft skills.  The hard skills are easy to test for, the soft-skills are less apparent.  If your new hire cannot build rapport . . . you have a problem. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>How</strong>:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Be respectful.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>This sounds old-fashioned,&nbsp; I know, but few people have manners today.&nbsp; If you are courteous and respectful, people will pay attention to you.</li><li><strong>Be humble.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>Admit you need help.&nbsp; Be self-deprecating.&nbsp; Be willing to make fun of yourself.&nbsp; Give them the opportunity to help you.&nbsp; It is disarming.</li><li><strong>Be fun.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>Apply a little bit of humor.&nbsp; Take the edge off.&nbsp; Have fun.&nbsp; The government worker I had some good banter.&nbsp; He made my day, but I made his too.</li><li><strong>Be relevant.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>Find connection points.&nbsp; See how the local sports team did last night.&nbsp; Talk about food, travel, sports, children or things important to you.</li><li><strong>Be yourself.&nbsp;&nbsp;</strong>Don’t fake niceness.&nbsp; Don’t try to schmooze your way into their heart.&nbsp; One absolute rule about clients: they know when you are lying.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>=</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Whoa I like this:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In this week’s Fortune magazine,&nbsp;<a href="http://money.cnn.com/2013/04/11/news/companies/ben-jerry-ice-cream.pr.fortune/index.html" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Ben and Jerry’s co-founders</a>&nbsp;talked about their 30+ year working relationship and had some good advice. Jerry Greenfield said:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:quote -->
<blockquote class="wp-block-quote"><p>“Our basic agreement was that the person who felt more strongly about the particular issue got their way,”</p></blockquote>
<!-- /wp:quote -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^published in a separate post :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>also from that source ( <a href="http://www.consultantsmind.com/2013/05/05/6-reasons-why-consultants-are-revision-crazy/">http://www.consultantsmind.com/2013/05/05/6-reasons-why-consultants-are-revision-crazy/</a> ), it mentions all the stakeholders that need to be aligned on a deliverable... which makes sense now how partners needed to see everything.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Great list on <strong>what to proofread!</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>link:  <a href="https://www.consultantsmind.com/2015/08/22/consultants-are-serious-proof-readers/">https://www.consultantsmind.com/2015/08/22/consultants-are-serious-proof-readers/</a> , prob biggest takeaway: <em> Style:  Good writing is <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2015/01/16/clear-writing/" target="_blank">direct</a>.  Take out superfluous, flowery, or deliberately vague consulting-y language.  For a list of cheesy consulting words look <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2012/10/07/consultant-jargon/" target="_blank">here</a>. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I did learn this too:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Explain it as if you were speaking to a kid.&nbsp;</strong>This is the most common piece of advice I give to junior consultants who make PowerPoint slides. Explain this 1 page as if you were explaining it to your nephew, cousin or husband. What&nbsp;are you trying to say (in&nbsp;simple words, and simple sentences).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Too often, consultants can verbally explain it to you clearly in 90 seconds, but oddly, none of those wonderfully clear, basic words are on the page. As a result, I tell them to blow up the PowerPoint slide, and re-do it with the words they just told me verbally.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>=</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>XD We had our own jargon and acrynoms, the website mentions:  Scientific wild-ass guess (<strong>SWAG</strong>)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>=</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Great McK tip:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong>Train your eye. </strong>Look through business magazines, research papers, and presentations to look for good graphs, tables, and charts. All consultants need to know what good looks like. <strong>One of the tips from <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://www.amazon.com/The-McKinsey-Way-Ethan-Rasiel/dp/0070534489" target="_blank">McKinsey Way</a> is to draw 1 graph a day. That is truly good advice, as this helps you to tell visual stories. </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>great skim on how to get up to speed quickly on a project:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>link:  <a href="https://steveshuconsulting.com/2018/08/management-consultants-quickly-speed-projects/">https://steveshuconsulting.com/2018/08/management-consultants-quickly-speed-projects/</a> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>learned from that:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Industry reports – Consultants often dive into industry reports very close to when they arrive onsite for a new client. This can help the consultant come up to speed about industry-specific terminology, product offerings, competitors, new entrants, regulatory issues, geographical considerations, etc. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>and what a workplan is! (I also did learn this in my study)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>the workplan is addressed in the first week +/-. These often breakdown the workstreams, key activities, deliverables, project roles, and governance structure </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>=</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>on power:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> The patriarch of McKinsey, <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://www.economist.com/node/13432134" target="_blank">Marvin Bower</a>, rightly felt that management consultants should have the highest level of professionalism, integrity, and candor.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>related to J's dad and I's convo... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>link is just an overview of tenaments of consulting and how they relate to 3 types of power:  <a href="http://www.consultantsmind.com/2013/02/21/3-kinds-of-power-positional-relational-and-expertise/">http://www.consultantsmind.com/2013/02/21/3-kinds-of-power-positional-relational-and-expertise/</a> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>words:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong>Kick-off meeting. (Positional)</strong> It is customary to have a kick-off meeting where the executive sponsor formally introduces the consultants to her staff, thereby, “loaning” the consultants some of her authority.  This allows the consultants to do work and create change. It’s like being a substitute teacher, it is a privilege and borrowed power. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong> Best practices. (Expertise) </strong>Consultants bring some objectivity because they benefit from working at multiple competitors, suppliers and customers. Clients like to have that “outside-in” perspective and know where they stand relatively in performance. “What is best practice?” is a common question from executives. <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2012/06/10/best-practices/" target="_blank">Best practices</a>, <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2012/07/01/maturity-model/" target="_blank">maturity models</a>, <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2012/11/14/bain-management-tools-and-trends/" target="_blank">benchmarks</a>, and survey results are all examples of expertise power. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://consultantsmind.com/2012/04/15/love-data/" target="_blank">Consultants love data for many reasons</a> – including the fact that data gives the consultants credibility and conviction. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Being on-site. (Relational)  </strong>Generally, consultants don’t have a lot of relational equity. They might know the “buyer” of the services, but often meet the stakeholders at the kick-off meeting.  So, <strong>it is critically important to get to know the working-level stakeholders as soon as possible. Collaboration is a two-way street.  Some of it has to do with being professional, friendly, and helpful. Some of it has to do with the tacit understanding that consultants can help (or sometimes hurt) career prospects.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In my mind, one of the main reasons that consultants are often at the client site Monday-Thursday is for relational reasons.  The<strong> travel is a beast, but it is an effective way to work with the clients, get to know each other, share meals, and build relationship</strong><em>s</em>.  The ex-CMO of Deloitte wrote a best-seller on <strong>building relationships </strong>called <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://amzn.to/29JBShu" target="_blank">Never Eat Alone</a> (affiliate link). Guess what the<strong> main point of the book is. . . . . never eat alone</strong>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>==</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>To read in the future... if I'm presenting to a larger group! (incls how to tailor the deck)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> The best presentation requires no PowerPoint. Tell <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.consultantsmind.com/2014/09/19/stories/" target="_blank">stories</a>. Grab the audience’s attention. <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.consultantsmind.com/2017/09/25/be-likeable/" target="_blank">Be likable, be yourself</a>. Enumerate your points #1, #2, #3. <strong>Walk around the audience and use the space. <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.consultantsmind.com/2012/04/20/pause/" target="_blank">Pause</a> for effect. Speak 20% louder than you think you have to. Animate – use your arms, and expressions. Importantly, have fun. </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>link:  <a href="https://www.consultantsmind.com/2018/05/01/large-groups/">https://www.consultantsmind.com/2018/05/01/large-groups/</a> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Read Link 0 first (19 Excel modeling tips, incl comments):  <a href="http://www.consultantsmind.com/2014/12/11/excel-modeling-tips/">http://www.consultantsmind.com/2014/12/11/excel-modeling-tips/</a> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>somewhat interesting: " <em>We might use Powerpoint to simplify complex ideas, and hallway conversations to build client rapport, but excel is where the money is made</em>. From my experience, there are 10 hours of Excel for every 1 hour of Powerpoint. "</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>" <strong>Eureka moments</strong>: Although people think of PowerPoint for its graphics and visuals, it is when you are analyzing data with excel that those Eureka moments avail themselves. Powerpoint is for telling stories. Excel is for uncovering the real story. "</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":1} -->
<h1>“He stepped down, trying not to look long at her, as if she were the sun, yet he saw her, like the sun, even without looking.”</h1>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>―&nbsp;<strong>Leo Tolstoy,&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/2507928">Anna Karenina</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But I read the sun quote in a YA book I think... how the planets revolved around it.</p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong>On building client relationships</strong>: it is critically important to get to know the working-level stakeholders as soon as possible. Collaboration is a two-way street.  Some of it has to do with being professional, friendly, and helpful. Some of it has to do with the tacit understanding that consultants can help (or sometimes hurt) career prospects. </p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>pre-story I) New life hack I'm going to try out: when I misspell a word (as I do quite often...), instead of right click + correct, I'm going to right click to see what the correct spelling is, and then delete and re-spell from the start.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>and: misspell</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Effervescence </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>pre-story II) Playing piano has made me more creative in other elements (i.e. writing!). This makes sense to me. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Story: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>cleaning ladies</li><li>.......</li><li>I HAVE to frame it so that I'm not complaining at all, and these aren't seen as negatives!</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For example, when my roommate cleans the apartment and throws out a bunch of old stuff, then it feels easier for me to do so as well! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When my roommate buys a bunch of new things including to organize stuff, I am inspired to as well!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
And

Figure out how to remove the negative aspects of the feeling of not getting
*not sponsored

1) free WiFi on flight for messaging and movies (and pretty great movie selection btw!)

2) free snacks

3) wonder moments. The little, unexpected but very welcome comments that brighten my day for a few moments

4) we get to choose our own seats! Being in a priority ticket means there's ample room in an emergency row. Or if I don't want to wait getting out of the plane, being near the very front.

5) our tickets also have a drink voucher, which I personally don't need, but it's cool! Not needing to pay for an alcoholic beverage (even if the company is paying for it if I bought one on a different Airline).

6) another one I no longer am using much: 2 free checked bags. It's the little things that just make the experience phenomenal!
Great things I've learned:

Take time, don't put all funds in immediately

Don't procrastinate, actions should align with goals

Learn and track lessons learned, reasons and outcomes for each action

Diversify: at times, I want a large sum to make a large bet AND consistently invest in index funds

LEARN! There's wisdom in the past as well. Tune out the noise.

long term for me now: decades

Make a plan, stick to it, but ALSO examine it every year because circumstances change and we learn more

<p>Here's a story.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There was an old man living in a house on the corner of a street. At this corner, there was a middle school bus stop where a girl and a boy waited in the mornings for the yellow school bus to make its daily route to take them to class.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On one newly snowed Chicago winter morning, the girl and boy stood waiting at that corner, trying not to show their shivering, when the old man living in the house came out and said Good Morning. The girl waited for the boy to say something. The boy didn't say anything. The old man then asked kindly, Would you both like a ride to school? Again, the boy didn't say anything. The girl was scared </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>snack less, cook more :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>hang out with friends - plan something!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<p>Don't forget what I have that others don't... The break... I don't need to have an existential crisis. I don't need to try out tech. I've already dabbled around enough to know what I have is gold.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sure, I worked "hard" the last few years of college. But this "hard" was just a relentless prioritization. Less time for friendship, more time for planning, and sticking to it to get in those meetings, coding sessions, presentations, homework sessions, lecture and TA hours. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Prior to working hard, I took a break - the opposite of working hard. Traveling France and Morocco. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Then after working hard in college, I took another break - I had a year where the first semester I basically chilled (though I interviewed a ton) on campus and then the second semester I completely chilled at Boulder, Colorado.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Oh and then when work started? My first month was "on the beach" and so was the next month after my first study. I'm hoping for a few more weeks on the beach to reflect and chill again as well before emailing partners for my next staffing :D. What a freaking blessing - having days in between work. </p>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I want him to be C-level. I believe he can - he's got the work ethic, he's got the build (he fits in with the skin and height and gender of many in that group) and accompanying incredible look when clothes fit him, he's got the intelligence, he's got the growth mindset, he's got some sort of business foundation, and beyond all of that, he's got the EQ... he has the people skills, he has the posture, he has the presentation skills, he has the caring heart and honest values.</p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Her ..</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Her love for the man in our lives was ....</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>She created with poise. Her free time consisted of dance, keyboard, and poetry </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Play time were legos, books, make pretend. Hikes, knight-battles in the neighboring forest. Screaming on the top of our lungs at the top of the snow-capped mountain. Jumpy, Golden, Rose.. our chickens pecking the feed in our backyard.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Through it all, we chased wonder. We caught wonder in our bare hands and feet. Looked up at the full moon and the summer solstice colors. We biked along these streets lined with marvelous trees.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We fought and cried and laughed and hugged. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Then working backwards perhaps.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Combination of fiction and non-fiction</li><li>Collection of thoughts, glimpses, feelings I've had, into fictional stories with emotion... </li><li>And things about life that I've learned through these past years</li><li>Combined into a collective story, that ties together after a few chapters, yaknow</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<p>Feb 21st, 2020</p>

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Pushing back, i.e. Ch making many requests to client - standing my ground to not overwhelm clients :) - learned from Curt J!</li><li>pushing back in meetings too... sometimes clients don't know as deeply as I do</li><li>practicing speaking terms i.e. "Anything else"? + repeating back what I heard, + using an example to illustrate a point :D &lt;- woot first practiced at WCU!</li></ul>

<p>I'm going to start dating these... The dates of when I'm writing them down.</p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Mar 2nd, 2020</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Successful leaders build other leaders... having others do your works makes you that much more effective. Leverage, etc.</li><li>Again, over communicate. Incl/i.e. giving context. People are busy people; context switching can be difficult, make it easier for everyone by practicing context habit :) </li><li>I've learned and practiced meeting tools, like when I'm presenting, stopping and asking "Any questions" instead of rushing through and having others interrupt with questions. This also makes me seem more confident, present, and thoughtful to others :) instead of "I just want to keep going and get this done"</li><li>Another meeting tool I learned from WCU: On <em>answering</em> questions: making sure people feel heard... going behind answering quickly, but addressing the concern behind that question. </li><li>Speaking with authority when I don't have much... saying "someone else" that the person I'm trying to convince, respects (i.e. KNOW, a McK expert, a GLG call, a partner, etc.) said something or thinks something or asked for something... </li><li>This is huge:</li><li>!!!*I*!!!! need to prioritize my life. Decide what I want. Even more important when things get busy, even during sprints; to have anchors to see when things are steering off course. During this study: exercise :)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<p>WCU = West Coast University</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Possible workout routines using free weights or body weight:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>arms? https://www.womenshealthmag.com/uk/fitness/workouts/a706391/free-weights-workout/ </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Day 1 of WC U (brain dump):</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong><span style="text-decoration:underline;">On answering questions:</span></strong></li><li>It's OK to gather my thoughts before talking (do this more!)</li><li>When I say "that's a good question" to every question... sure it buys me time; but it's also <em>insincere</em></li><li>Acknowledge questions/answers: "That's a valid concern," also by summarizing questions: "You're asking ____, correct?," "I'm hearing...," etc. This is step 1 of empathy.</li><li>Step 2 of empathy is learning more about people's concerns; learning the reason behind why they asked the question, what they're really afraid of, and addressing it in an empathetic manner</li><li>Ex: "what if we can't make these deadlines?" A: "what are your concerns with meeting the deadlines?" (instead of say, A: words that end up saying "we have to meet these deadlines... we'll find a way no matter what to meet these deadlines")</li><li>^ex consultants are known for... </li><li>Poised phrases can also show graceful "exit"s: "....I'd love to address that more with you offline"</li><li>When I'm thinking and my sentences may not be very structured: "I'm going to think/brainstorm out loud for a second..." (+ possibly ask "is that ok?")</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>On when I'm talking and realize I mess up:</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong><span style="text-decoration:underline;">Prior to a meeting:</span></strong></li><li>Remind self to remind group of the 4Ps: Purpose, Payoff (what's in it for them), Preview, Process &lt;- I can see this applicable sometimes</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong><span style="text-decoration:underline;">On presence (during a meeting):</span> </strong></li><li>First sentence I say sets the tone... In presentations, <strong>make sure I know my first sentence</strong> and I say it loudly, clearly, confidently, and with the accompanying body language.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong><span style="text-decoration:underline;">On myself</span></strong> (for my personal increase of self awareness... the first step*)</li><li>Advice I keep hearing include:</li><li>I'm personable, I'm a nice person, I'm genuine</li><li> I blink a lot in front of cameras!</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong><span style="text-decoration:underline;">On building gravitas:</span></strong></li><li>Sit up straight</li><li>Be louder - get attention</li><li>Say as little as I can</li><li>"Ze who holds the silence, holds the power" - Robert Cera (or something)</li><li>Also: speak with a clear voice</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong><span style="text-decoration:underline;">Other tips:</span></strong></li><li>Choose times to go in depth (like a somewhat unexpected aside)... this shows passion</li><li>"Lead with your intelligence" ("intelligence" being boobs) ("leading" with them being stand up straight girl!)</li><li>Say less... like 1/2 amount I'm currently saying and pause more. White space is OK, is powerful!</li><li>Show excitement/passion on what I'm saying even if I'm not really, or if I've drilled the topic to the ground already; by choosing one small thing that I am genuinely passionate about, practice that, remember the bodily feeling of that, and apply that feeling to more of presentation</li><li>Align: visual, vocal, content, intention</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Steps*:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>self awareness - taking inventory of self</li><li>choice - choosing what of myself I want to keep and strengthen to become my brand, and choosing what of myself "doesn't serve me" as much</li><li>pilot choices! - see if I like the actual effects of changes</li><li>continue learning, repeat from step 1 continuously :) after all, I have some time to create my personal brand!</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<p>Not organized, but a month later (today is 3/2), I'm continuing writing on this:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>No longer organized, just digitalizing</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Prior to meeting, 1) think what my intentional impression will be, 2) interject my voice in meeting early on</li><li>Being energized when I'm already an expert/bored with subject: find something small to be energized about, remember that body feeling and carry that throughout :)</li><li>Throwing in something unexpected gets people's attention </li><li>Get people's interest: say "why" ... incl why they should care</li><li>DO NOT SAY "I think" &lt;- I really need to practice this... This is great wisdom. People/clients don't care what *I* think... they care what i.e. an accredited expert thinks, what industry thinks, what the firm thinks, etc.</li><li>@me: I've become more self-aware to smile less/find a balance... supply and demand :P, smiles are worth more when I toss them out less :P and more intentionally. Also I think I say "awesome", "cool", etc too much, incl in meetings with senior(etc) people... Figure out a way to do this less and replace it with something else. ALSO SILENCES ARE POWERFUL ! :D</li><li>...</li><li></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Write down your goals</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Write down the systems you’ll put in place to achieve those goals</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Write down the books you read</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Write down what you learn from those books</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Write down meeting action items</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Write down daily priorities</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Write down your thoughts, your stories, your dreams</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Just write! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>LThe <strong>why</strong>: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>1) Free up your working memory, be more present</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>2) Imprints what you write in your mind </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>https://www.lifehack.org/articles/featured/writing-and-remembering-why-we-remember-what-we-write.html</p>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>It's difficult to gauge sentiment</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>It's easier to avoid group think... </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>More observations learned from a highly digital coordinating team:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Still pause and ask for questions!!! Questions are really important. i.e. "Let me know if you have any questions before I move onto ____"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>More verbage (when asking a "dumb" question that you think everyone else in a meeting knows,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Some verbages that I've learned at GS :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>("Sorry just for my education") - AND SPEAK Steadily and with confidence </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>("I think we've run a little over, I really appreciate this because this is really important discussion")</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>("X name, would you mind taking notes?" *just ask!)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>It's ok to not pay attention<br>Often in meetings, you're sitting in a meeting you don't *need* to be there. Heck, you can be spending the precious hour finishing up that 10 page report due tomorrow. But traditional culture has it so that you should be sitting in the meeting, fully focused... Doing something else while someone else is speaking is rude.<br>THOUSANDS of people hours are wasted here!<br><br>However on Zoom, it's okay to turn your video off. To go on mute. To jump in when someone calls you.</li><li>...</li></ol>

<p>That world-class leaders can be made by acquiring phrases to conversational speech:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"Does that make sense? Any questions?"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"Any thoughts on that? Does that resonate?"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"X name, correct me if I'm wrong"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"Can we pause here and get your reactions X name and Y name?"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"My bias is..."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"What I'm suggesting is..."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On a page that is filled with text, mention "The key X points I'd like to highlight are 1) ... 2) ..."</p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Traditional movie marketing:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>1) it's about the people - i) having star-studded cast who will then do interviews, generate buzz, etc., ii) it's about pandering to the critics / reviewers who have sway and credence in the industry<br>2) other forms: meeting people where they're at... in terms of posters across towns, effective trailers, etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Book marketing - James Patterson:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Market yourself - <strong>build your personal brand... i.e. what do you want to be known for</strong>.... i.e. James' brand (i.e. page turners, prolific writer)</li><li>Social media!! (Twitter, fb, etc...) How to get people to pay attention? GET THEIR ATTENTION - put something out there, get people curious, be provocative... and then be consistent  </li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Routine - publish</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Possible learnings:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Marketing is to bring awareness to help sell. But the mindset is to help. To show something that someone needs to benefit and enhance their life.</li><li>... </li></ol>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The external world is already really good at motivating others. The incentives are already put in place and there are external pressures and rewards involving others such as reputation in integrity and ____... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For example, ...teachers, etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Our internal motivation wanes however. The same systems are not set up in place. So if from the morning to the end of the day, we are constantly succumbing to the motivations of others, we lose the willpower we have most of when we are refreshed and wake up.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Another reason why to do the hardest thing to self-motivate self as early as possible is because mindset-wise, you build: 1) self-efficacy, 2) habits / routine, which in turn builds, 3) motivation and the fly-wheel of productivity. Doing one thing (<em>e.g., sending that one email, submitting your taxes, finishing a chapter of ACT prep, etc.</em>) to a self defined "completion" - even if it's small, and actually especially if it's small - will trigger a flywheel or rolling snowball effect of getting more things done right after or throughout the day which compounds over life! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Quick take on who I am: 23 y/o in management consulting with an adoration of people, presence, nature, movement, freedom, and happiness.</p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Reason for post:</strong> Snapshot of my consumer (time and money) behaviors in 2020 </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li><strong>Writing / note taking:</strong> Wordpress, Notion, SimpleNote (caveat: I'm switching many uses of SimpleNote to Notion)</li><li><strong>Apparel:</strong> Smartwool - socks, AG Adriano Goldschmied - jeans, Theory - work clothes, Nike - workout clothes, Birkenstock - shoes,  </li><li><strong>Content:</strong> Wes Anderson - movies, </li><li><strong>Food:</strong> Produce - farmers' markets and CSAs, bulk bins - co-ops and Whole Foods, frozen foods - Trader Joe's, </li></ol>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Key reasons of what I love: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>...</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Open questions: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>How do brands and products intersect? </li><li>What insights can I gain from brands deemed "successful" by me? What does data support...</li><li>What products do I sincerely dislike and avoid? </li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here's a potential chart of if I were to analyze my preferences:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Brands I love and am loyal to (expected behavior) | Brands I love and am not loyal to (not expected behavior... insights to be drawn from gap analysis from this and former category) | Brands I am impartial to and am loyal to (insight to inelastic demands? and potential other factors) | Brands I am impartial to and am not loyal to (expected behavior) | Brands I dislike and am loyal to () | Brands I dislike and am not loyal to () </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Then in each category / column, dive into the reasons "why" accompanying each Brand / Product, to see if there are trends.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Reasons for this analysis on myself - a data point of n = 1: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Time commitment required:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Opportunity cost:</strong> (this is done for minuscule decisions to larger decisions)<br>1) What else could I be doing now? How much value output (long term and short term, intrinsic and external, etc.) and effort input do the other opportunities have? <br>2) Is there a better / another time for me to do this? Is there something else that I could be doing right now that I can't do later? (i.e. I should workout outside right now / in the morning, because it'll rain the rest of the day starting noon; or I should drop out of school now because I can always "come back" to school; or I should start a startup now because I can always work for someone else since I've first built my skills and experiences to be hireable)<br>3) What secondary opportunity factors should I factor into consideration? (i.e. is my piece of work blocking someone else's for a common goal? An example of this is prioritizing sending emails / outreach communication earlier than later, so others know of my asks or instructions.)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Thought / thing I learned about myself writing this post: This is how I tend to structure thinking... for most things in life. Perhaps it's primarily a product of McK problem-solving reps, my industrial engineering college education, and economics high school classes.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<p>I love that McKinsey has the following BUILT INTO the system (like from the book "Nudge"... when something is set as "default" then it's much easier to accomplish than going against default and requiring extra energy):</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>...</li><li>More things I learned that I'm working on still! 1) Vocalizing my thoughts with less restriction... comes with reps :P, 2) Standing to my initial thoughts even when I'm not certain... because it probably has legs somewhere., 3) McK has smart people! There's a mindset of respecting and listening and asking to listen to what others have to say because of this premise... I think it's a great mindset to incorporate to my social interactions with other groups - because it leads to win-win (i.e. people can rise to who you think they are, people feel respected, my mindset creates more open-mindedness to listen), 4) working hard... and mindset / visualization (bringing things closer / to home) of what's possible... including myself, my peers, and leadership (i.e. partners)... making me also more empathetic when I "complain"... knowing what execs and others could be going through and knowing what is possible in productivity / efficiency / output :) </li></ul>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Biggest learnings at Mck :) PS skills, client skills, comm skills, page making skills - with practice (also check out decks from PE folks in their profile cuz they are tanks ;P and practice duplicating some slides... without using a mouse ? - to practice and memorize keyboard shortcuts!)</p>

<p>Ex: "At X age, everyone still looks around not sure what to do."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Better attacking ways:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>1. First listen to the opposition</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>2. Say “Yes And” ie “that’s a good point on X (in reference to a point they said that you genuinely agree with... and there’s got to be at least one if they’re passionate about their stand)... AND here’s another factor to consider...”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>3. Still use stories (emotion) and data (logic) to share your thoughts</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*both sides of argument should engage in all three points </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Increased / fervent desire creates sense of less mutual desire from gatekeeper to item of desire </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Even perhaps when the provider of desire may be a good fit for the gatekeeper. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The gatekeeper, also seeks feeling of scarcity associated with worth? For ex the gatekeeper may say yes to another provider of desire who seems less fervent...</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Like romantic courtship... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It’s a thing to learn in life.... when you really really want something, worth working hard for it, but not to show ferverence</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*me: to illustrate this and add illustration </p>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also, I just remembered the first day I was there, I put together an excel of the people to attend an event we were helping put on.... and that day, I was asked to present this to the CEO by the partner...<br><strong>Thing learned: be ahead of things, have things ready! </strong>You never know when you may need to present before a "deadline"<br>Also haha: my excel was formatted terribly (no formatting) with no oversight by anyone... I wonder if this gave the partner a minor heartattack. I also answered questions to the CEO about it! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Another memory: when I was drying my hair outside of the building (it's Arizona and really hot) and the partner arrives and asks if I'm ok and I tell her what I'm doing</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Team cartoon though... that I regret a bit... Having the core team, my first team, with the quotes and cartoon... that would've been awesome. <strong>Thing learned: 1) execute, 2) establish guardrails </strong><br>(Part of the reason it fell apart was because people kept joining the team and I wanted to include everyone :/)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here's what I know, all of it linking to my eating habits and accordingly, ME</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I wasn't stressed while at PP, <strong>I got enough sleep</strong>, I did a lot outside of work and sit and be lethargic</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I played ping-pong, I went paddleboarding / out into the water every day for <strong>breaks</strong>, I went water skiing in the morning</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I ate brunch pretty late - around 10-11am with protein (lots of EGGS!) (maybe this is one thing for me to change!!! I used to <strong>start my day with a lot of protein</strong>, recently, I've been just eating a lot of cereal which is lacking that protein!!! that kept me not hungry or having cravings during the day)</p>

<p>Advice on success and living from bestselling authors, entrepreneurs, investors, executives, and creative people.<br>— Read on <a href="https://forge.medium.com/33-things-i-stole-from-people-smarter-than-me-on-the-way-to-33-c38e368e5cb8">forge.medium.com/33-things-i-stole-from-people-smarter-than-me-on-the-way-to-33-c38e368e5cb8</a></p>
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Things learned from INSIGHT 2020</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>always have a point of view, no matter how much you know the content</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>ASK GREAT QUESTIONS - as a consultant, we contribute by pushing thinking, helping clients think differently</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Don't ramble</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>visual cues</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>interrupt with phrases (and practice) that acknowlege and build on</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>find an advocate "kat, did you have a comment?"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>frame sorry for thank you: thank you for your time, thank you for letting me interject (reframing)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

(your directive is to help startup succeed / grow in any way possible).... others: head of growth! </li></ol>
