<p>Learned:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>job / professional:</li><li>personal: *his reason for why: he wanted to work internationally after college!! answer his q: what's it like working outside of the US... learning: WHAT IS AFRICA like.</li><li>people in africa... have less but live their lives in a similar mental state (hope, optimism... w much less resources)</li><li>nigeria corruption (visibly corrupt - vs US - less visibly corrupt)</li><li>learned how to be more observant on his surroundings... he had a personal blog to observe / reflect... time for introspection + nice to share w others.</li><li>there's a certain <em>mindset </em>that helps.... overall, even sucky things... are valuable learnings... be up for anything!! !!! it's definitely not easy. he hadn't lived in other places, but travelled a bit. he was only there for 3 mo!!! not full 6 mo!! but he thought 3 mo was perfect amount of time... no AC, no easily drinkable water, extreme water.</li><li>connect w the person who runs the program: Taren - send email! - ask more q's on application process - logistical q's... </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Prep for possible call with Vanessa:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If I were to do this again:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Have the right team set up from the start (e.g., tester - manning the UAT smartsheet and more, trainer, someone manning the prod smartsheets, product manager - prioritize backlog and gather requirements, etc.)</li><li>Have the right team norms... incl pushback on timelines and identifying reasons why </li><li>Identify the right stakeholders and make sure they are / become the decision-makers for items in their arena</li><li>Maintain team cadences, set and communicate expectations... ex: weekly pushes? helps to communicate to all audiences all the changes we have made to prod.</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Default mindset of: how can I help? From my mouth, I'd end up saying specific propositions of how I can help. Helpful</li><li>Thought: I'm wondering: ?</li><li>Positive thinking / outlook on any situation</li><li>Being ok w failure in some ways</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Work on building something for 3-5 years</li><li>Build culture of LEARNING, incl "retros", feedback, and safety<ul><li>Correspondingly, build culture of being okay with failure and even expecting failure / experimentation... focusing on what works and trying a lot of things with prototyping.</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I think I'd like to try this twice. Perhaps 1x before kids, 1x after kids.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Include engineers as part of product discovery (and in my opinion, especially in some product user testing...) so they can really see the user pains... helps with prioritization / understanding instead of PM needing to relay everything and having some information lost in translation.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Per Nordstrom video: don't just work in a lab... nothing gets shipped... Work at the place users are... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>FOCUS ON A PROBLEM that people have great pain for. BE OK with lots of pivoting. Also learned from another convo: work in a market space that is huge.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Last bullet: revisit and revise this every X months.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Add value in meetings as a lower tenure colleague by:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Have your files ON HAND - can pull up asap</li><li>KNOW your numbers... know the key numbers inside and out... </li><li>Jump in to share this information when questions about your topic is asked</li><li>Also totally agree, when I was even lower tenured: to align with the project lead on the meeting flight formation... if there are a few slides that you can voice over!</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<p>Overview of what it is:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Next steps (using it for "good" / making myself the best version of myself.. and overcoming possible negative parts of it):</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Grateful:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Continuous reflection, quickly noticing when a new detrimental action (that does not serve me) happens reoccuringly and is on track to become a habit.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Hair loss</li><li>Brain fog.... this is annoying. examples: hard to pay attention</li><li>Recently, idk if this is Covid though: 1) feeling really cold, 2) FATIGUE - feeling really tired often, and overall perhaps not having as much energy as before - to jump around, do anything i wanted anytime, ... etc., 3) sore-ish throat, 4) sometimes (tho p rarely) my chest / breathing deeply isn't there..., 5) recently, feeling a wild hunger. part of being cold? where if I'm even a bit hungry, I don't feel good / comfortable... then overeating? or idk if I am, because I eat till my body feels good (not till when it doesn't)... I just know I've felt bigger - in my stomach, in my face, in my thighs... in my pants, and my weight has been highest it's ever been... 140lbs per the scale here!!</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If I were to do this again:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I'd be more sure of my boundaries, breathe deeply to understand what's important. Not work while I was sick. Not work long hours and on weekends immediately the weeks right after I felt a bit better. Not lying to my manager / teammates that I feel "totally better"... I thought I did, compared to how terrible I felt when I was sick. But I was not totally better. 3+ months later, I'm still not.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Would've still done:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

(impact! more impact :), limit burn-out), 2) spending $X... because time is also so valuable, so go all-in INCL on $ investments if I'm devoting my time to it!, 3) stop-criteria?</p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Incl my insight (maybe put this under the Finance post): news / podcasts / email news -&gt; are REACTIVE... about what's already happened... in analyzing trends, I should predict myself, write down and have corresponding steps (incl perhaps investing), and get some people's opinions, but DO NOT think that others are righter than me... listen to others' thoughts, but don't anchor on them - think critically for myself... because by the time it's picked up by news (ideally months later - from the pandemic exp :P), it's "too late" for the biggest gains. So diversify, get in, HOLD for X months through the tops and bottoms. HAVING a strategy helps make sure I buy more when things bottom, and sell maybe Y% after Z% rise</p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>other tactical tips: diminishing notifications</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Make friends with the messages from the "imposter" within you. As Adam Grant says in his new book "Think Again", imposterism is when your competence is greater than your confidence. And, it's actually a pretty useful catalyst for working harder, working smarter and increased learning. So, embrace it. Plus, "that which we resist, persists." Looking at your feelings of being an imposter, recognizing them, naming them, takes away some of their power. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>“the head is a lovely place to visit but we wouldn’t want to live there.”Instead of adding more knowledge, often what we need is remove stuff particularly barriers. Like blocking beliefs or the stories we tell ourselves about our worthiness.“We walk around in shoes far too small for us.” Carl Jung</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Dear readers, I am moving to Africa. Nairobi, Kenya in particular. I am beyond excited. Right now, I am scheduled to be in Kenya for 6 months. I haven't arrived to Kenya yet, but already I feel that I need more time there. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here are some of my goals before I go:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I wish I had checkboxes</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>from 10:30-11am, get some OAF work done</li><li>from 11:20-1pm, play some tennis with dad :)</li><li>from 1:30-2:30pm, figure out chase and money stuff for Kenya</li><li>from 2:30-3:10pm, get 2nd vaccine dose</li><li>onwards....</li><li>misc things to sort through:</li><li>*rydoo reimbursement of rxbars, *rydoo reimbursement of another meal....... (~$40 prob, caribean blue meal? or a grocery thing...), *rydoo reimbursement of internet bills! (once dad sends), *McK stuff to do -&gt; timesheet and </li><li>my right eye feels weaker, exercise and ask eye doc about that??</li><li>charlie - vet - talk to the technician!, follow up on it</li><li>ask my travel doc for altitude prescriptions? </li><li>also pay express scripts :P</li><li>TAXES - ask mom for help on this later today - thankful for mom &lt;3</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>What does work hard mean? What does it mean if I don’t feel like I’ve worked hard?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We do what we know. I do what I like to do. Putting in 15+ hours / day towards making progress in something I can be proud of, is just that… putting in time. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Then there are periods of my life that I put in less than 10 hours per day towards some goal (usually “work” related). I think I’m just as happy (surprisingly, not much happier) when I “work” less at my job tasks than if I’m putting in the 15+ hours / day (just weekdays though!). Both cases are assuming I’m working the same amount of “smart” or efficient. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>At my age, I’ve already defined what success looks like to me. I’m not sure if I’m less “ambitious” professionally than I was before, or if I’m just more patient. Acknowledging that the more surefire way to my goals requires putting in the time and acquiring experiences that are difficult to compress or overlap in required time. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Potentially being incredible in multiple things. But I don’t know or I doubt that doing more things would help me with my current things that give more impact. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I want us to create a life on our terms, not based on what's societally the norm, but based on what works and fulfills us to the core.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I want us to have an airtight plan, but also have a wide range of flexibility when inevitably, life deviates off course from it.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Honestly, the biggest thing is that I want us to design our own lives, not needing to abide by the societal norm lives that others before us have defined.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My OKRs from OAF / Kenya:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Professional: </li><li>Learn how to scale</li><li>Practice managing / leading others</li><li>Ideate - X ideas / week or so, research validity of Y of them in the same week</li><li>topic learning: *last mile delivery / logistics, loan repayments / financing, and marketing!!!</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Personal: </li><li>Learn more about the Africa entrepreneurial ecosystem - meet X people, have Y conversations</li><li>Build X lasting friendships :)</li><li>Adventure! - X adventures?, building Y stories, trying out Z new things</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Personal professional goals? - I want to see how much of the corporate training I can bring to non-profit world... see new needs (already - I see how tech dev would be helpful to have!), see how an effective non-profit operates - how they've been able to recruit great talent?, etc.</p>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Saying less filler words like "Um, etc"</p>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Do you remember, my flower dress and Birkenstocks. Tip-toeing to kiss you while balancing on the swing.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I remember thinking - I don't want him to kiss anyone else here. I wanted to be your first and last love brought to these swings.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Do you remember </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>***Fireworks</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>excited and exhausted...</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>fireworks in my heart</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Star-gazing from the boat! shooting stars! w dad &lt;3 </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Hahaha that time we took a nap? "overslept"? and your dad walked in on us, and we rushed to cover our naked bodies with the blanket we were on top of</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Bike rides... to the church upon a hill, sunset, biking to podcasts</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I remember -&gt; checking my meeting schedule for the next day -&gt; and when I had no morning meetings till 9/10am, then we would jump into the boat around 7/8am to get water skiing in!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Conclusion: Do you remember -&gt; transition to -&gt; a life successfully lived -&gt; memories tucked into my mind book </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Solidifying my life in some regards</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>1. I’m not the biggest fan of cities anymore. My childhood appeal seemed to be the beautiful ambitious people that littered these streets. A sense of being an “adult.” </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Now, living in a city is expensive! It’s hard to get to nature-y spots, and probably the biggest for me right now is that I don’t feel like I have a solid friend group in these US cities anymore… Less group event invites, etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>2. On Nairobi…………..</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are a few articles I’d like to write about on this topic. I’ll write one on the next draft post.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>3. And on where I’m going</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Perhaps a few places… For 2022, I’ll work for some work-life balance and use my spare time to read, write, spend time in nature and with good people (trying to optimize for kite surfing!!! few months doing this would be ideal, being able to work remotely while doing this for a few months, and then maybe taking a few days off as well to get better at this. Ideally I’ll be able to go upwind and downwind and do a few jumps by end of the year!!!). While I’m living closer to cities, I’d like to improve on horseback riding. Just spending a year to advance in hobbies that I enjoy. Low expectations :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Another wild thought to think about - that there is so much money out and about in this world. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Thoughts.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Wow! I have a whole world ahead of me! I’m 25. I can spend 1-2 more years learning and learning (I really don’t think I need a MBA and instead will maximize my learning from jobs that interest me, like CoS!). Then I can spend… honestly nearly the rest of my life! Building projects that I’m interested in, that could bring unfair potential upsides! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Damn on life. Money can accumulate. I’m around 200k this year…. Huh. I wonder if my equity is now 4x what I joined at, meaning I’d be at 120*4 = 480k / year and more in equity? I think that’s what it means right?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Maybe that’s something for me to look up more on… what stock options mean! Incl what happens if company valuation goes up. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Another thought: I feel like I’m in the best place possible. I’m at a cool role at a startup that’s in a “tidal wave” of the times. I’m paid just not enough to pour my life into my work. To be able to have a good amount of work life balance and coverage. Versus for example if Nishad wasn’t here! My job lets me accomplish the 3 goals I have, listed in the other private post.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ok time to write more about Thank You Kenya.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Thank you Kenya - you’ve shown me the femme I was looking for. The femme I was working towards finding first, to then become! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On this femme, it’s a sense of near complete self-assuredness. More certainty on what I myself like, want, and will go for. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’ve realized that I very highly value freedom above near all. I’ve learned what this means and how I can embody this. I know that I feel stuffy when I’m in cities too long. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Freedom, incl on movement. I am happiest when I’m pushing my body to new limits and doing things I find thrilling. Like kitesurfing, horseback riding, surfing. I am optimizing for some sort of self-fulfilling flow. I don’t get enough of this when I live in cities. I’m not close enough to the trees and beautiful clay ground called Earth. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On freedom, I value expression. I value a high quality of life while spending relatively minimally - another tenament of my freedom being financial freedom. Knowing that this money, when I put it in automatic investments, will pay great dividends in the future. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On companies, I feel more hyper aware that this world is just built and led by PEOPLE. And I continuously feel closer and closer to that sense of People.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Another thought on cities - there feels like too many people. I get lost on the seemingly unimaginable expanse of quantity. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>My gaze softens when Jordan’s near.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I like bodas because they also represent a sense of freedom. I can hop in one for less than $1 / ride, and get nearly anywhere with no traffic (they weave through traffic)!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I liked the beautiful clothes from Toi Market and artisanal made jewelry. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Weird to think no one has a say on how I </em>spend my whole days</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I loved the spaces I lived at, the spaces I worked at! The beautiful clean outdoorsy-ness. Green spaces. Just gorgeous interior design and minimal plastic. Relatively minimal disposableness and waste - where did we go so wrong on this here in the western world?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ok, beyond an overall reflection on Kenya, I want to dig into my mind for documentation on my last day there. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Kenya last day - digging into my memory</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I remember the night prior to my last day being pretty great, tho I’d have to check if it was a Friday or Saturday. It was a Friday. I left on Saturday night, I remember now because I was bummed about missing out on Sunday yoga at the arboretum.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ok so Saturday morning:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Woke up in my wonderful beautiful bed and room. Breakfast! Full circle, I’m remembering now. My first Kenyan friend came over a bit late (but it was okay, because I was doing something?). Mae and her bf also were over in the morning and bought supplies to cook CREPES! I made French toast :) We also had two kinds of tea - masala chai and Japanese rice tea. It was wonderful!! A bunch of my roomies came too. We had banana and Nutella crepes, and honey and lemon crepes, and the other kind Mae recommended was butter and something, but that one would’ve been a lot less healthy! So we didn’t do that. My Kenyan friend brought me a keys to success book :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Clue 1 that I didn’t see in the moment, when I asked one of my roomies who came by what he was doing later that day, he gave an answer that turned out not to be a full truth so I wouldn’t find out about a surprise! Also, I was like, I want to give you a hug in case I don’t see you again before I leave, and he was like don’t worry I’ll see you again. And I was like, ok so to confirm, you’ll have to be here then at THIS specific time (I was going to be back by around then to pack before going to the airport). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Then we were going to go to the Christmas market in Karen with a few friends, however we were running low on time… Mae told me lunch was at 130… I then also heard her calling them and asking about a reservation. For context, I was expecting about 4 of my roomies for a small lunch at hot pot, and didn’t think too much on this.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>So instead of going to the Christmas market, we went to my favorite place in Nairobi, the arboretum! Did a walk around, then took a ride to hotpot. At hotpot upon entrance, Mae asked again about the reservation. I was still confused. Then I saw a HUGE table with Zach sitting at the head of it!! Wow. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Just still feeling in awe of the love.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Of the joy, and happiness, of these incredible people who care and do so much for me, with no expectation of return.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Other thoughts to expand on next I’m more on my phone / computer:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The amazing 2 cakes my roomies ordered for me before I left! The amazing trip to the airport (incl the full moon and the fireworks and man Mae is the best!!!! Aw when she cried when we were leaving)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And Sam the driver who carried all my stuff… and getting into the express lane into the airport, and just having an incredibly swift journey on the way back.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Everything… just felt. Too perfect!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>v vivid</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<p>first: on optimizing for options - how i personally did it - and why i think it's ideal for people like me.... cuz like ex: marketing / cooking / whatever it is... being a SME - limits your freedom to change later on... leading maybe to some peoples' mid-career crisis? </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>2nd to write on... what was it!!!!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>can do non remote stuff at any time... the life feels capped at a local maxima, vs global: more global maxima!</li><li>examples, like locally - things to do would be like the specific restaurants / grocery stores / fitness classes / etc hobby offerings of that place.... </li><li>maybe another thought about the future of my generation: thinking about: the local / global maxima - how we can adjust and change things we previously couldn't as much, like where we raise our kids!!!! ....</li></ul>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>ex: jobs - how you perform in them?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>ex: job recruiting process - when you have some competing offers from companies who REALLY want you, vs the feeling of your worth when this doesn't happen... and how that affects oneself, but really, it's so external... a part of this is luck - based on the companies you are talking to / apply to... and based on macro stuff like which companies are hiring / luck if they really want you for your specific skill sets... etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>TBH I really like it here and am thankful to be here.</p>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Starting a series of posts reflecting on the mental models and quirks of a 25 y/o Kat </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>At an intimate and (replenishing?) GoodPeople (to tag them :P) team dinner in San Francisco last month, our (insert word for real?) speaker (insert name) challenged us to each answer the question: “What are you optimizing for?”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Upon a few moments of reflection, my answer became sure and stark in my mind: Freedom.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Paragraph about why? / overview</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Specific examples: (maybe some story telling?)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(Prob for myself ex, not for publishing necessarily:) I don’t want to have a dog until I have a kid. (I really want a dog, but I know that sometime in my life, I’ll have kids….</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Another point I want to get across: how I make decisions. “Allocatively efficient” , again to maximize opportunities and correspondingly, Freedom. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Examples in the past:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*Studying industrial engineering in undergrad - optimize for opportunities</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*same with consulting after undergrad </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*honestly same with my current role, CoS at Turing. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sometime in this post, mention why I’m obsessed with Freedom? (something about happiness?)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Story of feeling claustrophobic </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>physically - in Tanzania… </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Maybe another example too?… maybe when I was in UIUC? And needing to bike around</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Basically, convey how I learned each are impt, cuz when I don’t have them, then I don’t feel as great! So I calibrate my life and what I do accordingly then.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Why is Freedom important to me? Ultimately, it provides me with opportunities to live my life in a way that I want to, thereby being a somewhat direct correlation to personal satisfaction and happiness. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Why is each Freedom important to me? Fundamentally, each freedom allows me to learn and have fun - the two things that make me happy. Or something like how Freedom is directly tied to happiness for me? Freedom is the controllable input to happiness. Thus, why I’d rather optimize for something controllable than the output (less controllable) of happiness. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also maybe mention somewhere how optimizing for Freedom maximizes opportunities for me. OH maybe freedom is a combination of Opportunity and Choice. Choice / free will actually does make a difference and is part of what freedom means… to be able to have diff opportunities and the ability to choose which to pursue.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>What does Freedom mean to me?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>(Side thought: there’s another Asian person -guy- at this cafe! Who i think also speaks not fluent Spanish? I hope to talk to him and meet him!) update: darn he’s leaving and I wanted to be friends with him!!!!! I think it’d be cool to travel with someone else who’s kind of new. Perhaps me to just approach people next time!! Cuz he also would be wanting to visit and explore Bogota I’d think? + I like connection. Plus there’s some sort of comfort ness when the connection relates to you in some ways. Prob from N America, also Asian!</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The following dimensions of Freedom are most important to me:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Physical freedom (the health of my physical body, the ability to have a range of movement)</li><li>Financial freedom</li><li>Mental freedom </li><li>Professional freedom (incl skills….)</li><li>Time freedom</li><li>Born-with freedoms (non controllable but jotting it here for freedoms that I’m incredibly grateful for)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Maybe to write about, how these dimensions of freedom correlate? </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Physical freedom - this means ensuring my physical body is healthy, fit, and able to move. This freedom is important to me because it allows me to try new things, keep learning, achieve flow state with physical activities. For example, as opportunities come up, I can say yes and have fun with people: e.g., ski trips, hiking trips, most any sport! When I engage in movement (from acroyoga / aerial yoga / paddleboard yoga, to biking to kite surfing to rock climbing to playing tennis) I nourish my body and my mind. I can think clearer. I feel more at peace and fulfilled. (Maybe to add: tbh I need to continue this, these are continuous never ending habits / routine. That can always be improved, like my eyesight / posture etc. Also perhaps that these are active habits, because still relatively easy to revert on these.)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How I optimize physical freedom: prioritize and take care of my health! Prioritize getting good sleep - having a good bed / sleep environment, getting enough time in sleep. Prioritize physical care in terms of what I eat (I’ve learned what kinds of food, how much I eat, and when I eat could optimize my energy and thus my physical movement abilities). In what I drink (lots of water! :P). Skincare like SPF, moisturizer, etc. Dental care like flossing, brushing teeth / drinking water after eating acidic or too sweet stuff. Running / lifting / exercising with proper form to minimize injuries. Prioritizing getting at least around 30 min of exercise each day. Ideally a bit more in outdoors ways over the weekend. When I can, walk / bike / take stairs / move in the ways I get around. Staying healthy / avoiding getting sick through (in addition to the things I mentioned above) avoiding things that are or could be detrimental to me (e.g., limiting alcohol, substances, too much screen time when I can, not dressing for the weather, combining wet hair out of the shower with cold atmosphere or windy / drafty atmosphere - I’ve learned that somehow this combination takes a drastic blow to my immune system without fail… Perhaps mention that part of this is habits / identity? And like habits stacking over time to have a comprehensive lifestyle with these habits? With acquiring one or a few each time I build habits.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Financial freedom - this freedom enables me to pursue the things that I want to - without money being a barrier. this freedom was bought from a mixture of things. 1) choice of initial education / skills acquisition (I knew that engineering would allow me a baseline of skills to get myself a job where I would be paid enough), 2) learning of the world of what’s enough for me… tbh it’s really not a lot at all! I guess this first started with thinking more on what I want in life / what’s important to me in life. And then figuring out how much that costs. This mental understanding brought financial freedom with it! When I kept thinking about fundamentally, what do I want? What do I need? 3) making $ and keeping $ in the “bank”: on making money, I did try to work for a few years to save some $ to ensure that I could have enough $ to do the potential path I may want to take after that would take the most $ (starting a business). For keeping $: part of 2) is that I just spent my $ in a “smart”ish way - in accordance to what I need / what makes me happy. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Mental freedom: I think this is a pretty underrated freedom tbh. It’s a building block to happiness, and achieving sustained success in the other freedoms. Closely correlated to other freedoms like physical freedom. Emotional Stability, mental clarity, happiness / good people around me… With my family and BF and friends!! Maybe part of this is acting the way that I’d want others to treat me.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Professional freedoms: this also helps me optimize for opportunities, since my professional career is what I spend the majority of my time in my life on. This is also fairly tightly correlated with financial freedom. Professionally, I almost always want to be in careers where I can be learning… I feel like I’ve kind of gotten lucky that: I’ve never chosen or passed on a job so far because of how much it pays. Instead, I have a mentality that for each thing I do, tbh I would <em>pay</em> to do it, because I’m real life learning things that are interesting to me! Examples: fellowship at CentraleSupelec and Watson - mention what I was intentional in learning in both and the people I surrounded myself with in those communities. Consulting at McK (vs almost double starting salary in some tech roles). Non Profit OAF in Kenya. And now where I’m at in terms of CoS at Turing. (Again mention what I want to learn in each). Maybe even mention: maybe freedom in switching to IE vs ECE in college? Maybe / maybe not that relevant. Or maybe: one summer working on my startup. I was able to make each decision despite higher near term financial opportunities costs. Because I knew what I wanted, what makes me happy (e.g., what I’d learn and the people I’d surround myself, and the freedom it would offer me after - because of the two things listed…) (perhaps then mention it’s because I could think of these in terms of both immediate and longer term freedom optimization decisions; then these became a no brainer)… btw also in this section maybe mention what skills i acquire and why for optimization of opportunities? Incl like coding! Earlier on - since tech is so big, and wanting to stay in tech and being able to speak the same language as engineers / know how to work with engineers because I have some experience with it.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Time freedom: Maybe freedom to make choices? To make changes. TBH Idk about this one. Maybe like, for some people, they’re tied down for various reasons. Or like, how I make decisions with this in mind? We each as human beings have the same amount of time in this world. Once we commit to something, then that means we can’t use that limited amount of time for something else. Maybe my time freedom comes from my age? My macro environments? TBH I’ll prob scratch this one.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Born-with freedoms. I can’t neglect the large amount of freedoms that I’ve been so blessed to be born with. Freedoms that I can’t change, freedoms that I definitely should not take for granted. There freedoms are gifted from my parents. Or write something like: each freedom I’ve listed above stems directly from privileges in my life that I do not take for granted. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>My body - perhaps how as a family, we often joke “good genes” - tbh tho yes this a lot! Healthy body, without genes to gain weight easily? Being lean and tall !! Input to the optimizing of my physical freedom</li><li>Stability at home / with my family (input to optimizing of my emotional freedom)</li><li>Education - ties into my financial / education / professional opportunities</li><li>My passport - ties into my physical freedom? To be able to live in different places? But also somewhat financial freedom? Being able to easily travel to different places - also being able to afford really good lives at those other countries. </li><li>My parents’ habits / ways of living and how they brought us up: being financially literate, being growth minded, prioritizing our health! Being open minded, sense of wonder, etc. Also how they gave us all they know from the world and gave us the mentality to go and continue to explore more. (And my parents’ values they’ve instilled in us by living by example: hard work ethic, continuous learning, optimizing for opportunity, positivity outlook / gratitude, etc.)</li><li>Language skills / my culture skills - being Chinese, being able to speak Chinese - the rich culture I have from this that I can connect to X B (1.2?B) people in the world because of this.</li><li>Also macro trends in this world have given me many freedoms that I’ve taken advantage of / made the most of. Ex: lots of jobs available it feels like, the remote ecosystem after a year or so of getting to work in person first, women / minority / diversity have a lot more opportunities now than ever before… / etc. Plus I’m lucky to have gotten these trends at times of my life where I <em>can</em> take advantage of them!</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>the side to hide</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>are the multiple 3-letter acronyms to the right of her name</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>in signatures, in social platforms, in professional networks</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>--- </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>is the  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>chasing ambition , $ as a social status for achievement ? , </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>then back story -&gt; chip on shoulder? etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Each year, I feel myself getting closer to the person I've always wanted to become.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And beyond. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Power of visualization for instance.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For instance, in high school, I remember finding out / seeing people in the following - around college / right out of college age:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>these are mostly linked together :)</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><span style="color:initial;font-family:-apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, &quot;">on dress / body / fitness</span></li><li>on career</li><li>on boys</li><li>on lifestyle / finances ?</li><li>on friends ? </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Vignettes on visualization:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Chicago people -&gt; the people who were young professionals, the way they dressed like they had places to be</li><li>Georgetown -&gt; similar + the guy &amp; guy who were holding tennis racquets and i thought were v attractive</li><li>Sciences Po dual degree program videos -&gt; well dressed, intellectual, etc.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As a child, I wanted to be a writer. My favorite thing to do was read. I'm pushing further towards this in 2022. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In addition in HS, I also wanted to lead an impactful <em>international</em> organization. That's where I'm going to go in my 30s.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>and how to operate in a world where there is so much noise</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>thought to explore: in the crypto space.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>e.g., so many startup founders / ceos / etc., everyone in some tech incubator, everyone raised some sort of money, everyone having a white paper and a discord / telegram chat space</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>is the answer = no one knows?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>similar for when public financial markets go up and down dramatically.... lots of noise, not a lot of signal...</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>my main approach is to pull back and let things figure itself out and engage during periods of more stability</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>when is there "right" time to engage during period of "instability"?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>when something doesn't go right in life, be thankful. you're getting stronger AND it means you've had it really good prior .... so helps you think more about what you can be thankful for / more appreciative for.... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>life is easier this way.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>intro: maybe mention how recently, some friends with whom i've shared this blog have been inspired to blog too! so here are some tips from my lessons learned these last X years.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>don't go for perfection -&gt; there are incredible very public blogs out there-&gt; when you start, you won't get there</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(my personal exp: i wrote A LOT on mostly paper notebooks / some on evernote / diff online mediums, felt A LOT, grew A LOT my first years of college - one of most formulative times in my life in so many ways -&gt; I don't have any of this anymore. )</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>back then, i was super angsty? / SO much emotion -&gt; relationships especially, from an emotionally volatile, naive (first loves / etc), and feeling place, I wrote a lot of emotionally charged (i think beautiful pieces) -&gt; i also had SO MANY thoughts here that I didn't write about... why? I was too busy designing my perfect blog <em>format </em>-&gt; here, mention hosting, designing / ghost.io subscription, photos, all the stuff that I realized (too late) doesn't matter to start.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>then talk about my story with just doing it (first post) -&gt; and easiest thing -&gt; wordpress!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>just write. publish in private -&gt; helps to sustain yourself. more words about the "audience of 1"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>write about topics that you're interested in + i think it's easier to write about things you know! + things you naturally think about regularly</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*longevity / sustaining the habit = &gt; reaping the biggest benefits (from my experiences)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>also to make it more sustaining -&gt; make there to be positive feedback loops (for me, I feel happier / sense of accomplishment after writing something :P)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>also maybe on scheduling posts (+ not committing to need to publish each week / day etc when you're on a "steady state") -&gt; reasons why -&gt; again audience of 1 (at least for me, i'm really doing this for myself!!) something super selfish i can do.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>when to commit to writing everyday for a "sprint" -&gt; is for like a "reset" or habit making stage.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>it's fine to have private posts or drafts. write when you have inspiration, and then add some bullets on content for that piece. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>lesson learned from: way too many just titles of posts in my drafts; that looking back, I am genuinely interested / curious as to what I had to say and feel about those times, but just the title is not enough..... having just bullets is good enough for me to write out more later, or for me to </em>look at it and remember better :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>on writing, try to flush out pieces in the moment. good habit to build to. it's more meaningful to publish something than have 50+ unpublished drafts. (analogous to startups -&gt; so many - esp from personal exp - get caught in pre-launch ideating / perfecting / planning, but there's no real impact till a launch / getting things out in the real world) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>it's a lot harder to get into that mentality of specific inspiration later on.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>also ok to pivot ideas-&gt; again you're writing for yourself, and what you want to do. there are deeper topics i've been meaning to write for a while (e.g., perspectives of debt in emerging markets), but haven't yet, and it's ok! write what you feel like. don't make it feel like an obligation  like school work etc... then it's easier to procrastinate then</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>jot down things / plan out things? -&gt; for ideas?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>also structure helps for writing <strong>longer</strong> pieces?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>on peer editing -&gt; personally i don't do much of this (cuz private blog :P), and also I feel like - it makes your friends "have to" read all the pieces you ask for edit (vs when you "private publish" - and people come on your site, they can read just the ones that they are genuinely interested in)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On editing -&gt; separate time for editing than creation process . read what you write after you write it -&gt; either a few minutes after to a few days? &lt;- tbh i'm not the best at editing so not sure if these are best tips tbh</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>also on bulleting structure in drafts -&gt; this is helpful for me to think more on posts content throughout the days that my post is in draft, and i can easily go back and edit / add in:) - instead of writing / brainstorming part <em>needing</em> to be all in 1 sitting</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>maybe conclusion: end w benefits i've felt from these years of "blogging"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>e.g., benefits: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>supplement my memory -&gt; i like going back and those references bring me back to a more "Exact" time i felt something / learned something - cool tracking</li><li>fundamentally: i hope it accelerates my learning! documentation of things learned from all sources (e.g., podcasts, work / on the job, interesting conversations, observations, books, and more) into one place </li><li>i like sitting down and reflecting -&gt; makes me feel like i'm creating something fundamentally of my own.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>maybe tbh take a screenshot of these bullets / thoughts to show my initial writing stages and how i flush things out later</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here are some of my favorite questions that interviewees ask me:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>...</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>how to best define it and make sure that </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>ex-consultants.. exec -&gt; needlemoving stuff...</li><li>planning / ingest</li><li>roles / responsibilities ... examples</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>things learned from McK -&gt; that when I don't have as much subject matter expertise compared to people who've built their careers on the subject (function or industry for example), here are ways that I can still add value, gain trust and positive views from execs / experts / longer tenured people:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>....</li><li>Spending more time ... </li><li><span style="color:initial;font-family:-apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, &quot;">Speaking eloquently when I do talk. </span></li><li>share screen / present docs easily -&gt; know that stuff inside and out!</li><li>being funny / breaking the ice? </li><li>^maybe part of that, listening well! so that you can bring in the details too there in referencing things -&gt; makes you more likeable</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>i haven't had one since i could ever remember.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>why: live each moment that i'd be happy if i died tomorrow or 10 years out or 50 years out... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>how: 2 things: 1) live each day TRUE to yourself -&gt; deep dive into this / how</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>2) tell the world you love the world each day. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>tho i don't have a bucket list, i have an "experience" list = desires of experiences i'd like to have if the timing is right (and assuming i'm alive then)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>first on the list: to be a mom! :) *this one is super packed... because there's a lot about the "kind" of mom i want to be... to really lead by example -&gt; thus have led and lead interesting / impactful lives / hobbies / friends / etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>others: would love to visit japan and south korea one day... (but for travel: i don't really like traveling for tourism, so i'd have to have some purpose!) - both were close - IKON in s korea (but conflict w nationals rowing tournament), FLITE training in Japan but covid!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>maybe an example on my perspective is: Mt Kili... never thought of doing it till i knew i was moving to africa... then i was like, well since i'm already there, gotta do it :P. Vs v unlikely for me to go to Africa just to do it.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>tbh that's legitamately all the things i can think of (i paused for a solid 6.5 minutes sitting at my screen racking my brain on this)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>McK people are super cognizant of people dynamics. in work place. with execs. etc. Once you realize for example that your goal is for someone to have more ownership of something that may not be good for them -&gt; realizing that they need more time and more buy-in and stuff.... navigating people = soft skill that's amazing seeing partners / etc at mck navigate through</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>kind of like chess in some ways!</p>

<p>Ok here's the structure of this post:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Hook: "I entered a room of 22 completely new faces; 4 hours later, I knew their stories better than friends I've had in my life for years."</li><li>Context: I visited Medellin on 3/12 to attend ______</li><li>Here's what I learned: _____</li><li>Conclusion, something like shoutout to Stefano, Ines, EpicLlama, etc for hosting this!<em> </em></li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On part 3 - things learned:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>On Golden Rule: I realized that in my romantic relationship, I am often giving unsolicited advice....</li><li>I learned more about myself. The questions were thought provoking - many where I had to reflect on new experiences in my life that I hadn't prior. + I don't think of myself as a natural storyteller. But as questions came up, I thought, and told stories that surprised myself. </li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I feel like each story I told could've been a blog post... About dreams that I've given up (Sciences Po etc.) story. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>About the quote.... I'll take a photo of it! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>and Finally: <em>each person is shaped by a series of interesting / ___ stories. And those stories form thoughts that are very relatable... </em>Our discussions covered commonalities related to societal pressure v staying truthful to ourselves (from country-moves to marriage / engagement to ____). We struggled with similar feelings of guilt related to being well-off in a country where __(less well-off)__.   We've gone through periods where we felt unworthy of love... and __(something about getting through it?)__. Or something about: completely stuck... and gotten through it with love of someone else, or an external factor like the right art work hitting us at the right time. Other examples: we explored our beliefs in the supernatural (witches are real in certain indigenous tribes and were portrayed as evil / green / creepy because of the Christian religion's ____). We swapped book and show recommendations ...</li><li> </li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Part of part 4:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>By the end of the night, I felt a deep closeness to many of the people  I saw around the room. Their stories were intensely human. I saw how their adversities and corresponding victories shaped who they were today. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(vs prior / 20th century? this arbitrage was more for physical things - like manufacturing etc.)</p>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>i also feel like, there are so many small things to do on a daily basis - that i'm behind on. that's not a great feeling</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>plus, i don't really have a routine with same hours each time... yet</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Basically, one person gives by talking. But the receiver receives what they want to. And then takes it and interprets what they want from it. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>pushing / standing for something</li><li>when standing for something -&gt; have valid "becauses" to justify it</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>my why:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>..</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>how this shows up, in order of earliest to most recent:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>a week prior to turning 25, i summited Mt Kilimanjaro in tanzania</li><li>got scuba certified in kenya</li><li>spent a few months living in LATAM, kitesurfing every other weekend (it's been about a month since then, and i've been really itching to get back on the water!!!!)</li><li><span style="color:initial;font-family:-apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, &quot;">went on a psychedelic trip</span></li><li>got a tattoo</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>here are other tentative but likely plans for the remaining 1/2 of year 25 (and likely some leakage to start of year 26) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>go to burning man</li><li>i'm absolutely itching to do another kitesurfing trip - maybe scheduling that and taking a week off to just kitesurf. another potential option is to buy my own gear - incl need wet suit and such - and somehow go with my new SF friend who kites in Foster City. maybe just maybe i can find a way to store my board in his apartment, bike there and back every sunday with my kite on my back and wet suit / gear. tbh i would enjoy this miles more than almost any other sport! </li><li><span style="color:initial;font-family:-apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, &quot;"></span></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>professional</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>one acre fund exp -&gt; designed, built, scaled last mile logistics for farmers in kenya. got in the ground - incl field work. as matthew daiter says: i made a big step in the building of my backbone.</li><li>left mck, to a remote startup with a killer team, lots of new learnings (e.g., metrics! + scaling + managing exec team + so much more), such a cool role.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>relationships</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>a year ago - this is what spurred this overall post actually - a friend remembered i was getting upset at jordan for going to a packed club during covid. my relationship with jordan has since improved it feels so drastically from one year ago.</li><li>friendships -&gt; really deepened my friendships -&gt; throughout the world. solid close friends, who develop and become closer even. me, building a discipline to call more, to set up calls more. make friendships meaningful and extend beyond the intense months of living and knowing them. + being secure in them</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>personal</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>honestly i'm so proud of myself for having gotten a tattoo - everything about it - from where it is, to what it is, to what it means to me, to where i got it and the experience of getting it - all i'm deeply happy for</li><li>kite surfing &lt;3 gotten basically independent at it! kited in all these beautiful spectacular places around the world (aka kenya and colombia)</li><li>having gone to africa -&gt; absolute dream come true</li><li>summited mt kilimanjaro </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>founder -&gt; invest and advise a few companies -&gt; make remote work more effective... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>my professional world hacks -&gt; the notebook :) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>recently, i haven't felt terribly happy. when i experience the loss of something, i then better understand what's important to me.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>so, here are things that i believe make me happy - in reflection of my last few years:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>community</li><li>easy access to the brilliant outdoors</li><li><span style="color:initial;font-family:-apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, &quot;">good food</span></li><li>energy and mental space to be creative and build things that matter to me</li><li>some sort of steady state consistency to better optimize my schedule</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>i think i've felt a similar claustrophobic feeling to before</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>it's hard. here's what has worked for me</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>i think / hope this could be helpful - as people become more nomadic and travel and visit new places!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>building furniture together</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’ve been living from a carry-on suitcase for a while now. I feel like I’ve incrementally created efficiencies through my life that  when disrupted, mean headaches (?) maybe I’m too use to a lot of efficiency! Like… I only have the 1 blue jacket (perfect! for X Y Z…) the 1 black blouse for… + also more special because thrift shopped!, the blue swim suit top I’m more ok with losing - my mom gave me another swim suit so I have 2 of those. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But also! Gotta budget for disruptions. Plus each disruption is a lesson learned. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This lesson is to not bring my clothes to the washer people especially when combined in a huge load of other stuff (SO clothing, bed covers, etc). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also lesson recently learned: encourage the process even when outcomes are negative. Step 1: separate the process and outcome. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As a friend and I were preparing to leave Nairobi, Kenya, we were lamenting how there's a certain magic about the East African city that we wished we could capture and transplant to every place we go afterwards. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And maybe there is a way to do this.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How I break down and distill the essence of Nairobi:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li><strong>People -&gt; social calendar -&gt; ... adventure (maybe: newness, exploration?)</strong></li><li><strong>Freedom of expression, of chasing your dreams... being yourself and defining your life in a new context / new view of life. + continual growth -&gt; limiting stagnation in part... because this world is so big!! there is so much to learn while still progressing on things that matter to you.</strong></li><li><strong>Impact -&gt; the kind of work to do</strong></li><li><strong>Beauty -&gt; nature</strong></li><li><strong>Reflection -&gt; </strong></li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Note: this list is not mutually exclusive; in fact, I think each bullet is tightly intertwined with the others.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Overall theme? -&gt; something about being able to be yourself... Courage to do that... etc. My list above are the things that represent that for myself; thus this list may be different to each individual -&gt; for what is important to them! </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Other:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><em><strong>Scent</strong></em>: The friend got me a Nairobi candle before I left! It's gorgeous and my favorite candle. When I burn it or think of it, I have a fondness to the essence of the city. I also recently bought a new perfume called <a href="https://www.byredo.com/us_en/bal-dafrique-eau-de-parfum-50ml">Bal D'Afrique</a> that's my favorite as well. I fall in love with the scent whenever I spray it on. The story behind the perfume is supposed to be the maker's love letter to Africa.</li><li><em><strong>Sound</strong></em>: I made a <a href="https://open.spotify.com/playlist/5G0I1vcpWixdriJcfEg6bp?si=7c1605227c464812">Nairobi playlist</a> with songs I listened to and really resonated with while living there. Also music from the place's culture like afro-beats - though not in this specific playlist - pull me back directly to specific night outs, beach side parties, dance classes.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Although I hadn't taken the time to sit and really think about what made Nairobi special to me prior to now, I think I've subconsciously both brought and naturally gravitated towards elements with a touch of Nairobi to the places I've gone afterwards (Colombia, California).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>On People - connection? , friendships and activities(?): </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In Nairobi -&gt; tight group of expats; in Colombia -&gt; tight group of people from a certain background (e.g., having been international). Because of these shared similarities, it was easy to create tight relationships with ... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There is merit in having more diverse friends as well; and I acknowledge that I didn't do this well during my time in both countries. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>In San Francisco: people - activities - being more conscious / making more effort to make plans... , new idea: shared social calendar...</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>On Freedom of Expression:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Expression, exploration, and connection with intentional unpretentious communities:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In Nairobi, I was part of the WonderHouse community - where a group of incredible people came together to sponsor a beautiful house just for creation and connection. No one lives there except sometimes artists in residence. There are ....</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In Colombia, I was immediately attracted to ... Curiousity House -&gt; becoming the first person to move-in and live there! ... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In San Francisco, I've found ... my favorite place: the Center SF. I'm also learning about new pockets with the same vibration - such as the third space, etc... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Expressing a personal value of Adventure:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Reflecting on my childhood, I realized my younger self embodied a sense of adventure when I begged to go on the most adrenaline-filled rollercoasters (that my guy friends and parents were weary to go on), when I made pillow and bedsheet forts in basement sleepovers, when I fought dragons and we were knights on secret missions in my friend's forest backyard. However, I hit pause on adventure for most of my middle to high school years.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In Kenya, I tapped back into this sense of adventure when I took a boda boda (motorbike!) to and from most places to avoid Nairobi traffic or because it was one of the only ways to get around unpaved roads in the rural areas. I felt this sense of freedom and awe when I felt the wind in my hair as I cantered through Karura forest on my favorite horse I took riding lessons with. When I felt the wind in my hair as I finally got up on the board while learning how to kitesurf. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In Colombia, I continued my kitesurfing adventures which led me to three different coastal spots with good wind. I galloped on my horse through Tayrona National Park. And I got a tattoo of a flying kite to cement this feeling of freedom in my body. A permanent mark on a temporary body. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In San Fransisco, I felt a sense of frustration at first due to much harder it was to access activities that induced a visceral feeling of being alive. Financial considerations being one of them - for example, I know there are horseback riding stables in South Bay, but I don't want to spend $100+ each time I go just on the transportation (Uber / car rental). My adventure-filling activity for the time being is biking with the bike-share Lyft bikes around the city. I love how many bike lanes there are here. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Adventure - something I do for myself for my own satisfaction.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>On Impact:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In Kenya, all around gave me the courage to dream big and create. The ongoing construction projects for roads and bridges where I saw the exposed materials and beams. The nearby <em>kibanda</em> selling fresh chapatis run by mothers. The ramen restaurant next door that was gorgeously decorated and interweaved with the surrounding nature. The living spaces of my friends and my home that were spacious and decorated with plants, swings, sunlight. My second-hand clothing that singed with colors and felt right to me, bought from the bustling Toi Market. The list goes on. Things, spaces, pursuits around me were close to its source of creation. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In Colombia, there are many similar traits to Kenya, likely because it's also a developing country and perhaps because I lived in Bogota where the elevation and proximity to the equator presented geographic similarities to Nairobi. Similar to Kenya, I gravitated towards spending time with people who were building things that seemed to carry tangible impact, from city policy and infrastructure like the Bogota Metro to tech products that provided access to financial services for the large middle class.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In San Francisco, to be transparent, I haven't found this close fit yet. Meetups are centered around Web3's pursuits to create NFTs and financial value for crypto holders, conversations are about how virtual tokens can be created and transferred or the recent Twitter post from a prominent tech thought leader. However, I've found a few individuals who I now call friends that resonate with me in how we think about impact. I'm determined to attend an Effective Altruism meetup in the coming weeks. I have a directed plan to reach out to SF people who are in the more tangible impact space.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <strong>On Beauty:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Seeing the sunrise on top of Mt. Kilimanjaro* is one of the most beautiful views I've ever seen. Similar feeling of beauty in Kenya were weekend trips to the mountains for hikes, to the coast for brilliant sunrises, to the safaris where majestic animals roamed free. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In Colombia, I'd take advantage of hikes before work. Day trips to mountains and dense forests just an hour or so away from where I lived. The proximity of those places reminded me of what Earth was like in most every city we now occupy. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In San Francisco, my first weekends were intentionally planned around this deep sense of beauty of the Earth. We had a friend gathering on the beaches and sweeping hiking trails of Fort Cronkhite. We took a weekend trip to see looming and sage Redwood trees in Humboldt State Park. During weekday work breaks, I biked to parks to breathe in trees and a feeling of peace outside of the congested city. Wherever I live, I need <em>this</em>. The mountains, the trees, the streams and crashing waters. My bare feet contacting our ancestral home. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>On Reflection:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It's easy to stagnate in life after college without a structured learning plan. It's easy to get caught up with the archetype of success that our childhood adult figures touted. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>From Nairobi started a journey of self-reflection on what I want in my life. In Colombia, I continued that reflection as I embarked on a habit to write more. In San Francisco, I'm creating space to write and think. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Living happily in the present while happily dabbling in nostalgia,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Kat</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*in Tanzania, Kenya's neighboring country</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I move around a bunch. I'd say it started when I was growing up in Canada. I attended 3 different elementary schools and 2 different middle schools. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Each time I move, there's always one thing that stays constant: the exercise to make new friends. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Reflecting back on primary school, friends seemed to be made fast. There was often another kid who wanted another friend (that became me!) or were curious about the new student (which then led to invites for events like movie nights, hang outs, etc.) or I would join student organizations like clubs or sports teams - and again, voila! fast friends.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How did it get so much more difficult as adults? In the real world, there are less immediate shared commonalities (grade / age, obligatory classes, location, etc) and more differences.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here are tips that have worked well for me making friends as an adult:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*= similar stories to my childhood (e.g., molly!)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Starting with just say 1 good friend -&gt; from commonalities in the past (college, childhood, intros from other friends) and do go and reach out! -&gt; getting plugged into more of their friends too :)</li><li>Joining clubs or classes in the area -&gt; in your interests</li><li>Finding events to go to, based on your interests -&gt; FB events is a great source</li><li>Saying yes to events / invites -&gt; keep showing up -&gt; when you see people more often, you strengthen that bond and have more shared experiences :)</li><li>Organizing events yourself!</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Systems / charts I want to add on friendships (see notebook :))</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>1) friendships -&gt; when and why to invest in them (when they become an engine -&gt; more opportunities etc)... maybe part of my structured / framework thinking book! <br>2) evolution of friendships? -&gt; how someone goes from an acquaintance to a good/ close friend? -&gt; and maybe also some structure / guidelines / framework on what each "type" of friends looks like<br>3) maybe? something about how to break down what makes someone a good friend for myself? and/or maybe if i were to break down criteria of when to keep vs drop a friend? tbh maybe this is too systemized and thereby not that helpful! vs what feels more normal?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>+ mention / PS: there's also a lot of merit in maintaining and <em><strong>deepening</strong></em> friendships that are no longer in the same location... why: __maybe to add__</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>how to do this:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>recurring call invites</li><li>organizing a trip / making plans in the future to adventure together :)</li><li>advancing on projects together :) </li><li>naturally sharing docs / links / interests / etc. that you come across that make you think of them!</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>the vibe!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>so much more than many other places in SF</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I'm not afraid of you. Your __gnarly roots / upwarded trunks / etc... ? some darker descriptions__<br>Seems like all the startup CEOs and probably big company CEOs and all the big shot investors, they talk about you, they prep for you, all for good rationale.<br>But as you turn your horned beak, as you may scare ___description of people___, including past self.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But the sun still shines.<br>The neighborhood sandwich shop will still make my turkey with everything but no cheese on dutch crunch sandwich as they've made it for customers before me through recessions or no recessions.<br>My partner will still love me. I'll still love him.<br>And ______insert another wholesome fact :)______.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Some of this, I speak of privilege. <br>In addition to the above basic small things that I love and make me happy, <br>I am not in massive debt / leverage.<br>I have skills and a network, my reputation (integrity etc?) &lt;- to be reworded prob... that I can bounce back from potential temporary financial ruin (either this upcoming recession or a future event)... incl in times of downturn = more opportunities I can also take more advantage of!<br>I still hold a passport from the United States of America where we don't .... (land of ... ) have excessive corruption / etc.... war torn / etc...<br>I still have freedom to live in another lower cost of living countries if need be.<br>....</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I'd like to think, that a lot of my friends / peers are in similar situations to me. Writing this as a reminder, the sun will still shine.<br><br></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We did that too as kids. We woke up at 2am, rented warm wool clothes - cuz it was too hot to carry them all the way up, to summit a mountain and watch the sunrise. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It ended up being cloudy that day, so We didn’t see it. Dad pauses and then laughs. That’s life. (In English) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Later they climbed a bit higher and saw the sun rise over the clouds. Not the same as the horizon but still definitely something  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>basically about.. this new relationship thing i learned from the book i read... and is a thing i want to work on in my relationship :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>when you're beautiful, everyone looks at you. you need to actively not </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>when you're </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
