<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>structure: cool new experiences specific to a place</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>two types of these experiences: i) more permanent (e.g., hiking spots, tourist mainstays, etc.), and ii) more temporary (mostly local events! these are often more fulfilling for me personally - to get to meet the people that live there)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For San Francisco:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>... bunch of saved places in my google maps.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>jotting down the why here for easy reference</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>learn ? - greater enriched life - awesome more ideas - in a really really easy and passive way</li><li>support network / power of community &lt;3 &lt;3 &lt;3 &lt;3 &lt;3 &lt;3 </li><li>share? don't need one of everything (e.g., lawn mower, all the baking supplies, community garden, etc. etc.)</li><li></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>i've noticed, that as i've been growing older, it's easy for me to forget the above. and i don't think i want to forget the above!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>imagine, forgoing all those benefits. if we were just in our nuclear boxes - mom, dad, kids - then i think that's quite limiting from the potential we have. forgoing the wisdom, knowledge, experience, fun from the diversity of people you're living closely with. the ___ ethnic recipes cooked by the __insert example of specific aunt XX?__. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>from parents with X careers... inspire kids!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>learn what's advantageous and what's not advantageous (when you hang out more with other families' you see things you can incorporate yourself for example!) - to incorporate into your own lives.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>for parents, they have the social benefits as well! 1) continual learning too, 2) friends / community feeling - that a lot of parents start having less when they have kids, 3) mutually giving support network ... going on cabin trip - someone else you've known for a while with "skin in the game" in the community to look over your kids and have your kids hang out with their kids... or vice versa! kids are easier to raise in communities... we lost this somewhere in US's strive for independence </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>also, recently, i feel like i've found similar awesome pockets of individuals from the bay area and boulder area that are looking for the coliving and community in the way they raise their future kids as well. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>perhaps the easiest way to do this in the future (without too much overhead on administration / etc which leads to less sustainable projects) is to just design for this in living spaces. meaning, having private spaces for families to live - but in close proximity to the other families and with shared common areas naturally leading to increased interactions. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>there are a few other thoughts i have on how / why this is harder in practice, and ideas on remedying them. perhaps something to think more on later in life.? e.g., maybe starting with people you know / referrals.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>if you're interested in this in the future somewhere in the US, let me know!! message me on fb @kat q hu.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>context: i've recently read the seven principles for making marriage work by john gottman. it was recommended on a blog post by self help guy Mark Manson.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>background - my personal philosophy on learning, vSelf-Development: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>i approach knowledge gathering in two buckets: 1)  just in time knowledge (knowing something exists so you can reference to it later), 2) incorporated knowledge (actively incorporating the information into my own life)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>the second approach is my active learning. for self-development, i can't put all the new knowledge i come across into the second bucket, because when i have tried to incorporate everything i learn at once, i feel overwhelmed, i don't create sustainable habits, and then i don't reap the effects i hoped for.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>instead, when i start with just a prioritized select few pieces to incorporate in my life, i create enduring habits that become minimal energy to maintain which give me space to add more habits later on.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>aside, could be a fun graph to plot positive habits accumulation (step graph) over time, juxtaposed with another graph of energy spent on habit building (more sinusoidal). it'd be fun to add nuances like habit-stacking -&gt; where sometimes more habits are accumulated but the energy spent is not directly correlated to increase in habits. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>also because of the above, i find benefits in re-reading books, re-listening to podcasts, re-watching recorded lectures. each time i do it again - often years later - i pick up and incorporate new pieces of knowledge.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>here are the few habits i'd like to work on for the next few months, from the seven principles book:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li><strong>one</strong>: listen better -&gt; interrupt less <ol><li>I noticed and we've discussed that I often interrupt J's stories because I get so excited about them! I often have a lot of questions and thoughts. </li><li>On the phone, to listen fully to what Jordan has to say before I interject, I've been trying out muting myself when he's talking to add another layer of friction. </li><li>In real life, when I'm playful, I often raise my hand and wait to be called on :). If Jordan is done, he'll acknowledge me playfully. If he wants to finish a story, he'll let me know :). </li><li><strong>The situation I'm working on is when we're arguing</strong>. When I'm more heated, I interject a lot. As soon as J says something that I don't think is correct, I often interject before he finishes everything he wants to say. He listens well when we're fighting, and I want to work on building the same respect. I'll try working on this by thinking about my goal here when we're arguing! </li></ol></li><li><strong>two</strong>: fight slow to fight fast<ol><li>my goal in arguments is to get something i want - often a change in how jordan acts. in order to get to the final goal, the easy in-the-moment action for me is to express and act exactly how i feel emotionally. however, this path is suboptimal because it leads to greater hurt between us (requiring longer term healing) and our fights often are longer till we get to a solution. the harder in-the-moment action for me is to employ various tactics that require me to command greater control of my emotions. below are a few of those tactics:</li><li><strong>employ soft startups</strong>: make sure partner feels known / respected - not criticized / attacked. think about a strategy to get to my goal before just launching into my current pattern of what feels easiest.<ol><li>e.g., from book: "There’s a big difference between “Sheesh, you’re a lousy driver! Slow down before you kill us!” and “I know you enjoy driving fast, but I get really nervous. Could you please slow down?” Maybe that second approach takes a bit longer. But that extra time is worth it since it is the only method that works!"</li><li>“If you’re angry with your spouse, it’s worth taking a deep breath and thinking through how to broach the subject. Softening your start-up will be easier if you constantly remind yourself that it is the optimum strategy for resolving the conflict. If you feel too angry to discuss the matter gently, your best option is not to discuss it at all until you’ve calmed down. Follow the steps for self-soothing before talking it out with your spouse.”</li><li>personal example i'm going to work on in my relationship: for context, at group gatherings, J often doesn't interact with me much. i've learned from him that this is because he feels pressure to make sure the group is ok first. sometimes when i'm tired / lower emotional stability, i feel hurt by this. i'm used to so much attention and affection when we're by ourselves that going from 100 to 5 makes me feel less loved in group moments. to improve this situation, i'm going to practice communicating the following prior to parties or group events i attend with J: <em>“please spend time with just me today at this party. You’re really good at 1:1 settings, but I really like specifically your attention in group settings too.”</em></li></ol></li><li><strong>ask questions</strong>, approach the situation to seek understanding from his perspective, then <strong>over-communicate to show that i understand</strong> him before pushing my point. example: i can playback what i thought i heard / my understanding and ask if he thinks it's accurate. often in our arguments, i've noticed that i often push my points as a response to the assumption that i correctly heard him / understood what he said. however, he doesn't always <em>feel</em> that i listened to him (even if i think i did), which makes him less receptive to what i have to say after. </li><li>Tactics are easier to do when you really believe in the why and are more optimizing for end outcome than necessarily "being right" - fighting smarter not harder :). So note to self to remember my end goal: to win the long game not the short one.</li></ol></li><li><strong>three</strong>: respond affirmatively to repair attempts <ol><li>repair attempt definition per book: “... refers to any statement or action—silly or otherwise—that prevents negativity from escalating out of control. Repair attempts are a secret weapon of emotionally intelligent couples”</li><li>benefits of repair attempts per the book: “you frequently have the experience of being calmed by your spouse, you come to associate him or her with feelings of relaxation rather than of stress. This automatically increases the positivity in your relationship.”</li><li>after reading this, i realized that both jordan and i employ these so-called "repair attempts" when we argue! however, either him or i don't always respond positively to the repair attempts. i can't control him responding positively to my repair attempts (though i suggested him to read this book, which perhaps if / after he does, i can be more explicit in the future to him to let him know that i'm trying to use a repair attempt). but i can control my own responding to his repair attempts. <strong>my goal is to respond affirmatively more often and quicker to his repair attempts.</strong> it'll make the repair attempts actually successful, and ideally we'll reap more of the benefits as mentioned above (less heated arguments, greater feeling of trust in each other). for him, he'll also associate more clearly that his repair attempts work, which go in the habit building cycle as a "reward", which ideally leads to more repair attempts in our relationships and less fights.</li></ol></li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>BTW, a past tactic i've worked on and now incorporated, that i think is fairly effective in decreasing magnitude and frequency of fights, is: <strong>practicing self-soothing</strong> to decrease situations of "flooding."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>what is "flooding":</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>for a while, i didn't have a word to describe this feeling. i just observed that there was an inflection point (another word i didn't previously realize i could use outside of math class) in my arguments with J (and with family members) where once passed, i'd get so heated that it'd be really hard / seemingly impossible to control myself and calmly resolve fights. that's the "flooding" or "fight or flight" state. </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>how do i practice self-soothing?:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>in self-soothing, timing to employ this is key (if too late, then it's a lot harder for these techniques to be effective). thus, i start with noticing my body! when i'm more in tune with my body, i notice signs like shallower breathing, my mental state changing and feeling more heated, my tone of voice more curt.</li><li>focus my mind to think about towards the lower half of my body</li><li>breathe deeply</li><li>hug J if i can and not talk for a bit</li><li>go for a walk and listen to music</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^got those tips from various sources (e.g., books, therapists, first principles / trial and error, etc.)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>ending sidenote: i've been playing around with typing without capitalization. feels more casual. takes less time? not sure if this is a habit i want to keep or not yet! (it's been trickling over to my work communication too...) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>another sidenote: i think there's a lot of merit in editing docs after i write them, to help with readers' experiences. this article is really for my own documentation, but perhaps one day later i'll come back and edit this if i think it could be helpful for others!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>below are some basic do's. don'ts = don't not do the do's.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>do's:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>ask interesting questions. some of my favorite: <ul><li>words...</li></ul></li><li>know the interview format. interviewers anchor and judge on what they know... no need to re-invent the wheel <ul><li>star method for example...</li><li>tactical stuff on case interviews for example...</li></ul></li><li>figure out what the interviewer is looking for and give it. <ul><li>the way i approach interviewing as an interviewer: i need to fill a role, i go into each interview hoping and vouching for the candidate to pass / do well... they do that by ticking boxes i'm looking for and ideally showing some sort of "spike" - AND - not having any immediate red flags that make me discount them</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>aside: quick thoughts on more senior interviewing below! i've done less of these, but here are preliminary observations on what works well</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>the way the speak - executive presence comes through<ul><li>pauses / clear voice / confidence</li></ul><ul><li>influenced by their content too - they know their stuff! through years of experience and having done practice in interviewing</li></ul></li><li>their content:<ul><li>smart. they answer your questions. they're direct. they share results.</li><li>they have <em>interesting</em> content with seriously cool impact.</li></ul></li><li>they way they connect to you:<ul><li>charm! you feel energetic and happy and excited to talk to them. they remember details... they genuinely care. </li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>people that stand out have a "je ne sais quoi - yet" element that i want to distill in the future. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>potential future deep dive blog posts ideas from this one:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>tactical case interviewing tips (things that are really easy and small and once you know, can really help you - but just a lot of people don't know)</li><li>setting up a recruiting pipeline, as a startup </li><li>closing the deal - getting them to say yes, as a startup (e.g., drip campaign)</li><li> </li></ul>

<p>rock climbing gym example</p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Being scared to give trust:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The child sees this, feels it’s too limiting, and revolts. Or the child sees this and tries to live within the confines of the trust limitations, is bound to make mistakes, and feels unsupported during those times. Trust breaks. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But to be brave, to give trust early:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You’re telling her that she is an intelligent capable person. You tell her what you know, including the risks. And ultimately it is her job to make the decisions and own the consequences. Trust builds. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ways to get luckier:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Maybe in sum, as a young’un (someone in your 20s) for your career: add a lot of value to someone who is 10x where you are (in direction of where you want to be). </p>

<p>i recently read a book called "people we meet on vacation" where the main guy character reminds me of the main guy character in my life</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>recently, i've reflected on this topic with the following actions, that show a sort of beyond thoughtfulness in his actions:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>we both got tested before having sex without condoms (after i got on an IUD), his suggestion</li><li>when he looks up online about other kind of sex - and my health implications</li><li>when he orders me a chai oat milk latte - exactly what i would've wanted - at a coffee shop that he rushes to help me get here on time for </li><li>darn i had a lot of other ideas to put into this bucket but i currently don't remember more.</li><li>i am thankful</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here's what I'm learning and some re-learning:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>I should not break momentum.</strong> If I'm doing more, then I'm more productive as a whole.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I should use events as a way to start or not break momentum. Especially while it's such a beautiful biking weather outside!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I feel horrid when I stay at home for hours. Because I end up eating junk food and watching Mrs. Maisel for HOURS. What the heck Kathleen. I'm glad I did it, to know that I dislike it, so I'm done with that kind of relaxing... I'm glad I know that watching a show or eating junk food makes me binge and thus the answer is to eliminate it almost completely. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Every day, I should have 1-2 major accomplishments towards my long-term picture goals.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On days I have a lot of free time, I should schedule <em>ideally one but at most two </em>social events with other people that I want to deepen my relationship with and be present and cheerful and on time with. Quality over quantity!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Key Takeaways:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*the less stressed I am, the more HAPPY my relationships are!!!<br> *the hallmark of a good relationship is when one person goes crazy at a time (the other person takes the high road :) )<br> *raise my own bar: challenge myself to be patient, helpful, caring, kind<br> <strong>*take a deep breath and say: "<em>i'm so sorry you're upset. what's bothering you is important to me. what can i do to help?</em>"</strong><br> *if needed, use i would love it statements, i.e. "i would love it if you help me with <em>_</em>" "i would love it if we pick a night to be alone together" (use it for positive things and future-focused)<br> <br> *relationships need: connection, communication, playfulness<br> *we become a team! trust and goodwill to get us through the good times<br> *when we take responsibility and value our partner, taking this first step can Inspire the other to do the same thing!</p>

<p>I'm working from home in Woodside, CA. It's 68F and sunny and I'm sitting outside in shorts, flip flops, a t-shirt, my glasses, with a towel under my butt and a couch cushion behind me. This morning I woke up at 7AM, got my work out in (!), showered, made breakfast, cleaned up my room, got some McKinsey training done, and overall just have been doing stuff instead of making a list and prioritizing which is effort. I am living in paradise. I have access to a car. I have food in the fridge of soymilk, strawberries, cherries, veggies, a few more eggs; freezer: frozen fish :); pantry: tuna cans, quinoa, pasta, oats stuff for cereal. I have more than I need and enough that I can minimize stresses and finish my food before grocery shopping next (which btw I'll probably do this week at the discount grocery store :)! My computer battery is fully charged.</p>

Instead of trying to figure out all the options and then picking after exhaustive information gathering. Edit: also working on: practice storytelling and in particular, sharing bits of my own story... So others can connect to them, remember me, and share more with me.

I'm here to live my own life. Here are some of my choices:

1) live with my aunt for ~2 years

2) then live in SF? I like living in the suburbs because I can focus a bit more. I can still budget in friends say ~twice a week. Then if I become a higher-than-entry PM in a pre-IPO + rapidly growing company based in SF, I'll live in SF and spend a good amount of time making and solidifying friends who are also living in SF!!!

4) I also think I'd like to do that with kids because I genuinely believe resilience developed from obstacles creates long term success and purpose perhaps.

5) save and contribute $60k to Nicole's college fund (I have 4 years to do this, it's only 15k/year!!! Aka literally just the rent I'm saving on)

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also, here's a theme I've started to notice in life: Don't forget to pursue yourself. In high school, the overarching goal for the commons was grades and test scores. In college, it was also grades. In relationships, it's love. In work, it's work. BUT, the people who end up more successful in my mind after and through it all are those who continue to pursue themselves. Making yourself more than one "obligation" creates a fuller life and a happier happenstance within the "obligation" as well. For example, for me, I shall choose to keep on being interesting by following my interests outside of my common roles. Be multi-dimensional.</p>

Happy people

I am SO thankful
<span>Our bodies do a lot of crazy,&nbsp;</span><strong><a href="http://www.scarymommy.com/body-image/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">regulatory things</a></strong><span>&nbsp;that we don’t even realize. If our body is producing something and we try to strip it away, our bodies make more. If you have oily skin and you use harsh soaps and astringents to strip it of oil without applying a moisturizer to replenish what you took away, your body thinks it didn’t make enough oil the first time and makes even more to compensate. Take this from someone who knew nothing about skincare as an adolescent and did everything on the planet to make my teenage acne a million times worse.</span>

Source:

<a href="https://www.scarymommy.com/pedicure-foot-care-tips/">https://www.scarymommy.com/pedicure-foot-care-tips/</a>
Starting on the right foot
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For example, when the UI/UX McKinsey expert asked me to send something to VG, he did it in ~2 sentences, quickly and easily understood. And emotionally well too, his first sentence was, I know there's a lot on your plate, so I'm sorry to bother you/ask for another thing.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Whereas when K asked me, she gave me a story of the reason why... And it felt like it was easily double the time.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
AP -&gt; Need to staff people
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li><strong>Make plans with intention.</strong> I used to message multiple people when I thought of people, to make plans "someday." It's far more viable, efficient, and reflective of me in a way I want to be (doing what I say) to know of a date I'm free and ask a few people about that date (if they have anything planned that I can join) and possibly suggest an event I'd like to do :) </li><li>Condition A: <strong>Focus on a few geographically close friendships, doing activities I genuinely enjoy doing. </strong>It's okay not to be friends with everyone. I realize now that my free time is incredibly limited when I'm staffed, thus, when I'm staffed, to optimize for Condition A, and be okay with free time, meaning time I can be present with my family here.</li><li><strong>Appreciate the progress.</strong> I made it out! I'm no longer feeling that gnarling lonliness I felt two months ago &lt;3 </li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When an EA told me she puts her husband's wife as a priority when she asks for time on his calendar... because he's a family man (or something along those lines)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When my PD (or someone) told me that she knows a partner who **READS** on planes... and she makes the best of that time by reading a book. I didn't understand how much that's against the norm... and how most people are working on the plane rides.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

And this was all a dream
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Generate a perspective<ul><li>This is something taught in top business schools: generating a view with limited knowledge</li><li>Understand that not everyone is an expert... people don't really know as much as I maybe think they do</li><li>This is a mindset shift... work to practice it until it becomes a habit! :D </li><li>oh and remember that PSes are non-hierarchical! ! ! </li></ul></li><li>Take more ownership<ul><li>Add more to daily check-in than can do</li><li>Move a bit away from logistics</li><li>Work on keeping ball rolling on things</li></ul></li><li>Etc.<ul><li>Check in with Kathryn on a more scheduled, regular (weekly) basis</li></ul></li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Pros: can-do attitude. Con-ish to this: I take everything at face value. Remember the story of "obligation to dissent." It is a core value and a favorite thing of some at the firm! It's definitely something unique here, and I want to live towards it.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source: G</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ideas for self: be more helpful at feedback: be more constructive... this is what helps others! </p>

<p>Remember (this is what I've learned): </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>What's worse than saying no to something, is saying yes and not doing it well.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Give answers instead of questions... Then people can challenge your answer if they disagree. It provides a deeper level of thinking, including because if you've thought through an answer, then it's already deeper than just asking questions.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<p>Perhaps, when one has money, no matter what she does, she will make more money.</p>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Total contributions to retirement accounts: $703/month (15% of salary)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Contributing to Pre-Tax 401(k): 5% of salary<strong> [recently updated to 10%... numbers will need to be updated]</strong></li><li>Contributing to Roth 401(k): 10% of salary</li><li>Current YTD rate of return: 5.7%</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Take home pay (before tax refund?): $1993/2 weeks = $3986/month</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Automatic deposit to 2% VioBank savings account: $800/2 weeks = $1600/month (~a little under half of take home pay). This is my emergency fund (aka startup fund :)). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Left: ~$1200/month</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Spending breakdown:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Rent:  $300-500/month</li><li>Food: $50/week = $200/month</li><li>Misc purchases fund: $50/week = $200/month</li><li>Personal "giving" spending*: $50/week = $200/month... $2,400/year = 4.26% of my salary</li><li>Transportation: ?</li></ul>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When I feel a way:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>1. Take a walk outside </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>2. Take 3 deep breaths</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>3. Ask myself: what is important?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You're not happy. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And I'm not happy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We're just two unhappy people, trying to make each other happy?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I'm actually pretty sad.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It frustrates me how in your head you are. (<em>I want to become more like you in this way</em>)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How the world you see through those eyes, is a very much different world than mine.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>What happened to what we had?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Was it just in my mind?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Were those things just seen through a rosy-eyed filter of a life I wanted? The experiences I came up with that he agreeably said yes to? That I thrust him as wanting to as well in my mind, and when reality's curtains came up, yes he's happy to oblige, but obliging is only exciting for so long.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And why.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Why is it easier to write about angst than contentment,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Why are you a thousand miles away,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Why did you choose to do that,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>and why am I PMSing and you're freaking freaking not here.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>That’s what the books teach us to believe, to buy ETFs, because arbitrages and opportunities leave in a minute. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And others, they spend their lives thinking, living, breathing the markets. And they have all the information. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>So I / we can’t compete. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I think from this time (CoVid), I’ve learned this stream of thought is not true. The delay in market behavior can be days, weeks, months. Also, the market (I’m using this to be analogous to stocks) often over corrects. Herd mentality? </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Make sure API and channel teams are talking, make sure roadmaps are aligned</li><li>Make sure PMs are talking (incl what’s been done, shared learnings, things to keep consistent and less duplication of work), the organization has priorities</li><li>Make sure requirements are complete and have review by necessary stakeholders prior to when the requirements going to dev</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Overall, walkthroughs in general, with multiple stakeholders in the same room at the same time, allow for increased optimization of time / effort... there's less "throwing things over the fence" where people can get things wrong AND/or spend much more time individually trying to decipher requirement. And there's a sense of accountability: people should ask their questions there, and are responsible for knowing because they were there.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>They carry truer the more steps of the way I take</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I feel much more confidence in myself after a year here. I understand that I'm the owner of my workstream. I'm the expert. I manage-up. I'm the one who's thought the most on a piece, I'm the one who knows the insides and the outsides. I can talk with conviction. I'll ask questions, because I'm not afraid. I am selfish - I will do what it takes to get my workstream done, but doing so in a way where I understand the larger priorities of why this is important, and in a way that doesn't impede or negatively impact my relationships with others. I will balance this with working hard and showing that so that when I push back, I do it tactfully and not to make others (often at a "higher" position) feel disrespected. I will be cherry and positive and clear-minded and vocal about my priorities and needs. I will apologize when I don't do something right, part of ownership! I'm no longer intimidated by people of any titles (i.e. Partners, senior clients) because I KNOW they are counting on me to do my job so that they can succeed in their job. I will raise flags / lookouts as needed because that's part of managing up. I will defend the right to speak and get exposure because I'm the expert in my workstream and I'm proud of my work. I will listen to feedback and incorporate as needed. I will learn about different ways to conduct and lead. I will speak my mind. I will speak in meetings. I will be listened to. I will put myself in those situations... around those kinds of people, where I can thrive. I will take care of myself so I can add the most value to others. I will take a deep breath before reacting, because I know the way I act in times of stress is telling... and it speaks volumes to show my leadership in those times, and also people will judge me from those times for a long time afterwards. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When I start talking in meetings and someone else starts talking too, I usually say "go ahead" but instead <strong>I'm going to practice just continue speaking sometimes, and then address that someone was speaking after</strong>, saying X-name, sorry I think I cut you off? / you were going to say something? etc. Which I've seen leaders, esp women leaders, do adeptly and I admire and feel good when I'm on the receiving end.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I've learned things on adding value, and how I can best do so. Including being reliable... this means doing what I say I'll do. I'll earn trust. I'll be on upward trajectories. I'll keep people in the loop - on what needs to be done, what are roadblocks, and look outs.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Oh hugely beyond being reliable: REMEMBERING THINGS when they're told! Learning quickly... When a partner / client / etc. tell us something ONCE, we have to know it. We become experts but also know when to ask for others who will help us in different contexts. I.e. understanding that a partner can provide value by having visibility to other discussions and advice on client interaction.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Obligation to dissent with reasons and alternative solutions. Providing potential answers with questions. Sticking to my obligation to dissent. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Perhaps, there aren't any stupid questions. There are stupid actions - like not asking questions at a certain time... There are questions asked at some times when the time is not right.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<p>More things learned: I'm a point of filtering... My "intelligence" is... I.e. if someone tells me to do something (i.e. needing engaging with someone else), I'll filter for, i.e. when is the right time to engage, is the info already there?, WHY are we doing this / why do we need this?, how to communicate this?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Someone once said this advice... about writing a list of 20 or so of your top priorities. And then crossing off every single one of them... except the top three. Circle the top three. Then don't think, dream, breathe on anything else. Have those top three consume you. Immerse yourself in the community. And you'll become an expert.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>from McK vs elsewhere:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>we work backwards, to ensure everything is complete and proper time is allocated</li><li>we do more than needs to be done... to minimize the times we're hard pressed for time come deadlines and ad hoc things come about... like trying to predict what those ad hoc things are before they come up... helps with lifestyle</li><li>we finish things well and early to incorporate feedback. we do things and "push over" to the next person / client / decision making so that it's on them to do / review. I think sometimes in other companies, the person who needs to review (higher stakeholder / decision-maker) is asking those workers for the work, whereas here, we also manage up - meaning saying nicely asking the person that need to review for review... I.e. giving a reason (aligning with that person's goals too) and timeline and asking for the thing to be reviewed to be prioritized :)</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Day 1 of Monterey house</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Every single day, I feel a bit inspired. I feel good. My body feels good when the sun hits my bare skin.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Recently some updates:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>I want to work hard for 6, 8 years? I want to anchor my mind on other careers and other people who I think have fulfilling, inspiring lives where they are at, and work like them. Other career examples could include surgeons, lawyers, even just doctors.... how many years of school they need to prep... and residency or so on.</li><li>I want to continue keeping space from Jordan in my 20s or up to a certain point. I want to selfishly work on myself and my dreams. Because I know that I'm the type of person whose thoughts become consumed with optimizing my loved one's goals and actions. And I want him and I to both flourish individually so we can come together later strongly. </li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Day 1 </strong>- 2/2/21</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Time to value (more important than day to market)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Few companies that do product well: amazon, facebook, etsy, workiva(?), etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The hard thing about hard things &lt;- one of the best books on PM</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"dont need to market your orchestra"  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>fails to culture:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Engineering used only to deliver, Delivery oriented PM/PO roles, Limited customer interaction, Lack of focused goals / too many goals, Non validated feature-based roadmap, Limited data / insight, Focus on dates over results, Never revisiting the “MVP”, Limited x-functional collaboration, Long feedback loops, Lack of integrated design </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>+ a slide on all the failures... incl failure aversion</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Need to make sure that PM addresses all the risks on the slide before an engineer writes a prod line of code! (slide 23)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Collaborate at same time (PM, designer, engineer) instead of sequentially!</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Focus on solving problems and results (instead of like a roadmap / timelines, etc.)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Engage engineers! in testing, playing w prototype, etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Apple focuses completely on customer problems</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>on public dates: SHOULD HAVE ENG / etc team to evaluate risks and help with the timeline</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>high integrity commitment: team does DD on risk, etc... so the team can say if we can deliver stuff by when.... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>solutions should be validated (incl continuously) for risks!! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>q: how to manage commitments? ex -&gt; <strong>open, honest conversation</strong> with leadership.... maybe trim the scope? go to exec with different options. what else can we stop to do this? or can we deliver most of the value without all the functionality? is this a resource question (getting more resource from another team)? **DATA beats opinions... go with data on why something takes longer to deliver... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>hybrid model is ok, NEED internal: tech lead, designer, and product manager. (other roles like eng can be outsourced if so)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>he's not a fan of SAFE and POs... instead of focusing on stories being ready, focus on are we building the right thing</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>PM: value and viability of prod and accountability of team</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Testing MWF - 3-4 hrs / week... is how to iterative quickly. incl w users?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>random thought, these trainings cost ~$2500 / person and there are 60 people, thus this week of training, they'd make $150k.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>jon@svpg.com</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>SVPG workshop, 2.3.21</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>4 hrs/ week on discovery needed for good solutions,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Spending 1hr every morning looking at data (to coming up with insight! To deliver solutions to drive the most value)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*looking for insights: see changes to understand WHY… prod strategy shouldn't change every quarter… but frequency changes depending on insights</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Meeting free Thursdays - on team level - effective!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Roadmaps = root cause of ___</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Don't focus on features and dates!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>**objectives should empower to solve problems rather than deliver features</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Teams need context: understanding of what other teams are doing, etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Software: 3-5 years to deliver a vision</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Hardware: 5-10</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Lots of companies DON'T have a product strategy! (problems to cover)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Instead they often start at product discovery?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Objectives from leadership (ex: "reduce X time")</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Key results from product team</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(ex: "reduce X time to Y days")</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A negotiation!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But COMMON GOAL. Even if there are diff ways to achieve it</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>**MAKE High integrity commitments, meaning, leaders give a problem AND time for product team to do discovery… product team does discovery and gives a date.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(instead of being given a date!)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Smart strategy: leadership can expect failure… giving same problem to multiple teams, seeing which works! (diversified bets)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^similar to china companies</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*leaders tell how aggressive to be (moonshot ideas - <strong>being ok with those not getting anywhere</strong> - leaders need to be ok with this)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*collaboration is normal… when a team has dependencies, the depending platform team for ex should have same objectives<br>&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Servant leadership &gt;&gt; command and control</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*early escalation of problems (share w manager who should help - with prioritization or whatnot)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*weekly review / check in/ sprint planning</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Focus groups don't work cuz customers don't know what they want</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(eg Amazon Prime, iPhone / blackberry, car / horse, etc.)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*hard to know what you want before you see it…</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*focus groups would just tell you how to make current products better instead of innovation….</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*too late for eng to see something if eng sees something first time in Sprint planning… they should see it earlier, to talk about technical feasibility.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>PM =&gt; build trust by building the right thing… if you don't, and need to roll back / not reach users, then this decreases morale of engineers</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*PM to involve all stakeholders! Incl legal, etc. Do the homework! Understand business restraints… incl customer care, marketing, comms, sales, etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If the PM can't attend user testing / user discovery, then cancel it.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"Sometimes its like being a doctor, we don't feel the pain, but keep diagnosing, iterating on treatments, till a prescribed approach solves the disease"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Have a discovery backlog, in addition to a delivery backlog</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Why do I get this reoccuring feeling.... of... these lows on Fridays... after the "go-go-go" comes the period of utmost rest.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Like those days in high school I skipped... to be alone. Maybe a pattern on these days, is that I feel alone. Without too much of a choice. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Small thoughts.. in knowledge. Like knowing that team event budgets are $85, when I had assumed $65... for meals, etc. But alas. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Who we are, are who we are. The common threads from our childhood to our adulthood. I am me, you are you. And the world continues to turn. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Again and again, at the end of the day, I am anchored by gratitude. I have everything I could ever want. What more could I ask for. The question that torments me sometimes... what more "should" I ask for? My one life, how do *I* want to live it? I'm happy and perhaps that's good.</p>

<p>CEO/ founders should say: what do yo uthink of this idea, instead of "build it"</p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Reference (early) customers</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*people who really really need the solution</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*not sell at discount, they'd be willing to pay at full price… cuz people talk… if at discount, then discount price would become your future price</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*not necessarily tech forefront people</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*they are looking for change</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*they need to recommend the product to the world.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*include reference customers in your planning</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*MINIMUM OF 6, all from same specific target market</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>6-8 is sweet spot</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>PM should find the 6 reference customers using the PROTOTYPE before going into production…</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^this is product-market fit…</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<p>Google concluded that the most successful teams shared five traits:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>1. Psychological safety</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>2. Dependability</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>3. Structure and clarity</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>4. Meaning</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>5. Impact</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Product designer creates prototypes to test:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Feasibility, viability, etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Case study, Jon's exp at The Guardian</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*international prod strategy -&gt; mobile -&gt; build international audience!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*international media brands…</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A) Strategy, B) Operationalize</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Diff types of prototypes. For Feasibility prototype, takes an afternoon - few days… needed when tech lead says to you, "hey I'm nervous"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*also done in "spike"… sometimes some engineers go out to try this… and due the DD on feasibility… coding!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>ATV = average transaction value</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*is one of the hardest metrics to shift!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Live test prototype: do it fast, can hard code stuff…</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ex: the bundle feature in Amazon for high ATV products.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Idea came from a curious engineer :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In presenting to Bezos, they had a slide with 1 number, of the amount of $ the company would be LOSING if they didn't make the product live!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Don't listen to customers when: customers DON'T KNOW what's possible!! Why you need a product team!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(ex: Disney magic band)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Zappos initially was how they built things that don't scale… in the beginning, they built a page, when something's bought, a paper was printed and an intern drove down to the store to buy the shoes and then shipped them.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Comment: Jet.com did something similar!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*offline simulation: sometimes used to predict future behavior (for companies / products at scale)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Tomorrow: qualitative and quantitative testing</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*testing for value….</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Q I have:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>do engineers build production products from prototype products? if yes, when? if no, can you speak more about the change for users from prototype to production?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A: diff quality thresholds for the MVP and prod! *sometimes can re-use aspects of protoype to prod quality… but most of code isn't re-usable. (cuz prototype has only done ~10% of work… ~90% of work still ahead of you)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*the design work can be reused</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ex: when a Sr Partner I worked with (mostly exposed through planning a team event), reached out to me at the start of Covid to just check how I'm doing, I was pretty happy-go-lucky - I didn't know how to communicate with him and didn't want to take up his time.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I think a better mindset could be: I am adding value to him as well because I'm helping plug him into what junior consultants are feeling.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>One potential system: publishing! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>From Priya's article (echoes similar sentiments I've heard elsewhere too): "blogging can be about a lot more than validation. writing has lead me to new friends and romantic matches. my co-living house, the rabbithole, has three co-founders: me, my boyfriend, and a boy who reached out to me after reading my tweets and articles. i've been pursued for jobs by people who are familiar with me only through my writing."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I dislike social media because I don't feel like I'm good enough and I don't want to engage in a competition of posting things??????? But does that end up just taking me OUT of the benefits that come with social media? Do I really know if I don't feel good and I feel comparative if I post things on social media (Instagram namely) but then don't engage in consumption of others' content?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>MAYBE: if there's a way for me to engage only when I'm doing cool things in my life? And then to not engage (and to take a break) when I'm not? </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Hey Nicole,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here's a potential ACT study plan for your summer. Much of the ACT plan will help you in the SAT too! I think it's worth focusing your efforts to study for 1 test at a time. It's not necessary to take both, but you can if you want.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When I was in high school, people didn't really talk about studying for the ACT or SAT, but it <em>is </em>worth going all in to study for (for a few months or so), getting a great score, and then not needing to stress about it anymore! You're wicked smart and incredibly disciplined, so I know you'll do awesome.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My mindset on ACT scores for the colleges you're targeting:<br><em>If you want:</em> when you study, aim for a perfect score of 36 (yay for motivating, concrete, ambitious goals). <br><strong>If you get a 36 </strong>- woooooooot!!!! You'll get some special recognition from HCHS, the state, and more.<br><strong>If you get a 35</strong> on the actual test - that's awesome - in this situation, it's up to you if you'd want to try again for the 36 (my perspective is <strong>no </strong>- this score is good enough for your schools and it'd be wise to spend the time on other aspects of yourself and your application that make you distinct instead of using that time to study more for these tests). <br><strong>If you get a 34, 33, etc.</strong> - I'd recommend studying some more and retaking the test one more time. You can do it! The content isn't difficult and you'll have learned a lot from your real life test taking experience (which is inherently different than practice tests).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2 id="study-plan">Study plan:</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li><strong>Decide on dates. </strong>Is there a 8-10 week window you can commit to studying for ~8-10 hours / week? Then pick and register for a testing date. Actually signing up helps hold you accountable.<ul><li>Pros / cons of summer vs school semester studying. </li><li>You have ~3 months of summer vacation. I recommend taking the first 2 weeks to TOTALLY rest. Stack studying with other summer items... Otherwise hard to motivate...</li></ul></li><li><strong>Design your structure.</strong> <ul><li><em>Example:</em> <ul><li>First weekend - take a full diagnostic test (unless you already have done this or taken a test before!).</li><li>During the week - Study a chapter Tuesdays and Thursdays at 7-9pm following the Pomodoro technique. </li><li>Every weekend (around same time as actual test - usually morning) - take a full practice test or review your last test questions on alternating weekends.</li></ul></li><li>We can dive deeper into efficient studying approaches and specific tips for each section once you start!</li></ul><ul><li>Treat your commitment for studying for the ACT (during the time-boxed time - e.g., 8 weeks) similarly seriously as you'd treat a school class. Understand that this test score is an element to your college application about as important as a grade in a class... and think about how much time you put into attending and studying for any class! </li></ul></li><li><strong>Find accountability. </strong>Have someone hold you accountable to your goals and the study plan (I'm always happy to be your accountability partner ;)). The most brilliant plan can fall through if there is no accountability towards execution.</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3 id="tips-i-followed"><strong>Tips I followed:</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><em>Mindset: </em>You need to deeply understand your own reasons for why you want to do this. In addition, time-boxing your study time (e.g., 8 weeks of studying until your test) is extremely helpful for motivation, prioritization (you'll never have nor should put all the time in the world to study absolutely everything for this test - prioritization is important to focus on the most important things to achieve your goals), and less procrastination. </li><li><em>Mobile Apps:</em> Download a ACT (or SAT) prep app. Maybe try to download a few to see which ones you like the most. Move that app to your home screen. Build a habit to click it during those micro-distraction times in life when we go on our phone. I remember many bathroom breaks where I was reviewing SAT vocab because the app made it so easy to do so.<ul><li>This is a tip I've done for other tests in my life too. I had the Quizlet app for AP tests, I downloaded study apps for the GMAT.</li><li>These apps on your phone (+ a notebook) are also easier than the full test books to bring anywhere! </li></ul></li><li><em>Grammar for English Section: </em>Learning the tested grammar rules was most helpful to "easily" improve my English score. I still remember (and use) most of these today!</li><li><em>Calculator for Math Section: </em>Practice using your calculator smartly (there will be times it's faster to solve by hand). Know how you can solve problems creatively as needed (I remember getting a math question I was struggling to solve by hand. Then I plugged the equation in my calculator to plot a graph, zoomed to the correct range in the graph, and found an intersect. I did that because I knew how to use those features on my calculator). Possibly add <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://mcelroytutoring.com/blog-post.php?id=4332&amp;title=10+Helpful+ACT+Math+Calculator+Programs+for+the+TI+Graphing+Series+of+Calculators" target="_blank">calculator programs</a> - but only if you intend to practice with them during your studying - otherwise if it's not muscle memory to use, it may take more time to use them on the actual test than not using them.</li><li><em>On Practice Tests: </em>Focus on learning from your mistakes. While taking practice tests, I starred the questions that I was unsure of. After the test, I revisited all (/ most of) the questions I starred, whether they were right or wrong, and read the solutions to understand the correct answer. Reviewing questions from a practice test isn't fun, but is really important to reveal mistakes you can learn to not do on the real test! <ul><li>Also be mindful of timing and approach when you take practice tests to simulate the real test. Timing is less important for example questions to practice specific concepts.</li></ul></li><li><em>Focus: </em>Don't get inundated by the myriad of resources available. There exist so many ACT books, Quizlets, Khan Academy videos, blogs, etc. that there is not enough time to ingest everything. Pick a few good study resources (maybe primarily 1-2 prep books supplemented with a few website posts and phone apps) to have focused studying. Tune out the noise; it's okay to not do everything - a more focused studying will lead to better test score results.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3 id="few-internet-articles-that-could-be-worth-a-skim"><strong>Few internet articles that could be worth a skim: </strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://blog.prepscholar.com/best-act-prep-books" target="_blank">Best ACT Prep Books</a> - TL;DR: buy and use the top 2 ACT prep books. Other than that, this article may not be worth fully reading.</li><li><a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://blog.prepscholar.com/how-to-get-a-perfect-act-score-by-a-36-full-scorer" target="_blank">How to Get a Perfect ACT Score, by a 36 Full Scorer</a> - long, but this article in it's entirety is worth a skim</li><li><a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.reddit.com/r/ACT/comments/c00qmz/a_comprehensive_guide_to_studying_for_the_act/" target="_blank">A Comprehensive Guide to Studying for the ACT</a> - worth a skim section by section (when you're studying math for example, it may be helpful to review the math tips from this post. Same for science and English.)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Love from your big sis,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Kathleen</p>

Whether it's self-studying AP tests, starting your own club, or running your own business... there will be similar patterns in designing your own structure when life doesn't provide a straight forward one.</em></p>

<p>5/10/21 possible college essay idea draft </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>likely change first sentence to be more compelling.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My family and I climb the Swallow Cliff stairs about once every month. There are 125 thick ragged steps on the way up and 145 steps on the way down. Trust me, I've counted.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>By junior year of high school, I am able to comfortably do 6 flights (6 times all the way up and back down); on amazing days, I've painstakingly done 10. Today, I've set a personal goal to do 20.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The first couple rounds start with the usual roughness. My heartbeat races with the very first flight up. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->

<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Takeaway</strong>:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>I look around. I know what my race is. <em>Convey what you are really passionate about.</em></li><li><em>Show that you are really hard working for what you want. When you set a goal, you'll accomplish it :P</em></li></ol>

When my heart feels like it's going to explode, I <ol><li>Or: <em>Breathe</em>. I've felt this feeling a few times before. On stage presenting for BPA Nationals. Hosting my first entrepreneurship club meeting. Stepping on the tennis court at State. My heart feels like it's going to explode, and I am on the brink of crying. <em><strong>Breathe </strong></em>- my mother's voice says in my head louder. Like each time before, I start to take deep, collected breaths until my heartbeat is no longer in my ears and is back in my chest.</li><li>Nineteen.</li></ol></li><li>Thinking about the different races - how everyone is in a different race - thirteen?</li><li>Thinking about what my race is / what I'm willing to give it my all for - twenty<ol><li>My hands touch the final steps before I crawl my feet up to meet them. Twenty.</li></ol></li></ol>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>https://twitter.com/celinehalioua?s=21</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Damn. I came here without much expectation. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I thought I’d like in somewhere very green and rural - like a farm area. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Nairobi, man. This city is incredible. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>First, the people here. The community I built here. Wow. Everyone being so open and friendly. And kind and adventurous and fun. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Bliss. I feel overwhelming bliss and gratitude. Sometimes it’s hard to move because of a huge surge of this feeling. Looking around, I have so much. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How do I have so much? How do I have a beautiful body, blessed with my figure, my height, my health, my athleticism. How do I have the best family, so so so freaking supportive, so full of love, so wonderful always. How do I have the best boyfriend. We have our health, we have our minds. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My career. How do I have the best skills, education, experiences. How do I have the best friends, the best network, the best mentors. How did I get so fucking lucky. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This world, I started with some intentions… and then the world blew my intentions out of the water. Exceeded my wildest expectations. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Living here, sometimes I think of Catcher in the Rye - when there is the boda driver who delivers my fruit before the rain on his birthday. How happy he looks. How torn his pants are. How this makes me feel sad. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When these people who don’t have that much, or at least are working fucking hard - even like Caroline our house cleaner. And then finally, they are so fucking happy, cheerful, etc. Damn I just feel .. sad??</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I should share more. Send Caroline some money? Make her some brownies or something? Give her some food or something? I have everything. I sit and make money. Others live hand to mouth, working so so so hard!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Perspective. It’s relative. Life works. Life is great. How can I not work hard. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When I came to kenya, I hadn’t physically met / known a single person here. I didn’t expect:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d climb the tallest mountain of Africa</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d get scuba diving certified and swim with turtles, dolphins, mantis shrimp</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d learn about leadership from horse riding lessons - and that I’d gallop and jump (this was involuntary!) on a horse in Mt Kenya region en route to mao mao caves. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d get hooked on kite surfing. I’m hooked. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d visit the world’s (or Africa’s?) largest slum </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d find some incredibly beautiful clothing pieces at secondhand stores </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d have the best camping experiences </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d view my mom in new eyes - she’s so freaking awesome more so than I ever thought</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d attend the best parties I ever have </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d eat such flavorful food. The produce is so fresh!!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d meet such friendly, caring, loving people in the local people. Who care! Who provide the most excellent service. The honey waxes, the Swedish massages, the pedicures, the foot reflexology, the clean room and clean sheets and people who just fucking amazing. Personal service and attentiveness. And the personal training. The gym I walk to. The arboretum I walk to. The Sunday yoga. Damn I’ll miss that. 90 minutes of zen. Mindfulness in yoga, horseback riding, kite surfing. My beautiful friends. Stepping away from the US life I knew to chase adventure - a wild African adventure. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d laugh so so so so so so so so much. I didn’t realize I’d find a family in my roommates. Mae, Cameron… you two have made me laugh until my stomach hurt more times than I can count. You gave me a feeling of safety and security. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>That victorious youth. Some soundtrack of youth seems to play in my mind as I replay these memories. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

First projects? (Big ones incl: OKRs, AOP, investor relations, special projects and what those could look like)</p>
