<p>From Eisenhower </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Said from Jim Collins </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also: take care of people, instead of mindset of taking care of career </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"Satisficers are <strong>those who make a decision or take action once their criteria are met.</strong> That doesn’t mean they’ll settle for mediocrity; their criteria can be very high; but as soon as they find the car, the hotel, or the pasta sauce that has the qualities they want, they’re satisfied.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Maximizers want to make the optimal decision.</strong> So even if they see a bicycle or a photographer that would seem to meet their requirements, they can’t make a decision until after they’ve examined every option, so they know they’re making the best possible choice."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source:  <a href="https://gretchenrubin.com/2006/06/are_you_a_satis/">https://gretchenrubin.com/2006/06/are_you_a_satis/</a> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My thoughts: I used lean extremely towards being a maximizer, but more and more, I'm trying to make decisions in a "satisficer" framework which I realize lead to increased happiness! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How do I get better at this?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Important qualities
to PM-ing:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Intellectual
     curiosity</li><li>Graciousness
     <ul><li>Separation
      of self-worth and product success</li></ul></li><li>Emotional
     intelligence<ul><li>Empathy</li><li>Asking
      open questions and listening</li><li>Communication
      &amp; being comfortable with uncertainty</li></ul></li><li>Analytical
     &amp; strategy component<ul><li>Market
      research: understanding markets and trends, understanding strengths of
      company for market positioning</li><li>User
      research</li><li>Analytics:
      what data means, A/B testing</li></ul></li><li>Polyglot<ul><li>Ability
      to communicate with various stakeholders (i.e. tech, marketing, sales)</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>What makes an exceptional
PM:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This is dependent on the PM stage. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Earlier
     on, it is important to master the hard skills and lead by example</li><li>For
     PM leadership, the ability to inspire- to sell a vision and influence
     others- is important</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Red flags to look at
when joining a company:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Overbearing
     cofounders (lack of autonomy to do PM work)</li><li>Lack
     of company clarity or focus (i.e. doing everything to chase revenue)</li><li>Toxic
     environments (i.e. blame culture)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It’s the PM’s job to push back on these, but if they’re
immutable, the solution may have to be to change companies.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are differences between working with new founders vs seasoned
company leaders. For new founders, it may be helpful to establish personal credibility
(i.e. I’ve done this X times at Y.) and do more story-telling to appeal to
their emotional / idealistic visions.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Other insights:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>It’s
     okay to take time to think: 1) say thank you, 2) say I’ll get back to you,
     3) always follow-up!</li><li>Product
     dev is a team sport</li><li>It’s
     important to be self-aware (strengths/weaknesses) and ask for help</li><li>It’s
     important to have alignment with C-level team </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Differences between being a founder and a PM:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Founder needs to do non-product things, i.e. hiring (their friends in the start... which has potential problems in that...), payroll, fundraising, logistics, etc.</li><li>Founder has less work-life balance</li><li>Founder should be more idealistic and constantly selling their vision</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A wise mentor from Watson JM told me this. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A weakness I'd like to work on is closing out items. I'm good at starting things... Not so good at carrying them across the finish line.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>So. <strong>For the month of November, I will write four polished blog posts </strong>- or about one each week. I noticed I've been just jotting down thoughts in notes on paper, on my phone, or on Wordpress. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Time to work on carrying things through. I believe the details are what separate the good from the great.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Helps with maintenance. Helps with surpassing inertia to cleaning room.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>#1 is Performance.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"<a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="http://money.cnn.com/2013/04/11/news/companies/ben-jerry-ice-cream.pr.fortune/index.html" target="_blank">Ben and Jerry’s co-founders</a> talked about their 30+ year working relationship and had some good advice. Jerry Greenfield said:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:quote -->
<blockquote class="wp-block-quote"><p><strong>“Our basic agreement was that the person who felt more strongly about the particular issue got their way,”"</strong></p></blockquote>
<!-- /wp:quote -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source:  <a href="http://www.consultantsmind.com/2013/05/05/6-reasons-why-consultants-are-revision-crazy/">http://www.consultantsmind.com/2013/05/05/6-reasons-why-consultants-are-revision-crazy/</a> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Applied to my arguments, I will ask my counterpart how much they care about the issue and assess my own care level.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>source (and a great skim):  <a href="http://www.consultantsmind.com/2013/10/10/two-kinds-of-people/">http://www.consultantsmind.com/2013/10/10/two-kinds-of-people/</a> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I feel that I’ve finally grown into me. I was ready to be 23 when I was 22 (a stark departure from previous years where I'll still feel like I'm the previous year's age for months after my birthday).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I am continually entranced by this world around me.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A pause to reflect on where I am, how far I’ve come. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>On partner love:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’ve told my close friends about J. How when we started
seeing each other, I had this underlying thought of <em>I can’t believe I’m dating him</em>. We’re nearing three years of
courtship and four years of knowing of each other’s existence. He is beyond the
person I envisioned I’d be with, since I was a young’un dreaming of her prince.
</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And yet, he’s not perfect. He’s a human being, as am I. At
age 23, my perspective has matured to seeing him as a separate entity. He’s my
chosen case study who will continuously change (I’ll somewhat influence these
changes), and I will continuously stay curious to learn about this person.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Being so close with another person, I’ve learned the
importance of developing a stronger understanding of myself. I used to take his
words and actions (applied to himself) as truth to how I should be as well,
because I incredibly respect him. Now, I devote time to thinking about how <em>I</em> want to be, which lets me see if his
perspective would work with mine. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>At the same time, I would blindly follow him if he reached
out his hand. Our mutual trust (including our often exercised constructive
dissent) establishes a baseline for this sort of comfort I’ve seen mature
couples have. We understand each other, our needs for space, flow, sleep. We
communicate, we listen, we remember, and we act accordingly. I feel less
emotional angst when we’re apart.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>At age 23, I’m okay if we’re apart. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>On self-love:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This has been on maintenance mode since I can remember. Thank
you especially to my mom for being the best role model in this arena and my
family for creating an ever-supporting environment. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>On preferences:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I can purchase a pair of shoes in less than 10 minutes (from
entering a store to trying the shoes on to paying at the register). I can put
down a shirt that I love the look of (on the clothes rack) with no remorse,
because I know the cut will not be flattering on my body. My high school years
were the test kitchen where I learned through impulse purchases what looks and
feels good on me, and more importantly, what does not.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I know the kinds of food I like to eat when I eat out.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I no longer spend hours at grocery stores (and Costco!), but
I still do enjoy taking my sweet time perusing farmer’s markets and the corner
stores in Daly City that are primarily stocked with produce! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My prioritization of “value” in making decisions is a
prevalent common thread. I’ve learned that there is a direct relation between free
time I have and my incessant desire for optimization. The less free time I
have, the more I can push down my tendency towards optimization, creating a
happier overall self. This relates to a few concepts I’ve learned about this
year: 1) abundance v scarcity mentality (abundance mentality enables less optimization
of resources), 2) satisficer v maximizer (satisficers optimize less and accordingly,
have less regret).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>On the path forward:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d like to be relentless focused. My initial take on this
year and next year was to be relentlessly unfocused so that I can keep on learning
as much as I can about the world. However, after a few weeks of this (while I’ve
been unstaffed), I realize that this doesn’t make me happy. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>At this age, I can commit YEARS of my life to become really
good at what I do- both professionally and hobby-ally. I’d like my hobbies to
include physical growth, intellectual growth, and creative growth. I haven’t
found a hobby I’d like to be extraordinary at yet. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Hobbies I’m dabbling in right now (order not significant):
1) surfing, 2) piano, 3) ballet</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Hobbies I’ve dabbled in prior to 23: 1) fitness classes incl
barre, 2) cooking, 3) rock climbing / bouldering</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>On biggest lessons
this past year:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Give first. One example is to share more about
myself to build rapport with others. Another example is to do favors for others…
As I learned in the first episodes of Suits, having others want to reciprocate help
is a long-term powerful privilege. </li><li>The way I do something is the way I do
everything. I’ve started to see the validity of “work hard, <em>play</em> hard” because perhaps play builds
connection to others (which also helps “work”). Play can add value by helping
myself become more interesting, thus others may want to have more association with
me. </li><li>People are just people. Connect to people
outside of their professional role and more to their humanness. </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>On moving forward:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Exercise, diet, sleep are my cornerstone habits
for life</li><li>Creativity is an element I am cautious to not
neglect </li><li>Optimize for flow work (set schedules?)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Somewhat comparable to someone giving you their lottery numbers and their process in picking them. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>life is too short for anything else.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>So if they are talking about it, they’re making money off of you. Thus, be skeptic to buying what they’re selling. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Just checked, the word I meant is: vicarious </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>but voracious works too.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>So many hours wasted on social media, YouTube..., drugs,video games, Instagram (incl stories). <strong>Where people are spending their lives escaping their current lives.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We need to create, experience, and live presently more.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We're eight years apart. Yet it feels like we're a generation separated. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You're growing up with peers living a double life - on social media and in person.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are two times the social rules and norms to learn and adhere to. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I want you to know that: At the end of the day, only one of those lives really matters. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Both are important, but be cautious of getting caught in the social media world. It can warp your sense of identity and worth. It can create anxiety, desires for what you currently don't have (without providing the space to really question yourself if it's something you actually want), and a general less satisfaction with where you are right now.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you ever notice yourself slipping, there is a difficult but possible solution: a social media detox (see my second post on this blog). You'll see that life still goes on. You're not missing out on anything. And you'll be stronger than before.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Love you lots,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Kathleen</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For example, when my doctor once told me to take antibiotics twice a day after food until I finished them, I listened to what I thought was most important: the details up to "until I finished them." So after I felt better after a few days, I stopped taking them... Later I learned that <a href="https://www.who.int/features/qa/stopping-antibiotic-treatment/en/">stopping early can lead to antibiotic resistance</a>. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Another example is this <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EKIhc3tS0os&amp;t=217s">YouTube video</a> advising 18 year-olds to open a credit card. The advice is sound (this can build one's credit for the long-term!), and the instructions have more than one step. I fear that teenagers will listen to what they think is important and follow that (going to a bank, filling out a form, opening a credit card asap) with less focus on the step of paying back the credit card EVERY TIME. Also it's important to first build the discipline to not overspend given credit. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A solution to comprehensive transfer of instructions for the instruction-giver's side is: 1) develop empathy for the instruction-listener. Think<em> what might he/she need to know</em>? Ask them or others for questions or perhaps to repeat back what you said in their own words. 2) Emphasize the "why" something is important to do! Mention the risks for maximum transparency.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’m often in awe of new things to the world someone has thought of and built. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Some part seeing what there has been, some part creativity spurring, other part ITERATION. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For example the apartment with 5 bedroom for $3000 in San Francisco.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There was another example I had in mind when writing this, that I can't remember right now...</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Anyways, hold and pass on, dealing directly with humans instead of the world wide interwebs.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>is this a heuristic? or a psychological model for thinking? PRINCIPLE! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How for ex, the question asked is: visualize the congruence and frictions between our values and the firm's. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>So the answer for most people shows equal examples of congruence and friction to fulfill the question criterion.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>However, it doesn't address the magnitude of each... For ex, there *should* be mostly congruence, naturally, since we work here. Yet the "published" answer doesn't show that! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/the-knowledge-project-with-shane-parrish/id990149481?i=1000459190559</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Push back (i.e. to EM/others in position of leadership) smartly. They (EM and others) may respect you more. Do this sometimes instead of saying yes and taking orders every time.</li><li>There's a difference between being right and being liked.</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Write it down</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And check up on it next time in conversation </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It’ll mean you remembered and thought of them. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>However, and more effective, you can lead them to change their own mind. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Example tactics: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>* asking questions and providing enough context or justifying pieces of information to have the person connect the dots themselves, instead of force feeding the justifications (in which they may be more prone to poke holes in yours, thus being more defensive as well)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(Or more eloquently said: "people love to come to conclusions themselves or 'finding something out' by themselves. they’re more likely to change their mind if you present evidence and let them make their own conclusion, rather than telling them 'you’re wrong, here’s why'")</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>* leading by example; having someone directly see benefits of certain actions/mindsets </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>* instigate further, external support of your claims after planting a seed... Ex: quote/publication supporting your side from a source respected by the person you want mind changed. Ex: natural conversation the person you want mind changed has with someone in the future </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>By repeating what I think they mean , and asking if my understanding is correct, in a concise manner. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also, chronologically, seek to understand them first. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also @me to practice: presenting my views (no matter how sure I hold them) as tentative, using phrases like "unless I'm wrong", "according to studies/___ I've read/___", "the way I see things". I should improve on my own open mindedness to lead in example, to be vulnerable first, to "give first".</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And when minds are changed, don't gloat and instead say, "it seems we're on the same page that _____"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And thought on the long game goal: building rapport, to create trust, mutual understanding, likeability... All needed to persuade, influence, lead. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There may be many places reminiscent of Urbana the Urbane. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It may be cool to name my child Urbana.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Just like, how it may be cool to name a kid Chevy. Short for Chevrolet.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Let's go:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I'm chasing Urbana. I'm chasing the group potlucks and damn, the wind in my hair with my backpack thumping on my back, as I bike through those marvelous trees, bright red and bright green, in those scarlet days.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I'm chasing Urbana. I'm chasing my unknown dreams. I feel the down-to-earthness and the genuine niceness of these people who freaking care about... people, earth, the things that help me escape from go-go-go of a pressing, suppressed ambition; because I can't let that ambition enthrall me, he already has his hands around my neck, the grip pulls me towards people who talk about things I don't understand how they create value to the people that need value most.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I'm chasing Urbana. She's close, she's getting closer. I feel the air, the brisk bitingness of winter coming.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Fall</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Winter</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Him, with his gruffled grey beard. Him on his bike, the wrinkles pressed near his eyes when he smiles. He said "There's nothing like these caring people, this community."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When I asked, "why did you return <em>here </em>after all those other places?"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Spring</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Summer</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I'm chasing Urbana. I dance around the rainbow-light-kissed floor of our victorian era house. I dance around the soft, tough grass surrounding a fierce bonfire glow. I dance in the house parties with the rock climbing wall and mattresses on the floor and the attic we are invited to paint with our hands. I dance and run and want to scream to exhale my lungs enough so I can breathe in more on my next breath.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I'm chasing Urbana, and I know I can't go back. It all holds as a still frame in this ongoing roll of my life. And still, I'll continue to reach out for her trees, her air, her houses, her people, her bike lanes, and her nonchalant vigor of youth - rushing to make the most of this brief life we are given.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> Urbana is where I found myself, as wholly as I could. Urbana is where I started to love a boy who became the man in my life. Urbana is where I laughed all the time, traveled the world by interesting conversations with co-op-mates, and where I retreated to cry and cry again for the beauty of this spectrum of feeling. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Urbana, I quite like you.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In fact, this is the perfect and the right time. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>People remember the things closest to the present. Meaning, just because you were a certain way far long ago, doesn't mean you have to stay the same. Don't think you can't change. There really aren't social limits to you changing. What others think will be just in your head. Or not important.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Besides, improvement makes a better story. More memorable too. People tend to remember and praise the "mal" people who turned good later on more than the people who were good (i.e. putting in high effort) all the time. Just look at the philanthropists like Bill Gates. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also, young one, make friends. Don't rush. Let others win. It'll help you in the long run.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There's enough win-win in this world.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sleep less, run more. Get out and feel the sun's warmth or lack of sun's coolness on your skin. You <em>will</em> have the weekend to sleep (or at worst the weekend after that); use that knowledge as an anchor to do more now.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Work hard; own stuff. Be proud and be proactive. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Salute the sun and remember why you chose this path. The people make a dramatic difference. Smile openly, love warmly. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This is a key to working well with diverse people with very different working styles. Study them, wish them well, love them for their humanity, side on them to convince them (read: make them feel they’re invested or accountable somewhat of your goals) of your needs.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Oh and also: through this cycle... genuine relationships will be built. Integrity will be more easily kept meaning honesty and consistency of what you say and your respective actions.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Start with this. Get people on your side. Instead of "being so good they can't ignore you." That, will come later.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Even small things like saying good morning and thank you, cheerily </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>😁</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I do.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Kids in a sense, acting as how some script told us adults should play.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Don’t let it go</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There is magic in your words; choose them carefully. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are gazes from future generations upon your movements; are you proud of them?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Your future is sculpted by your thoughts; your thoughts shaped with Aeolus' power from where you choose to spend your time - what you read, who you speak with, what you hear.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Don't give yourself all away. Focus on what matters to you. And consequently command respect from this self-efficacy. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(In the first step, it's often helpful to speak to a mentor as a sounding board and a guide to structure what you want.)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Then speak loudly to the world. Tell the world what you want. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And you will get it. Plus people will regard you as a confident go-getter</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Consolidating a list of my go-to's... for daily effective and efficient energy bursts while at home, at a hotel, wherever.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If I am working out 1x/~2 days, I'll do a <strong>leg + arm workout + stretch</strong>. Otherwise if I'm working out 1x/day, I'll do a <strong>leg OR arm workout + core + stretch</strong>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Dumbbell workouts:</strong></p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source: <a href="https://fs.blog/knowledge-project/john-maxwell/">John Maxwell</a> from the knowledge project podcast</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li><strong>Work in a new place</strong><ul><li>In the past, I'd work at a new spot at a library or move to a coffee shop. Now, when I'm in a productivity block, I'll relocate to another room of the house. I'm currently writing outside on the balcony. </li></ul></li><li><strong>Have a "flow" playlist</strong><ul><li>In the past, I downloaded a playlist (~1.5hrs) of music for different tasks. These ranged from workouts, test studying, homework, to personal projects. </li><li>I downloaded these to play from my iTunes account so there wouldn't be interruptions from ads. </li><li>The repetition of the same playlists helped me immediately get into the flow of what I was to do. My body and mind built the pattern recognition. </li><li>They were also a great tracking of time... I could finish a few reps of a playlist and understand I worked for that many times the duration of the playlist. Or I could tell myself to work until the current playlist finished before taking a break.</li></ul></li><li><strong>Build off momentum</strong><ul><li>When I am productive because I need to be (i.e. I finished a group meeting or I finished something with a pending deadline), then I'm already in a state that I can push forward in. I remember that feeling in my body and mind to continue in my personal projects.</li></ul></li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Interesting that these "productivity" spurs I've learned and used in high school / college are things that I'm continuing during this remote working time.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Per a friend's verbiage, we have become closer in touch with our <em>pre-college selves</em>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And it's still not being written. I think perhaps I'm afraid to put words that can't justify the vibrant video of real life. I think perhaps I'm still somewhat afraid to put my full heart down, because perhaps, it's a healthier relationship to live in a reality we're constantly working on instead of a rosy colored standstill picture. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And being afraid, isn't always a bad thing. I think it's like stress... there's a gradient with a X and a Y-axis and an interval within that that represents optimal benefit.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<p>My body fits into his like a mold had been created for us to grow into<br>The top of mine is snug in the bottom of his<br>After all, how many bodies can cuddle and walk at the same time?<br><em>Shoulder</em></p>

<p>I remember when the passerby says, "<em>You kids must really be in love... I can tell by the way he's looking at you</em>"<br>As we're waiting for our take-out of beef tendon noodle soup to eat under the moonlit Champaign pond, and the soup is just tendon pieces<br>When his mom says, "<em>Stop acting so weird</em>", at lunch and you're just staring at me! <br>And the thousands of times no one has said anything, but you've unknowingly said everything<br>I never want to lose these<br><em>Eyes</em></p>

<p>They say the most sexy parts are those that we can't see, that are hidden to the public eye<br>That tantalizing allurement, SEXINESS when it grows and grows<br>I can't tell what's bigger, this or your heart<br>It's usually your heart ;)<br><em>Brain</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You strum the strings to a serenade in front of our friends around the sideyard bonfire<br>I pass by, our eyes lock, and my heart explodes.<br>You hoist me up onto the roof where we look out to a clear sky<br>There's something in the young, carefree air, besides the fish we have on the grill.<br>You carry me on your back when my knee's in pain, before the early morning you're sitting on the floor of a Walgreens fitting a brace you insist I wear<br>It's a reoccurring feeling - I'm the luckiest girl alive.<br>Intertwined, from that very first time we "met" to the time we walk in sync like toy soldiers to the time I'm falling apart to the infinite times evermore<br>I feel home<br><em>Hands</em><br><br>You're cute and delightful<br>Also strong and drive me mad<br><em>You guessed it, penis</em>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When I write down things* “to-do”, I’m more likely to procrastinate on it and not want to do it.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If possible, <strong>just doing something I need to do</strong> (and not writing it down) helps me get things done and build momentum to do more.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>“Imagine a world in which you wake up in the morning and you’re excited. There’s nothing special about the day in particular. You’re not about to go on vacation. It’s not your birthday. <strong>It’s just another day ... yet you’re excited. </strong>You can’t wait to get out of bed.”</p>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Break ups are healthy. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Each time J and I have broken up, we’d come back stronger together. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Early in our relationship (strangely), we agreed rationally that break-ups would lead to win-win scenarios. We wouldn’t immediately date other people, but if/when we did: if we realize the other people are better for me or him, then that’s a win (because we want to optimize happiness for each other), or if we realize we’re the best for each other, then that’s a win too (and we become more appreciative of each other). Perhaps we both had the self-efficacy to know that if we weren’t dating each other, long-term, we’d be happy with someone else. Time is just the factor there. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I remember once I mentioned to friends that J and I had broken up before. One who was in a long term (since secondary school!) relationship looked at me astounded. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Perhaps the taboo against breakups stems from an emotional place.... and some couples are incredibly great without ever breaking up. A time-withstanding relationship requires a healthy blend of emotion and logic. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When we’re apart, it’s empowering to know I’m okay. And we’re healthier together when we’re not completely reliant on each other. (BTW when we’re apart, I also feel terrible.)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Then again, what even are break-ups?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>https://www.instyle.com/celebrity/gigi-hadid-zayn-malik-on-off-relationship-success</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^This article articulates resonating thoughts:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>1) Coming back together requires addressing underlying issues and individual growth / change</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>2) Toxic on-and-offs are to be avoided!!! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>3) You can love someone without actively dating them</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li><a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://slideplayer.com/slide/4537744/" target="_blank"><strong>Comparative advantage</strong></a><br>This factors in <a rel="noreferrer noopener" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x-hYzRncxTc" target="_blank">opportunity cost</a> to deciding what I think myself and others should do to be net most efficient / productive. </li><li><strong><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GnaSEfCNDHU" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Marginal benefit </a></strong><br>This helps me with prioritization. Are there things that I can capture more benefit from that I should be spending my time on? (<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zPoA6dzKmtg" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">80-20 rule</a>*) </li><li><strong>Optimization</strong><br>I think high school economics gave me the initial frameworks to think of optimization (i.e. <a href="https://www.khanacademy.org/economics-finance-domain/ap-microeconomics/ap-consumer-producer-surplus/socially-efficient-and-inefficient-market-outcomes/v/socially-efficient-and-inefficient-outcomes" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">allocative efficiency </a>where there is minimal space in the triangle between supply, demand, price, and quantity). Since then, I pursued a degree in college studying Industrial Engineering with a secondary field in Economics &amp; Finance, because I was obsessed with optimization - a concept that just "makes sense" in my mind. My college courses provided numerous new tools and frameworks to think about optimization - which is closely tied to decision-making and shapes the way I make every day decisions. <br><br>*Acknowledging that some things require 100 not 80 to be world-class which is a value proposition on its own</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<p>Storytelling is a distortion of time</p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>BTW here’s a leadership trait I admire: sharing stories</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Why: this leads to funner environments and better connection</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How I’ll get better at it: work towards preparing and sharing 1 short story every day- whether to family or more likely to a work forum </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As a teammate, first <strong>do good work</strong>, this will <strong>build trust</strong> in your work from your leaders, which will in turn <strong>build autonomy</strong>, which will in turn <strong>build empowerment</strong>, <strong>satisfaction</strong>, <strong>motivation</strong>, and <strong>safety</strong> to do good / better work.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As a leader in a team, do the same as a teammate. Lead by example. Be decisive and respectful. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>At me</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This helps people value and look forward to the chat as much as you. And it helps them start to structure thoughts so you’ll get better conversation during the chat. </p>

<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I do feel good though when:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I've had 7.5 hrs of sleep</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I meditate 2x / day for 5 min each</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I go on 1 ~8 mile bike ride during the work day -this increases my happiness and productivity (and even confidence in meetings) more than anything! On productivity, this bike ride gets me kick start to do more / better in other things.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I eat fruit and veggies instead of sugary snacks and simple sugars</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I get a ~30 min workout in :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I write something </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I have a meaningful ~10 min+  call in with someone</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Why:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>It trains our mind to think more into what parts of what someone is saying that I agree with ("Yes" part). I will also listen more instead of what is being said instead of anchoring / waiting to respond with what's top of my mind.</li><li>It helps people agree more easily with what I would say after the "and" part, since I start with agreeing with them.</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are 2 phases requiring 2 mindsets:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>1. Creation - writing a post</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>2. Refinement - polishing a post</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Make space for both phases at different times to build something excellent. Because trying to do both at the same time leads to inefficiency in mindset shifting and a potential sacrifice in quality. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Reactions and actions in times of stress define one’s character and subsequently, reputation. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Power of leverage</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>and networks!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I'm appreciative of all I've learned as I move forwards. Of the people around me. Of making the most of this current time. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Because there's a balance between pausing to smell the roses along the way and pushing forward to get somewhere faster to smell the flowers others who've paused too much may not get to smell.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Actually, I'm happy with my balance. Perhaps I ought just to be more appreciative of the present - in the perspective of that I may not get something like this again - when I'm living in the present.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Breathe breathe breathe.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Otherwise we’ll live our lives based off of others’ intentions... leading to a sort of unconsciousness for ourselves and less satisfaction in our lives. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^one of the biggest things I learned from my NY study</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Because only through failure will you learn and grow</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>During then (when we’re not meditating and focusing directly on our minds), Pay attention to body and speech instead of mind itself. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This is a practice of being more aware of our actions will help us become more self aware of our minds. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The body reflects the mind. Just as the mind reflects the body. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Example of actions to pay attention to: slamming a door, being curt / short in speech, throwing a ping pong paddle. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source of insight: Headspace</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Knowing the room early on and who's in there, and having specific connections / "friends" already in the group improves my personal <strong>confidence </strong>and <strong>comfortability</strong> when the group fills in at time.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Because people aren't always sure of what they're saying</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And when we push back at the right time (when we have a good point / consideration, beyond just saying yes to whatever they're saying - which btw they may be used to from their peers or "subordinates") in a way to show that we're solving for the best answer, then it builds trust between speaker and push backer.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When we push back in the right way, it can show we're confident, trust-worthy people with expertise.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Experiences in food from personal examples:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>1) adding a splash of oat milk to black coffee</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>- previous thinking: oat milk is high in calories compared to almond milk or no milk... (90 cal / cup vs 45 cal / cup vs 0 cal)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>-  new thinking: the experience is SO good and absolutely delightful, a minor caloric splurge (that dwarves in comparison to other caloric splurges) worth it. Also 80-20 rule... meaning I should focus on the larger caloric splurges than the smaller ones, and to evaluate per input (calories) and output  (perceived personal experience improvement) ratios </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>2) keeping some fat on meat when cooking </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>- previous thinking: “fat = bad” because it’ll clog my arteries, be full of calories, and more</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>- post learning: a bit of fat makes me feel fuller longer and more satisfied with my meal (versus before I may have ate more of other foods to try and hit that satisfaction feeling... leading to more net calories and often not being as satisfied), also cooking with a bit of fat makes the whole meat more tender / juicier which also improves the meal experience  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>3) adding a dash of salt and olive oil to veggies, eggs, etc! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>- previous thinking: “salt = bad” because it can cause bloating, increase blood pressure and lead to other health problems, and I didn’t like when foods actually tasted salty</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>- post learning: a bit of salt usually doesn’t mean a salty taste in foods, instead it amplifies the natural flavor of the food itself! Also compared to the salt content of the salty foods I negatively associated salt with (these were predominantly dishes when I ate out), the amount of salt I add to my foods are a shockingly small fraction to how much salt there is in those processed and (many) restaurant foods. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>4) adding SPICES to food!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>- previous thinking: i) lack of knowledge that a little bit of spices can make a big taste difference - usually for the better and to add diversity, ii) lack of experience of using spices... so limited understanding which to use, which to buy, etc. iii) lack of understanding of health implications to spices (previous thinking was that flavors were added with sauces and things that weren’t “healthy”, thus adding spices may be “unhealthy” in a way since their purpose is to add flavor too) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>- post learning: spices are incredible!!!!!! Standard salt and pepper is incredible too. Food from farmers markets are the best - first is to get good food, then relatively fresh spices / herbs / etc that round out a dish into a satisfying, flavorful meal :) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Multiple times! With J as eye witness for once, and 2 others as eye witness for the other times. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>6 months ago, I started with the (not incredibly strong, but semi-persistent) intention to do a handstand. I’m still not where I want to be... in holding a handstand and exiting it safely, but I’ve made awesome progress with freestanding headstands! 6 months ago, I could not do either.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Handstand = inversion balanced on hands</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Headstand = inversion balanced on head (center of gravity closer to the ground and more stable) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Yay!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tFxQbPYe_ZA </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Thoughts and aspirations</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>So perhaps, it’s important to learn about bouncing back from those negative experiences? Since we all have them!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I just know there's nothing better to do but make the most of being inside and working / reading / etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But once you do, you find others who do it to. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ex, LFO to Europe when you’re on a coast to coast study </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ex, backpacking while living in seattle</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ex, co-living with friends in a house somewhere gorgeous during covid </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And once you find others who are doing it (things you want to do, things you think are fun but kind of out there, things that are hard to make the plunge), then you wonder why you haven’t been doing it all along. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<p>San Francisco (mostly Nob Hill) Nov 2020</p>

<p>And it's still not being written. I think perhaps I'm afraid to put words that can't justify the vibrant video of real life. I think perhaps I'm still somewhat afraid to put my full heart down, because perhaps, it's a healthier relationship to live in a reality we're constantly working on instead of a rosy colored standstill picture. </p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My body fits into his like a mold had been created for us to grow into<br>The top of mine is snug in the bottom of his<br>After all, how many bodies can cuddle and walk at the same time?<br><em>Shoulder</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I remember when the passerby says, "<em>You kids must really be in love... I can tell by the way he's looking at you</em>"<br>As we're waiting for our take-out of beef tendon noodle soup to eat under the moonlit Champaign pond, and the soup is just tendon pieces<br>When his mom says, "<em>Stop acting so weird</em>", at lunch and you're just staring at me! <br>And the thousands of times no one has said anything, but you've unknowingly said everything<br>I never want to lose these<br><em>Eyes</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It's hot when you align the things you say with the things you do<br>and damn I like to kiss this<br><em>Mouth</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>They say the most sexy parts are those that we can't see, that are hidden to the public eye<br>That tantalizing allurement, SEXINESS when it grows and grows<br>I can't tell what's bigger, this or your heart<br>It's usually your heart ;)<br><em>Brain</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You strum the strings to a serenade in front of our friends around the sideyard bonfire<br>I pass by, our eyes lock, and my heart explodes.<br>You hoist me up onto the roof where we look out to a clear sky<br>There's something in the young, carefree air, besides the fish we have on the grill.<br>You carry me on your back when my knee's in pain, before the early morning you're sitting on the floor of a Walgreens fitting a brace you insist I wear<br>It's a reoccurring feeling - I'm the luckiest girl alive.<br>Intertwined, from that very first time we "met" to the time we walk in sync like toy soldiers to the time I'm falling apart to the infinite times evermore<br>I feel home<br><em>Hands</em><br><br>You're cute and delightful<br>Also strong and drive me mad<br><em>You guessed it, ;)</em>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Just love when people are grateful</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>source: Pedigree book</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Is to stop taking personal calls during the day at a time that's not good for me.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Examples from 2020: catch up with a past EM, answering a phone call from mom, when a middle school friend reaches out to chat. In the moment, I try to schedule the meetings in my day (close to the time someone reaches out to me) so I don't need to do it later (mental overhead and I may forget), but the current time may not work best for me... I may be tired, stressed because I have pressing work, overall just not in the right headspace. And this ends up being a lose-lose... For me, I'm not alert and can come off the way I feel. For the other person, they may not feel good talking to me.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>A Little History of Economics by Niall Kishtainy</li><li>Misbehaving by Richard Thaler </li><li>The Psychology of Money by Morgan Housel </li><li>Attached by Amir Levine and Rachel Heller  <em>- mostly done... I think the main points of this could've been summarized quicker, and the specific example stories weren't extremely helpful for improving my current relationship</em></li><li>The Book of Human Emotions by Tiffany Smith</li></ol>
