<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Thing in life, phrased learned from Dominion card game</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>“Doing things other people aren’t willing to do... what happens is, you convince your mind: because I’m doing things other people aren’t willing to do, I deserve to get stuff other people don’t deserve to get.”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ex: hard work ethic </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source: <a href="https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/capital-university/id1533783270?i=1000496499431">podcast with Ed Mylett on Capital University </a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>So stop feeling bad about anything too long! &lt;3 </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>what a wise woman Barbara Corcoran</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Prioritize learning :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Mindset on building products</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source: SVPG product workshop, quote from Microsoft perhaps</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Pace: To speak with authority, use crisp, succinct, and declarative sentences.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And don’t be afraid of silences. Taking a moment to think before you speak is more powerful than rambling. <strong>Also watch out for filler words or phrases, such as um, like, or you know. These smack of inexperience.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also maybe lower tone. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Energy is the third tool in the AWE toolkit. It’s the quality that sets AWE into motion. Authority earns you respect. Warmth wins you trust. Energy motivates people to follow you.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Energy combines conviction in your message with enthusiasm. If you believe deeply in what you’re saying, your audience will be swayed to agree with you. But this only happens if you’re present, fully engaged in the moment, and authentic.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>a warm person without energy won’t win people’s confidence. For instance, a kind and caring employee with flat energy will be passed over when promotions are handed out. She won’t be seen as management material. Managers must motivate and persuade their teams, so energy is a crucial quality for them. Being liked by everyone isn’t enough. You must be able to inspire others to follow you.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Kind of need to understand this myself more:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Someone with true authority has the confidence to step back and let other people form their opinions. Don’t undermine your sense of presence by laboring to convince others that your agenda is worthwhile. This will make you seem needy and weak. Instead, state your case clearly. Then, give your audience space to decide for themselves. This way, you’ll exude authority, whether you’re in a job interview, or pitching a campaign to a client.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>New page: authoritative leaders inspire their team to work together toward a shared goal. This style of leadership fosters creativity, commitment, and ingenuity – assets to any team. It also increases staff retention, because employees feel supported and valued.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source: Blinkist on “Don’t take yes for an answer”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And its a choice we get to make each and every day.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Treat people fairly for them to be successful.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>More wisdom:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>"In the virtual world, small investments in demonstrating that you’re authentically interested in the relationship and the person, not just the task, are even more important."</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>"When expectations are not explicit we should not be surprised when they are not met the way we expect them to be."</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>"Assertiveness is the balance between being confident and courageous to say what needs to be said while showing the empathy and respect for the other person."</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Lead with empathy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Side thought for me to practice:</em> incorporate more curiosity than criticism in approaching my romantic relationship.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Dear girl, you only have this one brief, beautiful life. No matter what you do, no matter how big you choose to dream, the same amount of time will pass.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Expect a lot, deliver a lot. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Choose love.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>All the inspirational leaders at McK say the same thing: YOLO. This work place is special in many ways. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I'm appreciative of McK's:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Dedication to learning, dedication to our individualized personal growth journeys.... aligns with their incentives... more spikes is more ways we can deliver client impact.</li><li>Thoughtful, creative, hard-working, values-driven, intelligent, kind people.</li><li>I feel there is near infinite access to opportunity. I have the autonomy (or a different word about being able to make choices?) to work on near anything I want to.</li><li>Maybe this will be fun for 2 more years. There's much to learn!</li><li>I think this will be fun, until the work I do becomes work I do not enjoy or want to work on.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Rambling post, but publishing my thoughts in this snapshot of this time! 2/11/21 </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Part of how habits are built </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Evolution of Love (poem)</li><li>Words I'll Remove From My Vocabulary</li><li>Phrases I'll Add To My Vocabulary</li><li>Virtual Working Tips - part 1: Actually Fun Virtual Team Events</li><li>My Superpower</li><li>Structured Financial Investments Plan </li><li>Structured Relationship Plan</li><li>Habits I'm Building, Habits I'm Grateful to Have Built, February 2021</li><li>Observations from a pre-Covid Kat on a Covid-time Kat</li><li>Post-contracting-Covid check-in</li><li>Love in the Time of Covid </li><li>My Leadership Narrative (AKA This World is Our Oyster)</li><li>Remote Group Living Playbook</li><li>Maximizing 2 Years, so that Business School is my Opportunity Cost</li><li>Personal Guidelines on Starting My Own Project</li><li>Personal Curated Learning for 2021</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Wisdom nugget 1:</strong> "The Old Testament calls a spouse an <em>allup</em>, a Hebrew word meaning <em>best friend</em>."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Wisdom nugget 2:</strong> "A friend, according to the Book of Proverbs, is constant – she “loves at all times.” More importantly, though, friends improve each other. A friend criticizes you when you go wrong, but, like a surgeon, her cuts heal rather than wound."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Wisdom nugget 3:</strong> "Holding one another accountable and provoking love and goodness, we read in Hebrews, is at the heart of what it means to be a Christian."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Wisdom nugget 4: </strong>"For Christians, mutual self-improvement provides a common vision which can unify a couple. A marriage based only on attraction, by contrast, doesn’t provide such stability. Physical attractiveness, after all, changes over time, but this ideal is eternal."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Context:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Yesterday was Valentine's Day, a day great for reflecting on the romantic relationships in our lives. I've been dating the same person for 4+ years now. My significant other (SO) and I are both 24, meaning we get all the wonderful uncertainties in life that come as a given with being in our 20s and blindly figuring out what we want. This article provides a perspective on navigating a long-term relationship among the uncertainty.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Philosophy:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I subscribe to a view of a relationship between 2 people existing as a separate, living entity. There is person A, person B, and the relationship between person A and B. The relationship needs to be maintained and cared for, and a "poor relationship" is not necessarily indicative of the "good" or "bad"-ness of person A or person B.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"align":"center"} -->
<div class="wp-block-image"><figure class="aligncenter"><img src="https://kathleenwritings.files.wordpress.com/2021/02/1614a-1vowwp4y2kvhcpizy7t9mmg.jpeg" alt="Image for post" /><figcaption>The relationship between Person A and B is its own entity<br />Image source: <a href="https://medium.com/@NataliMorad/on-relationships-part-1-of-2-building-stronger-relationships-and-the-third-entity-143f9e3acb19" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Building Stronger Relationships and The Third Entity</a></figcaption></figure></div>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My optimization-craving brain loves to create systems to run certain parts of my life on a "default auto-pilot mode" in order to maximize my focused energy on important things that are more difficult to create systems for. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Below is a potential structured plan (some tactical systems, some abstract guiding principles) to promote a healthy, long-term relationship! Most can be done virtually or in person. Feel free to try some, all, or none of these in your own meaningful relationships.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li><strong>Establish that both person A and person B <em>want </em>to prioritize the relationship</strong> and mutually agree to put in the effort to work on it. The rest of the list do not apply if both parties are not mutually invested in the relationship.</li><li><strong>Learn each other's values.</strong> Although this can be initially discussed with words, it is more important to observe your own and your SO's actions. Learn and communicate if there are any deal-breaker values to each person. </li><li><strong>Understand each other's upper and lower thresholds </strong>for fundamental issues where there may be a mismatch in individual need or if a sweet spot can be identified. An example from our relationship was a mismatch in attention and communication needs. For me, I generally need more attention and communication from my SO - too little and I feel I'm not thought about enough, I feel less loved. Jordan on the other hand, operates contently with less attention / communication - if I ask for too much, he'd feel stifled. To find a happy operating model here, we focused on listing specifically what our limiting bounds meant (e.g., my lower bound asks my SO to have some sort of communication everyday, plan an activity for us every month, celebrate thoughtfully special occasions like birthdays, special holidays). See <em>Appendix A</em> for graphical illustration of finding relationship sweet spots with individual upper and lower bounds.</li><li><strong>Conflict prevention:</strong> Be in tune with yourself and your SO.<strong> </strong>Recognize when you or your partner start feeling agitated (ex: Has the tone of your voice changed? Are you less patient and more combative? Are you taking shorter breaths?). Most times in Jordan and I's relationship, one or both of us are hungry, tired, or stressed by external factors. If that's the case, we try to communicate our state with to each other - it's easier to be understanding of human conditions - instead of the common default to believing the conflict is directly instigated by person A or person B. A phrase that works well here: "<em>I'm feeling upset. Can we please talk more about this later when I'm more level-headed and have had some time to think about it?</em>" Diffusing arguments before they get intensely heated is efficient, because from my experiences, it is <em>much </em>more difficult (and an overall worse experience) to resolve arguments after an intensity tipping point than altogether preventing them. See <em>Appendix B </em>for an illustration on this concept. </li><li><strong>Conflict resolution: </strong>Apologize first. Admit where you are wrong (this is hard!). Hug it out if possible. Soon after, diagnose collaboratively on the sources of conflict and potential steps to try preventing future similar situations.</li><li><strong>Communicating criticism:</strong> Make sure the intent comes from a good place and the actual execution is conveyed with genuine curiosity instead of accusation (e.g., "<em>I observed X. I was wondering why you do that?</em>", "<em>My assumption in X situation was Q. Do you think that's the case?</em>", "<em>I felt Y when Z happened.</em> <em>I'd love to dig deeper with you on this.</em>"). In addition, decide on a communication style for feedback. Does each person prefer in the moment feedback or having a set intentional space for feedback? If your SO is not in an open-to-feedback mental state,  then there is no point in sharing your words then.</li><li><strong>Draft a relationship cruft document </strong>together every few years. The goal is the write down everything that you think you and your SO can improve on. Make a Google Doc to collaborate on ideas for each person. This thoughtful list will be a written documentation to track all the issues that may be helpful to work on. It may not be possible to work on everything at one time, so the list is also a great discussion tool to help facilitate a joint prioritization discussion on which issues each person should work on first. See <em>Appendix C<strong> </strong></em>for an example format.<ul><li>Develop a habit to generously give real-time praise to your SO behavior improvements. Behavior and habit changes are not binary (all or nothing). Acknowledge when any action in the right step is taken to support the general upward trend of progress. Give room for "failure" - it's human. Actual failure is when someone decides to no longer try. To geek out a little bit even more, if this concept was displayed on a graph, each action from your SO (or yourself) is a data point, with the X-axis being time, Y-axis being action result. There will be days where the data point's result is lower than previous days. But overall if we were to do a regression over enough time, the slope should be positive. See<em> Appendix D</em> for an example graph with a positive line of best fit.</li></ul></li><li><strong>Develop a bi-weekly gratitude breakfast.</strong> Pick a morning every 2 weeks (weekend mornings work best!) to each say and listen to 3 things you appreciate about the other. Do this over delicious breakfast. </li><li><strong>Set a weekly retro during times of large life changes </strong>to quickly calibrate what systems work best for the new situation. For example, the first time we moved in together, we set 30 minutes every Sunday evening to discuss what went well that week and what could be changed. This intentional time for relationship communication helped us confidently navigate the life change. </li><li><strong>Debate with "Debate Sheets." </strong>Jordan and I often have contentious in-the-moment discussions (e.g., is there currently macro level inflation in the US?, is international development worth the corresponding negative ramifications?, etc.) that we'd start to take personally, because we are both stubborn and like to be right. When we initially debate live in the moment, we don't know if the data points the other person vaguely cite have any credibility nor do we have certainty of our own. Thus, we started to write "Debate Sheets." Whenever a live debate starts to become upsetting to one another, we will move the debate online to be researched more thoroughly before resuming live later. We have a Google Drive Folder titled "The Great Debate" with Debate Sheet documents titled along the like of "Market Crashes" and "Philosophical Dilemma of Helping." Through this format, we learn about the world in a more accurate way (cited with articles for example), we have the space and time to better articulate and structure our argument, and can easily comment on specific points the other makes. If needed, we can also get a neutral third party to weigh in. We found in many discussions that there is space for both of us to be right; a productive debate is often a matter of defining the conditions in which each argument is valid. </li><li><strong>Discuss finances transparently. </strong>What is your financial philosophy? What is your financial situation? What are your financial goals? </li><li><strong>Make time for friends. </strong>Friendships are among the most important aspects of our 20s. Encourage each other to be independent people with independent friends, and also be able to have friends together and be friendly with each others' friends. Seek feedback from close friends you trust on if you are being too couple-y or showing too much PDA in group situations.</li><li><strong>Meditate most days. </strong>Think intentionally about becoming a better person - it'll help make you a better person for your interactions with your partner too! </li><li><strong>Choose love every day. </strong>View your partner as an evolving beautiful case study (as every separate human being is!) and view your job as his / her devoted researcher. Learn about your partner's interests and passions. Be present in interactions. Listen with authentic intent and curiosity. </li><li><strong>Revisit plan every 4-6 months</strong> to see what is working and what can be improved.</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>+ a few Covid-relevant items:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol id="block-64ea64d2-1cae-4d74-a0f8-88b7de4ed50f"><li><strong>Covid Situation I: <em>spending substantially more time together in a shared space</em></strong><ul><li>Establish physical personal space spots. This can be your own room or even a corner of a shared room set up with a couch cushion. </li></ul></li><li><strong>Covid Situation II: <em>long-distance relationship </em></strong><ul><li>Communicate everyday - we have technology today that makes this easier than ever (e.g., text, video chat, phone call, send video / voice / photo messages, etc.).</li><li>Establish a time threshold for physical visits. Our time threshold is visiting each other 1x / 2 months. </li></ul></li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Conclusion:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Jordan and I's relationship is nowhere near perfect. We are both individuals with a high degree of change and minimal stability in life plans. Geographically while we've been dating, we've lived mostly in the same city during college (I also lived in Seattle and Boulder for 3-4 months each) and then moved to San Francisco in 2019. Within the last year, Jordan moved from San Francisco to Austin. Within the last year, I have moved from San Francisco to Chicago, Okoboji (Iowa), Seattle, Monterey, San Diego... </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Jordan's career ambitions have dabbled from chemical engineer, musician, software engineer at a big tech company, early team member at a startup, real estate agent, real estate investor, to more. My career ambition includes living abroad for multiple years - helping impactful companies scale their international operations in Asia and / or Africa. Writing this out now, I can see how this seems like the odds are stacked against us. But I've never thought that - instead I see change as a welcome, comforting constant. Perhaps that's part of the beauty and fun of being 24 and in love.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sincerely,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Kat Hu</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>P.S. I have no idea what other relationships are like among persons A and B where neither A or B are me. This relationship plan was created from my personal experience and will not fit to every relationships' needs. Again, feel free to take and try anything, everything, or nothing!</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>Appendix A: Level of Attention and Direct Communication Needs</em> -<em> Individual Bounds and Relationship Sweetspot</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"align":"center","width":770,"height":577} -->
<div class="wp-block-image"><figure class="aligncenter is-resized"><img src="https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0?ui=2&amp;ik=c84201c8e7&amp;attid=0.1.1&amp;permmsgid=msg-f:1691878512182152558&amp;th=177ac28af9bbcd6e&amp;view=fimg&amp;sz=s0-l75-ft&amp;attbid=ANGjdJ-RnnjyPVGb3lf8p0G3PexKH3J83vg-UFMiwsUy74pelVVFDD9ZJmbXbRdQSdYMM6mkDSmpHn0UE_3D8ZTLwlM_YwPWpxzVwHobYgPSN1FZveu-0evZe65B7D0&amp;disp=emb" alt="" width="770" height="577" /><figcaption>Illustration of Attention and Communication Needs, assumes amount given / received are equivalent</figcaption></figure></div>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>Appendix B: Anatomy of the Common Argument</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"align":"center"} -->
<div class="wp-block-image"><figure class="aligncenter"><img src="https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0?ui=2&amp;ik=c84201c8e7&amp;attid=0.1.1&amp;permmsgid=msg-f:1691888024876623222&amp;th=177acb31d2822576&amp;view=fimg&amp;sz=s0-l75-ft&amp;attbid=ANGjdJ8IwW0AFNZNPJC7DLdNC4JZh2mP3ZAvXtfklFVZX9mmHSCZ5-Zn-HtKeprFn877oXfRpbvbaShFDEgTe6jRVxlcNMhjEcBSwFFT6s12ghlNsAJo9sGWwdaejPo&amp;disp=emb" alt="" /><figcaption>Take Path B! Diffuse the argument before it becomes increasingly intense and emotion-fueled.</figcaption></figure></div>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>Appendix C: Example Format for Cruft Doc</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"align":"center","id":2638,"sizeSlug":"large","linkDestination":"none"} -->
<div class="wp-block-image"><figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img src="https://kathleenwritings.files.wordpress.com/2021/02/image-3.png?w=975" alt="" class="wp-image-2638" /><figcaption>Real J+K relationship cruft intro</figcaption></figure></div>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>Appendix D: Positive Line of Best Fi</em></strong><em><strong>t Graph for Behavior Change Expectations</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"align":"center"} -->
<div class="wp-block-image"><figure class="aligncenter"><img src="https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0?ui=2&amp;ik=c84201c8e7&amp;attid=0.1&amp;permmsgid=msg-a:r500528683729891384&amp;th=177acc0c9606a85f&amp;view=fimg&amp;sz=s0-l75-ft&amp;attbid=ANGjdJ_MNP9NVqqqrBb3VQet1Ws5t2Fq6OXMGWuDV1Ssvt9r-dx6USAkRSJldyvgLDTTju6rUjuyDcY70HjmZr2tltWHXo6HSINv9ozG5Cj5unn-RE-ZRyq9hSBVQjM&amp;disp=emb&amp;realattid=177acc0b447231511e91" alt="" /><figcaption>It's ok to not have 100% positive behavior change immediately, so long the overall trend is positive.</figcaption></figure></div>
<!-- /wp:image -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>I have incredible women (and men) mentors who give me real, INCREDIBLE, actionable advice that I feel would propel my career by bounds.<ol><li>Women often are more real, empathetic, relatable, close with me.</li><li>The advice addresses deeper fundamental levels of why which create the mindset shifts needed to sustain habit changes. </li></ol></li><li>I see myself growing into their advice, living it and experiencing its' benefits. I see myself becoming that mentor to other people (again mostly other women who've been in my shoes - but perhaps the gender is circumstantial). </li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For those two points, I am beyond thankful.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Goal:</strong> To develop a more confident presence through removing un-serving words and phrases.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true,"type":"1"} -->
<ol type="1"><li>"I think"</li><li>"Um"</li><li>"Uh"</li><li>"Like"</li><li>"I’m not sure"</li><li>"I don’t know"</li><li>"Perhaps"</li><li>"Maybe"</li><li>"Kind of"</li><li>"Just"</li><li>"Somewhat"</li><li>"Wait"</li><li>"Well"</li><li>"And…" (trailing)</li><li>(agreeable chuckle at the end of a sentence)</li><li>"Just thinking out loud" <em>(I think this phrase is useful, but I want to use it less because I currently use it at times I’m not confident about what I’m about to say.)</em></li><li>"Cool"</li><li>"Awesome"</li><li>"That makes sense."</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Building a habit takes 30 days. I've written this list down on a physical piece of paper that I'll keep by my bed and desk to review before bed and on work meetings - so I can be intentional in changing my speech these next 30 days. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:image {"id":2745,"sizeSlug":"large"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img src="https://kathleenwritings.files.wordpress.com/2021/02/img_5273.jpg?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-2745" /><figcaption><em>2/19/21 Balboa Park</em></figcaption></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Something I learned from my first McK project. And continue to learn in life. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Experts just have a detailed view of their <em>specific</em> (not full) scope of an industry / sector / company / etc. They also have their own future predictions or recommendations based on their <em>own specific</em> past experiences, risk tolerance, personal risk profiles, etc. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>fundamental attribution error</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Lead with empathy - great mindset habit :) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I lost those eyes. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>An important step includes seeing more of the world. Taking inventory of what all that "can be."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I am grateful. Love outpours me. And life continues.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Aka 42 aka ASCII 42 aka * </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>thoughts: what are the drivers? what does it mean? where are there patterns and connections?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>People I get excited about!!! Excited to work with. That’s such a under-rated element. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Vs lately I had been solving for new topics, random walks, different people and working styles. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>TL , from mom's exp in IB, from my exp in approvals for pm role, etc</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>the ultimate decision makers who are responsible for impt decisions (relating to you, your career) are beyond people who may appear authoritative and act or interact with you a certain way </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Attachment to results = cause of suffering</p>

<p>Thoughts from Exhalation story of The Merchant and the Alchemist’s Gate, from the power of silence, from my recruiting process for secondment</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I don’t understand Twitter, so I use Wordpress to capture my thoughts :) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And the fear is that, once something much better comes along, I’m not so committed to what I initially was doing, but I’m also not free to do the better opportunity. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Time..... singular path! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>From my personal experiences, often times when someone brings up something I did that didn’t make them feel that great, my first response (at least in personal situations more than in professional situations) is to defend my actions and justify why I did it from my perspective. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Also from my personal experiences in those times, when I apologize first instead of starting with my defense, I ameliorate the situation quickly (leading to a win-win for both parties). And there’s always something genuine to apologize for! Say the sorry first, then later mention your intentions and how your intentions weren’t for those negative impacts the other felt. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Correlates with the “give first” mantra. Make it a habit to say Sorry first in some of these situations. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Situation examples where this often applies: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>The other person is someone you really care about</li><li>The topic isn’t that important to you. It doesn’t pass the “Does it really matter?” test when you ask yourself that question</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Thank you to all the organizations who employ me - for trusting me in putting my brain power to work in your impactful, interesting problems.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When I reflect on my life, I can't think of anything more to ask for. Thus, I want to make my life about giving. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I am thankful for the opportunity to work on interesting problems, for the freedom and privilege in being able to divert my time to those problems, for having the sweet spot of having some interesting problems paying better than others - thus affording me the financial freedom (combined with personal discipline) to save enough $ to cover living expenses to also choose to work on interesting problems even when the financial pay out is not as great. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I am thankful for my health, thankful for freedom, thankful for family and solid relationships. I am thankful for flow, for focus, for creation in things I find interesting.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I live a very selfish life. I make sure to take care of myself first. I draw boundaries. I choose fun over financial gain (this may be commonplace in my privileged circle, but it is not the norm in the immigrant culture I grew up in). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Side thought, there are a series of words that I'd apply to myself - where the definition buys me personal fulfillment and freedom, but the connotation of the words are typically not positive. Among these words include: selfish, discipline, frugality, introvert, satisfied.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I've learned that there is no right answer. There is only fun in the search. We're all playing different games. Just don't forget what's truly important to myself.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Since college, I've been constantly in phases feeling: "I cannot believe I get to live like this." When I strip away social media and comparisons to the world, I am happy and grateful for each step along my journey.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>instead, i just went outside and knocked the door to my neighbors' houses. my friends in the neighborhood did the same. brianna came to my door every single day: "can kathleen come out and play?", mostly to my mom response at the door saying: "i'll let her know to find you when she finishes piano practice", but sometimes to a successful outcome of me grabbing my shoes and running out. our streets were playgrounds and play fields; we used to occupy the roads so our soccer matches could be played. when a car came, there was always someone in charge of yelling "CAR" and we'd move our goal posts and ball to the side and give the acknowledging wave to the car driver. the dragons to be slayed were in melissa's backyard. the fairies to catch were in molly's basement. our forts were never complete without at least 3 different blankets, 2 bedsheets, and 6 chairs or whatever it was we could find to hold up the sheets.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>elementary years were fun; i'm sure they're still just as fun</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>the process, the team, the atmosphere</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>thankful for the opportunities i've had</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>No one else will even be able to completely understand it. The most amazing souls will show up to cheer you along the way, but this is your game. Make a pact to be in it with yourself for the long haul, as your own supportive friend at every step along the way" - Tara Mohr</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>First reflect on who is doing the saying. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Are the achy bone joints<br />Cold shivers<br />Purple lips<br />Headaches<br />Feeling like I’m out of my mind<br />Where is my mind<br />Not being myself<br />Not being able to do things! To plan things. To follow through with plans.<br />The release</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The hours waiting, navigating new hospital systems<br />The majority of my grocery budget spent on yogurt - plain, passionfruit and mango, strawberry, laki laki probiotic drinks</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>—-</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Thankfully, each additional time around, I feel like I also develop a bit more of a community with a few friends who make an effort to help, and time passes and antibiotics go down and I come back up to another version of me.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>In the United States, there is a significant point of contention around Native-American US colleges mascots. There are over 50 on this <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_college_sports_team_names_and_mascots_derived_from_indigenous_peoples">list</a> of US college sports team names / mascots derived from indigenous people. <br><br>From my personal experience, the majority of people who I heard express complaints on team mascots being Native American were not Native American. While it is great to hear so many allies amplify a cause, perhaps the voices of the people representative of the core issues can get sounded out.<br><br>A Native American I spoke with regarding this topic (big flag that this was just <em>one </em>data point) didn't care too much about this topic of contention. He did mention that the Native-American mascots, though not very accurate, could create more visibility on their culture - and without the mascots, then the Native American community could actually lose some valuable recognition, education, and dialog.<br></li><li>In Kenya, there is a controversy regarding "outsider" startup founders. "Outsider" here defined as non-Kenyans. Overall, startups that have been founded by "outsiders" seem to be able to raise venture money more easily and thus perhaps more likely to scale and be a larger success. The controversy goes beyond the unfairness in raising money. Also, when these startups are successful... then more money and power are funneled to the top (the founders), and in these situations where the founders are "outsiders", then there is a perception of A) money being made off the Kenyan market but the wealth is going to non-Kenyans, and B) non-Kenyans become in a position of power to drive decisions on technology products / services that then impact so many Kenyans. One of my expat friends compared this situation to a type of "new colonialism" of the continent. Actually, from my experience living in Kenya so far, everyone who told me about this issue were non-Kenyan citizens.<br><br>Armed with this knowledge and still wanting to start a startup here, I prioritized finding local co-founders. As I expanded my network to more Kenyans in the startup scene here, I also started to learn more about their perspectives on this issue. Below is a summary of their perspective (my data points here are a meager three, so again, I'd like to call-out that this is still not necessarily representative of Kenya's population's perspectives as a whole):</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Wealth and value is still generated for Kenya / Africa. <ul><li>First, these entrepreneurs have to be building something of value for the local market - that's the fundamental reason for their company's growth. This likely means that they are elevating the quality of life for a subset of local people by creating something new that did not previously exist.</li><li>Secondly, as a company grows, it increases employment and skill acquisition for locals. As the entrepreneur scales their company, then their team (assuming the team consists mostly of locals) also acquires skills and money to launch the next generation of innovation after they leave the initial company! The team can learn about launching, running, and scaling a startup with potentially more mature practices brought in from the "outsider" entrepreneur to later use to build their own company.</li></ul></li><li>There is a perspective that "outsiders" are well poised to bring in new ideas of products and services from their experiences living elsewhere - spurring overall more innovation in the local ecosystem. A relevant data point in the US shows that 55% of US unicorns have an immigrant founder, per a <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/stuartanderson/2018/10/25/55-of-americas-billion-dollar-startups-have-immigrant-founder/?sh=1c8ef1d748ee">study </a>in 2018.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>So what does this mean for "outsiders"? As an aspiring "outsider" entrepreneur in a market I'm not native to, here are my thoughts:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Listen to both sides of the controversy (not just the side that you <em>want </em>to hear) and understand where each is coming from - there is validity and truth in both.</li><li>Look closer at <em>who </em>(and if there's a pattern among the who) is saying each side of the story. Perhaps hold the "insider" voices and the voices of people you admire at a higher level of influence in shaping your own perspective.</li><li>Understand your own why! What are your fundamental goals - and what would it mean to your goals if your key decisions were shaped by one stance or the other?</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And in terms of my search for a local co-founder? I've concluded that I should do this because it makes good business sense - not to have a "token" co-founder or to try and avoid controversy. And in the preliminary phase of a startup, it's also valid to hire a local team (cash is often king) instead of necessarily sharing co-founder status right off the bat.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>^ learned from yoga and headstands</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Another thought: life is easier when you are okay with change (and can detach with more peace). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In making joint decisions, my partner and I narrow options based on our preferences. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For example, if we need to decide where to eat out, then one person will give 3 choices of food ethnicities (these 3 are of that person’s preference already). Then the next person will pick the category they want and suggest a few restaurants that fit the constraint. The decision to pick between the remaining options is passed back to the first person. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Another example is movies. When we sit in front of Netflix and try to figure out what to watch, one of us will apply an initial constraint by offering a few select types of movies they’d want to see (e.g., rom com, make you think movies, cult classics, etc.). The next person then works within that constraint and proposes ~3 movies. The first person then chooses the movie. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This process has been efficient for us to make relatively insignificant decisions (for one, they are reversible - e.g., we can start a movie and realize we don’t like it and switch to another one - and for two, they aren’t key dependencies that shape other major life outcomes), especially when we both initially have weak preferences. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When we use this process, we’ve been able to quickly agree on a decision that is optimal enough for both of us. The trade off is worth it. Previously without this process, I’ve felt frustrated trying to decide where to go for dinner - where the <strong>time </strong>to decide takes up mental overhead (not worth an insignificant decision!) and increases the level of my hangriness. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Making a decision between three options is easier than seemingly infinite options. The difference in computation is between validate and search… a measurable cost. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Thoughts inspired by the book <span style="text-decoration:underline;">Algorithms to Live By</span></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image -->
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://media-exp1.licdn.com/dms/image/C4E16AQGSIkMfk88AyQ/profile-displaybackgroundimage-shrink_350_1400/0/1581322294326?e=1643846400&amp;v=beta&amp;t=SdMtmofpw8mScg27oab35cLQl5c7THlRyFJ4-qESqbk" alt="Grayson Kinsella" /></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I’d like to think I don’t care for prestige. That it’s a cookie cutter machine to flush out people tailored a certain way - who are chasing the “wrong” things in my view. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>However, I’ve recently realized that, a huge reason I can afford this mindset is because I have a top consulting firm tied to my name. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Damn, I am so thankful I had McK as an experience in my life. Both for the name association but also for the personal growth it’s brought me. I’ve made some of my best friends literally around the world through McK. I connect immediately with people at work (companies after McK), people in different countries, people who are friends of my friends (<em>list not MECE</em> ;)) and am able to bond over a shared experience working at a top consulting firm. We communicate the same way, we’ve gone through the same programs and the same experiences. There’s a sense of shared <em>understanding</em>. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It’s easier to say I don’t care for prestige when I have some of it. It’s easier for me to live more freely, chase after things relatively free of the prestige consideration, now that I reap the lasting benefits that come with an association. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<p>But dear child, this now being hard makes the futures to come that much easier </p>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>the day charlie left, my dad cut down our fig tree.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>that night, my dad opened the door to our backyard, looking out the same he has every night these last 14 years</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>as i went upstairs to bed, i smelled the burning of an incense stick</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>why, when i think of designing my life with kids, i want to live in a good co-housing community, and why i want my kids to have access to alternative high school <em>options</em> (depending on their specific interests! e.g., academies to study their interest, top boarding schools, uwc, etc.)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sophomore year of college, a friend in my ECE 210 class responded with a flabbergasted "Why?" when he learned I had registered to run a full marathon. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"What do you mean why?" I pushed back.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"Are you going to win the marathon?" he asked. "Why would you play a game that's near impossible to win?"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I knew I couldn't win the marathon; I just wanted to complete it. (Spoiler alert: Fast forward 4 months, I didn't even complete 1km of the actual marathon - my right knee developed patellofemoral pain syndrome aka "runner's knee" from training with incorrect running form and not supportive enough shoes.)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But his words were a stark, new perspective - a <a href="https://www.thefouragreements.com/the-first-agreement/">seed of an idea</a> planted in my mind to ruminate over. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"className":"is-style-dots"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator is-style-dots" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This idea permeates across successful people in our society who've undergone pivots upon realization that they're not suited to win in their current game. <a href="https://www.inc.com/bill-murphy-jr/jeff-bezos-just-revealed-humble-wonderful-guy-who-radically-changed-his-life-34-years-ago-he-never-knew-until-now.html">Jeff Bezos</a>, CEO of Amazon, pivoted his career ambitions from becoming a theoretical physicist after realizing there are people much smarter than him in that field. Another CEO (<em>still trying to find this source</em> <em>- it was a podcast interview</em>) had a similar revelation: he turned down a quant trading job (or was it pivoted from academia?) because he realized he was never going to be as passionate or talented as the top people he saw in those roles.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Entrepreneurship is a game you can win. An entrepreneur spends her time building something that hasn't previously existed, something that she vehemently believes should exist because of the value it would add to the world.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Because the entrepreneur is building something that <em>hasn't previously existed</em>, it's likely that the competitive landscape is relatively nascent. If the entrepreneur continues to focus on her users and adding value to them (and a few other factors), then there's a viable path for the business to "win" a local maxima with potential to scale to win larger and larger maximas. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In addition, the rules of the game are not written. Unlike age-old games like Olympic sports (for example, <a href="https://www.footballhistory.org/">football</a> was invented 3000+ years ago with the rules we know today standardized 100+ years ago) or traditional career paths, entrepreneurship is writing and playing by your own rules. It means innovating your own marketing strategy, developing your own customer acquisition funnel, delighting users with magical moments through your product. It's easier to compete on your own terms than rules that have been studied for generations.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Finally, an entrepreneur has significant ownership. Her input has a direct correlation to the output; the product or service would not exist if not for her. For her business to persist, she must love and be obsessed with what she's doing. And when someone loves what they're doing and is obsessed, then that becomes an immediate unfair advantage towards winning the game.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"className":"is-style-dots"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator is-style-dots" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The next year, the same ECE 210 friend signed up for and ran the full marathon. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>All to say, it may be advantageous to play games you can win with the majority of your time - but you should still spend time on things that you want to do for the sake of it! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>1. Identify the goal</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Example: I want to build a technology product that enables investors to buy bonds from DAOs. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>2. Breakdown to smaller to-do’s to accomplish the goal</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For multiple layered breakdowns, break down goal to workstreams (layer 1), then breakdown those workstreams further (layer 2) to smaller to-do's ("deliverables"). Number of layers depends on scope and complexity of the goal. Generally, 1-3 layers should be sufficient to understand for someone overseeing the project.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Example:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>1st level breakdown of workstreams: Product, Development, Design, Sales / Marketing, Funding / Investor Relations, Recruiting</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>2nd level breakdown - for the product workstream:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Deliverables:<br>a) Create a product spec for investor workflow to buy bonds<br>b) Create a product spec for DAO workflow to post and manage auctions for selling bonds<br>c) Create a product spec smart contracts (underlying technical infrastructure)</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>3rd level breakdown - for a) investor workflow product spec:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>To-do's:<br>i) Talk to 10 potential investor users (sub tasks: develop specific research questions, develop target list of investors to ask, etc.)<br>ii) Fill out each section of a product spec template (ex: user need, detailed requirements, what's out, etc.)</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>3. Plot deliverables to a timeline</strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For a multiple layered breakdown, have the same number of timelines as number of layers. Timelines may not be needed for smaller sub-breakdowns at deeper layers (ex: 3rd level breakdown of to-do's in our example).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The plot of to-do's to a timeline becomes the roadmap.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Example:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>(Kat to add a visual drawing of how this could look from a 1st and 2nd level</em> <em>workstream</em> <em>roadmap)</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em><strong>(4. Execute!)</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Execute, track, and adjust roadmap accordingly when new information comes in.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Things that seemed so grandiose before </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Like publishing a book</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Starting a nonprofit</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Organizing a professional event </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Raising lots of $</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Onwards </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>thought, thing learned... possibly to write more on this?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>and mention how this was something i used to struggle with (coming up with stories) in my story telling class</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>and that knowing this - is a hack to that!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>cuz linearly as time passes, you don't know it'll become a story or part of a story.... the story part comes through reflection.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Something about the serene and immense-ness of being in nature and retaining a sense of control and self-efficacy. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Something about being absolutely present with no way to even care about mundane hubbub. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
