<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>That feeling is addicting as heck!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Interesting perspective that I feel like I've definitely seen this hold true for people in my networks.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:embed {"url":"https://future.a16z.com/equity-compensation-in-tech/","type":"wp-embed","providerNameSlug":"future"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-embed is-type-wp-embed is-provider-future wp-block-embed-future"><div class="wp-block-embed__wrapper">
https://future.a16z.com/equity-compensation-in-tech/
</div></figure>
<!-- /wp:embed -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>things feel more real, here are a few reasons why:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>you have validation (real people <em>chose</em> to join you and your vision / mission)</li><li><span style="color:initial;font-family:-apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, &quot;">you have accountability </span>(real people <em>chose</em> to join you and your vision / mission!)</li><li>you have support to go farther (when you feel like stopping, your team helps you keep going)</li><li>you have better ideas (e.g., 2 people brainstorming together lead to more ideas than sum of ideas if each person was brainstorming on their own)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong>Definitions:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Group 1:</strong> Selector(s) try everything to woo this candidate archetype.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Group 2: </strong>This candidate archetype tries everything to woo selector(s).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>Selector definition:</em> </strong><em>A gatekeeper of entry to a selective organization / program / opportunity</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>Candidate definition:</em> </strong><em>An applicant to the organization / program / opportunity</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"large"} -->
<p class="has-large-font-size"><strong>Observation seen through a series of examples:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>i) College admissions - athletic recruiting</li><li>ii) Executive hiring</li><li>iii) VC funding</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong>i) College admissions - athletic recruiting</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Group 1 example:</strong> my sister's tennis recruiting</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>For context, my sister is a highly competitive high school tennis player. She's consistently ranked top 5 in our state and led her varsity high school team to state (placing 2nd as a freshman and 1st as a junior - there wasn't state as a sophomore due to covid).</li><li>Correspondingly, coaches of top universities (incl those that boast &lt;10% admissions rate) have been actively pursuing her to join their college team.<ul><li>The coaches want her to commit to their school sooner the better. In terms of logistics, this would mean that in the fall of her senior year, she'd apply Early Decision to their school, her profile would be sorted towards a special path for athletic recruits, and the coach would secure her admission to the school.</li><li>In the meantime, the coaches have a very friendly texting relationship with her. They've set up curated multiple-hour-long sessions with her and my parents to provide more details about the school and address any questions. They email her personal updates on the school, the tennis teammates, and other value propositions to hook her interest. They follow-up persistently (but courteously) for her to commit or provide an answer so they know if they should start pursuing the "waitlisted" players behind her.</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Group 2 example:</strong> my personal college application process</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>I was among the regular massive applicant pool in the college application process. I worked hard to try and woo the colleges I wanted to get into - through visiting their campuses, doing in depth research on the college, finding and reaching out to current students to better understand their experience, and setting time to have conversations with the admissions team. On college campus visits or admissions chats, I didn't stand out among the many hundreds (thousands?) of other students who did the same. When I submitted my college applications, it felt like my file was going into a black hole - with no visibility or feedback on my path forward. Even when I was waitlisted at schools I wanted to go to, I would be persistent in updating the generic college admissions email address on my latest achievements, to try and get over the line.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Overall thoughts:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Once you're in, it doesn't matter which path got you in. After that, it just matters what you do with the opportunity you're presented with.</li><li>Getting into Group 1 is a combination of hard work and positioning yourself to increase your chances of "getting lucky." For instance, most of the coaches scouted my sister when she played high-visibility national tournaments. She worked hard to get into a place to play there. However, there probably exist really talented and hard working sports players who don't know about the forums to get noticed. Thus, it's advantageous to combine hard work <em>and</em> knowledge of how to position yourself to be in Group 1.</li><li>You can be in Group 1 and 2 at the same time. This is dependent on selector. For instance, my sister may still end up going through regular applications (Group 2) instead of committing for tennis (Group 1) because her tennis is still not competitive enough for her absolute top choice schools.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong>ii) Company hiring</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Group 1 example:</strong> me after working at McKinsey</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>While I was at McKinsey, I got personal solicitations for cool job opportunities through email and LinkedIn from recruiters. I also got access to awesome job opportunities through emailing lists and group chats. Thus, when I applied to a role, I by-passed the mass applicant pools and had prioritized interview processes. After passing interviews, I felt like I had strong pulls from companies to join - including regular check-ins with exec team members and interesting exclusive information about the company shared, especially in the topics I exhibited interest in - I later learned this is an effective technique in the war for talent called a “drip campaign.”</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Group 2 example:</strong> me trying to get internships as an underclassman in college</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>As a freshman and sophomore in college, I applied to dozens of internships through college job portals, hiring boards, many inbound emails, and lots of printed resumes handed to college fair recruiters.&nbsp;</li><li>I received a similar response to each application: crickets. I ended up getting internships for both summers, but overall got way more rejections than acceptances. Definitely no special treatment in the recruiting process or the “sell” process (where the company really wants you to join after giving you an offer).</li><li>(Later, as a hiring manager at a large tech startup, I totally understand how the hundreds of applicants via online portals are easy to pass on and difficult to deeply view and respond to each application. Also being on the other side of hiring, I kind of “get it” - in terms of what is effective in hiring; that’s another blog post :))</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Overall thoughts:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Group categorization is fluid! The change is a function of time and what an individual does during that time.</li><li>What that means as a selector: life is a long game. Don’t burn bridges or treat people “less than” based on their experiences to date. Where you can, bet on people who show potential but are currently in Group 2; you never know how your actions can impact the rest of their trajectory!</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong>iii) VC funding</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Group 1 example:</strong> my SO with his DeFi startup</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>My SO started working on his own startup a few months ago in the DeFi space.</li><li>In raising money, there was no pitch deck, financial model, business plan. There were just conversations (some even just 15 minutes) hat ended with verbal commitments after exchange of an idea and what the investor could bring to the table. Millions of dollars at a competitive valuation were raised pre-product and pre-team.</li><li>The pre-seed round was still oversubscribed. Highly value-add investors were able to be squeezed in with more space open at even higher valuations. Top name brand VC firms DM him and people refer him to join exclusive founder fellowships / startup opportunities.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Group 2 example:</strong> some peers I know who are building startups</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Their pitch decks, inbound messages, and application submissions to VCs and relevant programs sit among a repository of many others without reply.&nbsp;</li><li>When raising, limited dollars are hard bartered. Some already have a product, signs of early traction, and team.</li><li>*<em>Note</em>: There are numerous factors not detailed here that lead to different situational magnitudes; this is just an overall archetype observation.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Overall thoughts:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>The macro-environment is important. There is an amplifying correlation* between the amount of worldwide demand (and generally correspondingly $) for your industry with the desirability of you.&nbsp;</li><li>Life’s easier when you’re in Group 1 and people want <em>you </em>to join what they’re doing more than how much you want to join <em>them</em>. This leads to the next quick analysis: what qualities make someone be in Group 2?&nbsp;</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>*E.g., if the desirability of you is 2, then an amplifying correlation (say Y which is &gt;1) would be 2*Y. Correspondingly, if the desirability of you is closer to 0, then 0*Y doesn’t help much.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"large"} -->
<p class="has-large-font-size"><strong>Common factors that separate the two groups:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Speciality in a sought after domain<ol><li>There are more opportunities in a domain that’s growing than one that’s stagnant or getting smaller. </li></ol></li><li>Limited supply of candidate profile<ol><li>Mechanics of supply and demand. Strong demand is higher driver, but lower supply is also a contributing factor. </li></ol></li><li>Connection to the right selectors<ol><li>There’s some element of luck in intersecting with selectors. </li></ol><ol><li>Strong people skills are paramount if you’re not an absolute beast (say top 1%) in your domain. Things happen because of people and relations. </li></ol></li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"large"} -->
<p class="has-large-font-size"><strong>Closing thoughts:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Fundamentally, it doesn't matter which candidate group you're in. If you're in Group 2, you can still get in (albeit with more effort) to a selector. Plus, increased effort here due to necessity can breed greater grit and resilience for longer term success.</li><li>If you’re in Group 1, evaluate your selector(s). Are they the people / org / etc. that you actually want? If not, maybe jump into Group 2 for other selector(s). It’s a careful balance though - to get your best case scenario without dropping what you already “have.” Local vs global maxima problem - and knowing when the computational effort to keep searching for a global maxima no longer becomes worth it.</li><li>Everyone has been in Group 2; when candidates start on their journey, the default group is Group 2. With effort and time, they can move to Group 1.</li><li>Inefficiencies exist. Supply and demand is rarely a perfect market among two players. Psychologically, people often want what is harder to get. This is just a nature of the game.&nbsp;</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Current reflection on why I love the kitesurfing community:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>smart people</li><li>who care about the world - incl nature and other people. (beyond what some smart / ambitious people chase in movies or in NYC like money, prestige, power, fame, etc.)</li><li>who are also kind, friendly, accepting, genuine</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I fell in love first with the sport; but the people = huge reason for sticking with something longer term.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Reflecting back on activities / majors / career choices / etc. I've committed to and enjoyed in the past, I see the three qualities above shared through the activities' respective communities. Of the three qualities above, #1 and #3 are always strongest shared themes, while #2's magnitude has a larger acceptable range for me.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In order of recency, with judgements based on my limited personal experiences:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>People who move to <strong>Africa to work at impactful organizations </strong>there <span style="color:initial;font-family:-apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, &quot;">-&gt; <em>Extremely strong in #1, #2, and #3. </em></span></li><li><strong>McKinsey</strong> -&gt; <em>#1 and #3 were definitely strongest common traits in my analyst community. I feel like naturally being in Silicon Valley, there was a greater proportion of people with strong #2s, which I gravitated to more and formed tighter sub-communities with. </em></li><li><strong>Rock climbing</strong> community -&gt; <em>Generally strong in #1, #2, and #3</em></li><li><strong>Biking</strong> people -&gt; <em>Generally strong in #1, #2, and #3</em></li><li>People who shop at <strong>farmers markets</strong> -&gt; <em>Strong #2 and #3, I couldn't judge #1 (but I assume smart in many ways to care for the Earth, local farmers, and food they put into their bodies!)</em></li><li>People who live in <strong>co-ops / co-living</strong> spaces -&gt; <em>Generally strong in #1, #2, and #3</em></li><li><strong>Tech</strong> as an industry -&gt; <em>Similar to McKinsey group, I was able to find my sub-communities here with strong #1, #2, and #3s (though I feel like the community as a whole has a wide range on #2)</em></li><li><strong>Engineering</strong> in college -&gt; I chose to study engineering because I went to a "women in engineering" camp as a high school student, where I met college women who seemed so inspirational in what they were doing (from using engineering to make social impact abroad, to starting interesting startups, to going to top grad school programs after) <em>and </em>ranked really strongly on #1, #2, and #3. After committing to UIUC for engineering, I continued to find these qualities hold true for so many of my peers.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>P.S., deeper dive on the 3 traits above for kitesurfing community:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Smart people: Understanding how the kite works is all about physics. There are Newtonian forces at play, principles of aerodynamics like lift and drag, 3D and dynamic spatial visualization of power zones, and real life calculations of vectors, velocity, altitude, wind behavior given obstructions, etc. etc. You're out there in the water with just a board and a kite. You're solving problems in real time with just those tools - in order to achieve flight! I've met many kite surfers who studied engineering in uni.</li><li>Care for the world: I believe spending ample time out outdoors naturally breeds greater care and appreciation for nature. You're more aware as shorelines recede over the years. You see first hand how climate changes affect the communities living vulnerably near the elements. You also see the insane sunrises and sunsets over the water and are in absolute awe of the incredible Earth we are privileged to pass a brief moment that is our lives in.</li><li>Kind / accepting: Everywhere I've kitesurfed (n = 3), I've found the community to be extremely open and accepting. You bond quickly and make friends over a shared passion. Veterans share tips and stories. There is limited judgement no matter your skill level; everyone's been a beginner before. </li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>P.S.S., if I were to add a fourth trait, I think it'd be dedication for the "activity." I like being around passionate people; the energy is infectious. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>how in the world are there so many incredibly kind people? </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>at 6am this morning, i took a ~1 hour bus from Santa Veronica to Barranquilla</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>when i boarded the bus, it was packed and there was only standing room. for context, this bus takes people living in "outskirts" of the city (Barranquilla) to the city - almost all for work at service jobs.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>on the way, we also passed a lavanderia (laundromat).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>my thoughts:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>in cities, many service workers commute 1hr+ in packed and jolty buses to get to work at near minimum wage jobs. these people wake up around 5am or earlier. they spend hours on the road to what i think are among the most difficult jobs. their lives are a magnitude of inconvenience greater than mine - at a greater cost. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>quick aside- "poor" costs i've heard through the years:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><em>laundromat costs - $ and time / hassle to bring clothes to a laundromat costs more than using a washer / dryer at home (neglecting the upfront cost of the machines) </em></li><li><em>charging a phone if you don't have electricity at home - in the book I'm currently reading (<a href="https://www.gatesnotes.com/Energy/My-new-climate-book-is-finally-here">How to Avoid a Climate Disaster</a>), author Bill Gates mentions it people pay vendors ~$0.25 to charge a phone if they don't have electricity at home; which is order of magnitudes greater than the cost most people pay for electricity at home </em></li><li><em>commuting - again $ and time (and energy!) for commuting is much greater than not needing to (e.g., remote work) </em></li><li><em>toilet paper - poorer people tend to pay a 6% premium on everyday purchases, like <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2016/05/privilege-of-buying-in-bulk/482361/">toilet paper</a>. there is a mark-up for buying individual rolls vs in bulk, but poorer people may not have the upfront capital needed to buy in bulk  </em></li><li><em>many more examples!! a book on my reading list to learn more about this is called <a href="https://www.amazon.com/How-Other-Half-Banks-Exploitation/dp/0674286065">How the Other Half Banks</a></em></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>This means less time to spend with their families. Less time to spend on "hobbies" and on themselves.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>and they're fucking kind. on the bus, they're the ones who offer to hold your backpack at their feet area while you're standing because your backpack keeps falling around; they're the ones that stand up on the bus to offer you their seat. in cities, they're the ones who serve you delicious breakfast and coffee with a genuine smile on their face; they're the ones who have every right to be bitter at the world, at the hand they've been dealt with by the zip code of their birth, yet they go out of their way to make your day a tad bit better, a tad bit more convenient. and this makes all the difference.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>i'm absolutely baffled and overwhelmed by the kindness of human beings. it's been a common thread i've witnessed from people who may not have as much financial privilege as myself. onwards to trying my tiny bit in paying things forward.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>lots of love,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>kat</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>p.s. i keep missing kenya on a near daily basis. the hikes, the people, the kitesurfing, the people, the people. (but also loving the present!)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>p.s.s. like most of my writing, i'm making generalizations of an archetype :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Below are things I never regret doing (and can regret <em>not</em> doing):</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Sharing a complement</li><li>Talking with a stranger who seems interesting </li><li>Anonymous acts of kindness</li><li>Apologizing first</li><li>Dancing</li><li>Breathing, meditating, going for a walk outside</li><li>Drinking water</li><li>Smiling </li><li>Working out</li><li>Getting solid sleep</li><li>Taking naps when I'm tired</li><li>Telling people I love, that I love them</li><li>Exercising</li><li>Taking time for self-care</li><li>Cleaning my room / making my bed</li><li>Being barefoot on Earth</li><li>Hugs</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*At times, I'll make seemingly counterintuitive decisions to maximize freedom in the near term; but my rationale to is that those decisions would be like "delayed gratification" and lead to greater (in the absolute sense) longer term freedom. For example, I may choose to not overly indulge in food that could taste good but I know would deplete my energy levels later on. I guess I'm trying to say that the freedom I'm chasing isn't hedonism.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>(There was a quote I heard a while back about how laws counter-intuitively create more freedom .... I'll look around for this to pull in, in the future!). </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In the next few days, I'll be publishing a series of posts on how I define the types of freedoms that are important to me, and how I optimize for them. Stay tuned!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"large"} -->
<p class="has-large-font-size"><strong>1. Physical Freedom</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>My definition:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My physical body is healthy, fit, and able to move.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>Why it’s important to me:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This allows me to try new things, keep learning, achieve flow state with physical activities. As opportunities come up (say if my friends invite me to go skiing in Colorado, hiking at Mt Kilimanjaro, waterskiing in Watamu, scuba diving in Diani, deep water soloing and cliff jumping at Lake Kinkaid, etc!), then I’m able to say yes and participate.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When I engage in movement, I nourish my body and my mind. I think clearer. I’m fully present.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My favorite physical activities that en-trance me in flow state without fail are: biking, kitesurfing, rock climbing, slacklining, playing tennis, and most kinds of yoga (favorites are acroyoga, aerial yoga, and paddle board yoga :)).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>How I optimize this Freedom:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>By prioritizing and taking care of my physical health.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sleep:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Prioritize getting good sleep in my time management</li><li>Have a good bed and sleep environment</li><li>Get enough quality sleep time&nbsp;</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Diet:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Learn about what kinds of food at what quantities and what times of the day give vs take energy for me&nbsp;</li><li>Mindfully eat food that optimizes my energy levels</li><li>Drink lots of water!&nbsp;</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Skincare:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Follow skincare routine with SPF and moisturizer</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Dental care:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Floss teeth after brushing teeth</li><li>Wear my retainer at night to prevent grinding</li><li>Brush my teeth or drinking water after eating something really acidic or sweet</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Movement:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Prioritize getting ~30 min of sweat-inducing movement each day during weekdays</li><li>Prioritize spending ample time outdoors during weekends</li><li>Exercise with proper form to minimize injuries</li><li>Walk, bike, take stairs, etc. to get around whenever I can</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Misc:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Generally avoid engaging in things that have negative effects on my physical health (e.g., alcohol, caffeine, other substances, too much screen time when possible, not dressing for the weather, not fully drying my hair after a shower before going out if it’s chilly or windy outside - somehow my immune system gets shot every time I do this…)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Other physical care habits I’m continuously working on:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Eye care - taking better care of my eyes, especially in my technology screen habits</li><li>Posture - having good posture throughout my day whether when I’m working in front of my computer, standing up, socializing with others, or other activities.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>Other Freedoms this closely affects:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Mental Freedom (to be shared more about in a future post!)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"large"} -->
<p class="has-large-font-size"><strong>2. Financial Freedom</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>My definition:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Having the financial means to pursue whatever I want to.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>Why it’s important to me:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This Freedom enables me to pursue the things that I want to, without money being a barrier.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>How I optimize this Freedom:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I start with asking myself what’s important to me. What do I want? What do I need? After this self-reflection, I assess how much it would cost to live a life prioritizing what I find important.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I learned that my ideal lifestyle costs a lot less than I initially expected. For the last 3 years of my life, I’ve lived out of a maroon carry-on suitcase from Costco. My rent has always been less than $1000 USD / month while living in environments with people that make me really happy.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I worked at a well-enough-paying career I loved for two years after college. I spent some of my salary on things that were important to me and made me happy. The rest of it, I saved and invested. The savings bought me the financial cushion to continue to afford “buying” my financial freedom in future stages of life. I’ve been able to pursue my professional career decisions irregardless of the compensation. <em>(Side note: for me, compensation is still important! But more as an indication of my relative value to an organization than an absolute figure to chase.) </em>I know I’ll always be able to go full-time into passion projects without needing a salary to pay for my living expenses.<em> </em>For example, in 2021, I was able to afford working at a non-profit in Kenya and maintain a (more costly than my non-profit salary) lifestyle of African adventure.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I continue to spend my money in alignment with what I need, and what makes me happy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>Other Freedoms this closely affects:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Professional Freedom (more on this to come in a future post!)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"large"} -->
<p class="has-large-font-size"><strong>3.</strong> <strong>Mental Freedom</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>My definition:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Mental stability and clarity of thought</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>Why it’s important to me:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This is an essential (and I think usually underrated) building block to happiness and achieving sustained success in the other degrees of Freedom.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>How I optimize this Freedom:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My top habits and systems to maintain and strengthen mental stability and clarity of thought:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Cultivate gratitude mindset:<ul><li>Practice appreciation throughout life, look at every situation by the positives, feel wonder and presentness for even the relatively mundane things we usually take for granted</li></ul></li><li>Surround myself with good people and follow the Golden Rule:<ul><li>I try to show up for others in the way I’d want them to show up for me. By doing so, I feel blessed to have a core group of family and friends that have become my system for mutual emotional stability support and corresponding mental freedom.</li></ul></li><li>Manage my stress:<ul><li>My fav stress management practices: Meditate regularly, practice maintaining perspective (e.g., this is not a life or death situation, this won’t make a difference in 10 years, there are much greater problems in the world, etc.), exercise, go outside, take a nap, write down my to-do’s and have reassess my prioritization (incl what can I push out or totally drop), call a friend, listen to some music and dance, break for a clay or sheet face mask, turn on my eye massager</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>Other Freedoms this closely affects:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Physical Freedom</li><li>Financial Freedom</li><li>Professional Freedom <em>(more to come in a future post!)</em></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"large"} -->
<p class="has-large-font-size"><strong>4. Professional Freedom</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>My definition:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Freedom built by skills, experiences, and network to pursue professional opportunities that are most interesting to me.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>Why it’s important to me:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I spend the majority of my life at work - in my professional career. Accordingly, my work is how I maximize my impact to the world as well as my personal feeling of fulfillment.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Personally, I optimize for careers where I can have the steepest learning curves in directions that I find interesting. Financial compensation is a lower priority; my compensation just needs to be enough for me to feel valued.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Since my semester in Paris for <a href="https://paris-digital-lab.com/digital-tech-year-fr/">Digital Tech Year</a>, I adopted a mindset that, for at least in my 20s, each full-time thing that I spend time in (e.g., job, fellowship, entrepreneurship, etc.), I would do it even if I had to <em>pay</em> money to do so. Excellence at professions in traditional industries like medicine and law require multiple years of schooling; thus I find it valid to invest my 20s on learning to obtain longer term professional opportunities with greater magnitudes of impact, potential earning power, and fulfillment.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>How I optimize this Freedom:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I optimize the professional opportunities available to me through a strategic acquisition of skills and network.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Skills:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>From Turing - chief of staff role:<ul><li>How a CEO runs a fast growing $1B+ startup, incl org setup, exec interactions, metrics analysis, investor relations, etc.</li></ul></li><li>From One Acre Fund - operation lead role:<ul><li>How to design end-to-end processes, implement, and scale!</li></ul></li><li>From McKinsey:<ul><li>How to be a “professional”</li><li>Executive presence and confidence</li><li>Executive communication</li><li>Problem solving and achieving buy-in for a true success to implementation</li></ul></li><li>From Paris Digital Tech Year:<ul><li>Technical know-how for coding MVPs - including for mobile development</li><li>Working “in the field” to design a technology product with user-centric principles</li><li>Working in an engineering team&nbsp;</li></ul></li><li>From Engineering major:<ul><li>Analytical approach to solving problems</li><li>Hard work ethic and time management</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Network:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>From McKinsey:<ul><li>Working with many different people - from different industries, functions, tenures, etc.</li></ul></li><li>From remote year:<ul><li>Living with friends and getting to know people more deeply</li></ul></li><li>From Watson social entrepreneurship fellowship:<ul><li>Awesome social entrepreneurs from literally around the world (for example, my roommate was from Papua New Guinea) - both in my cohort and the other cohorts who’ve gone through the program</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Financial note:</em> In my 20s, I don’t have large financial obligations like a family, mortgage, or large health expenses. Taking advantage of this situational freedom, I am able to choose my professional decisions to optimize for the acquisition of the three above, which I believe will bring enough financial freedom in the long run for additional expenses (like a family!) that I’ll likely want.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>Other Freedoms this closely affects:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Financial Freedom</li><li>Physical Freedom<ul><li>(e.g., where I live for work)</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"large"} -->
<p class="has-large-font-size"><strong>5. Born-with Freedoms</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>My definition:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are a large amount of freedoms that I’ve been incredibly blessed to be born with. These are freedoms that I can’t change - and instead, I want to acknowledge and make the most of them. These are gifts from my parents - and from the universe that made it so I was born to my parents at the geographic locations they were at, at the time in the universe they were living.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>Why it’s important to me:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As I grow older, I see more of this world and have conversations with people much different than I. Through these experiences, a common pattern emerges: I continuously learn more about the privileges I’ve been born with - that I may have previously taken for granted. These “born-with freedoms” enable me to live the rest of my life more fully because I don’t need to worry about certain things that may limit many other people around the world.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>How <s>I</s> </em>external forces<em> optimize this Freedom:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Freedoms due to <em>where</em> I was raised:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Language skills</strong> - I’m conversationally fluent in Chinese, French, and Spanish (in addition to English!) because I was brought up in China, Canada, and the US.&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Chinese culture</strong> - I love being Chinese! I love the cultural values I grew up with, I love the beautiful languages and the <em>chengyu</em> phrases, I love how there are Chinese people all over the world - and it seems that I can quickly connect to this community no matter where I am in the world. I love having a rich ethnic history that I can call my own.</li><li><strong>American and Canadian passports</strong> - This. I have so many physical freedoms on Earth because of my passports. I can travel and work almost anywhere in the world. I get to live and work in one of the most prosperous countries with security, freedom, and liberty. There are so many perks of my nationality - that I grow much more appreciative of when I live in different countries and meet people with various restrictions and headaches that I don’t need to worry about.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Other freedoms due to my parents:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Body genetics </strong>- I’m relatively healthy because my parents and their families are relatively healthy. Like my parents, I’m naturally lean and tall which helps with making most of my physical freedom.</li><li><strong>Values and habits </strong>- My parents passed on their values to my sister and I through their daily actions. It’s easier to do something beneficial (or even to <em>know </em>to do something) when you see the people closest to you embody it. A few top ones:<ul><li>1) Be growth-minded and open-minded. We are life-long learners and explorers of this huge world. There is always something to learn in each situation - to take the good and to learn to avoid the bad. They gave us all they knew from their experience of this world, and urged us to explore beyond their knowledge.&nbsp;</li><li>2) Prioritize what’s important in life. Certain things in life are irreversible - like health! Thus, it’s important to prioritize these accordingly and ensure your actions reflect this prioritization.&nbsp;</li><li>3) Be continuously grateful and maintain a sense of wonder. This outlook on the world makes life easier :)</li><li>4) Work hard :) Perhaps this value stems from my parents being immigrants to North America from China when I was a child. They had to work really hard for everything they have.</li><li>5) Discuss finances openly. Through this, we learned about personal finances - one of those important topics that they don’t teach at school (but totally should!).&nbsp;</li><li>6) Provide emotional support and stability. My parents raised my sister and I in an environment of unconditional love and support. This provides a baseline of emotional stability that allows us the mental capacity and confidence to do more in our lives in other ways. (+ shout out to my SO as well who continues providing my life with an immense amount of emotional support and love.)</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Freedoms due to the macro trends during the time in Earth that I live in:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Lots of jobs available after graduation (I didn’t graduate during an economic downturn)</li><li>I was able to work in person for almost a year before work overall went remote due to Covid. I’m thankful to have had a solid in person start - for more mentorship and coaching.</li><li>Minority groups (by gender, race, etc.) have more opportunities now than ever before in the US. Diversity is valued.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Thanks mom and dad.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>xx</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong><em>Other Freedoms this closely affects:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>All other Freedoms.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>source:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>:) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>cheeers!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Thinking out loud: </em>in growing your online presence and what you share to a seemingly-infinite community; be genuine. It's better to be genuine (and happy by being true to yourself!) and have smaller followers who are truly invested, than to constantly course correct your content to what you think the masses want to see / hear / read - and lose some of yourself and what you truly enjoy doing. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Side thought: </em>A book I'm currently reading, <a href="https://www.amazon.com/Righteous-Mind-Divided-Politics-Religion/dp/0307455777">The Righteous Mind</a>, mentions how people are influenced by others' perceptions of them, no matter how they themselves think they are or are not (conclusions from a conducted study). Perhaps a way to avoid too much course correcting in content publishing is to schedule posts and look at feedback on a cadenced aggregate, instead of 1-off. Signal v noise!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>underrated perks, highly ranked in my book:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>sneaking a kiss w your SO during the work day</li><li>napping when you're exhausted</li><li>kitesurfing on weekends </li><li>dictating your own meal times </li><li>hangouts / meals with other remote workers; who are friends you choose to be around instead of have to be around without choice</li><li>no mandatory commute</li><li>wear whatever clothes make you most comfortable</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I prefer remote working culture than in-person; but in ideal world- it'd be somewhat hybrid (quarterly off-sites, monthly field visits, etc.)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>+ is longevity of relevance even important?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>one</em>. when i touch your body <em>once</em> again, i trace your new physique against my embrace; reminding me that we are separate human beings, constantly evolving.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>two</em>. we have <em>too</em> little time in this world, <em>too</em> brief a time together. so we squeeze the essence out of every precious moment, we can't afford to settle and take for granted this time before our next departing flight. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>three</em>. did you know that you still give me butterflies? <em>thrice</em> actually, in the last few days: in anticipation of your arrival, when we're with friends and the way you look at me, when you push your lips against mine in the morning.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>four</em>. there's time <em>for</em> myself. i'm finding my own voice, shaping my own thoughts, and growing into my own being. you too. and we'll love each other more for it.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>five</em>. it's been <em>five</em> years together. we've both changed a heck ton; it's pretty lucky we still like each other eh?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>P.S., the #s were a bit of a stretch. hope it was at least more interesting to read than bullet points! ;)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>is both partners having a <em><strong>growth mindset</strong></em>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It seems like most books, articles, youtube videos, and other content sources will tout answers such as: communication, respect, trust, honesty, compromise, physical connection, and others.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Although I wholeheartedly agree that these other answers are incredibly important to have in a relationship, I believe having a growth mindset is the most important (and most under-recognized) answer to sustaining long term romantic relationships. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Why</strong>:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Our lives are complex and dynamic. As we evolve, new challenges inadvertently arise that test relationships. A growth mindset ensures the relationship can navigate these trials and grow stronger as a result.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Plus, growth mindset is a bit of a cheat code answer; someone with a growth mindset would continuously improve on all the textbook answers of communication, respect, physical connection, etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Side thoughts:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Similarly, when I ask both my single guy and girl friends of the factors they find most important in their potential SO, the answers I commonly hear include: level of altruism / care for the world, smile / height / specific other physical traits, sense of humor, sense of adventure, intelligence, etc.<br>I urge people to include the <strong>growth mindset</strong> factor when assessing romantic partners. It's the factor with the greatest compounding returns ;)<br>You'll be opening yourself to the <em>right</em> pool of potential suitors. There may be a limited group of people who currently meet the bar on all of your standards, but if you're evaluating on growth mindset (evaluation by demonstrated actions and results), you'll be able to focus your pool on people who are more likely to provide long term happiness than just static satisfaction.</li><li>If I were to pick the second most important factor for sustaining long term romantic relationships, it'd be <strong>dedication</strong> to the relationship. The intent + growth mindset is a powerful duo!</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>s/o to Joy Xun for this reminder &lt;3</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>funny how i become more thankful of things when i temporarily experience not having them</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>you know, of the ones where the guy makes that face, or the girl falls asleep, etc. etc. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>if this already exists, where can i find and follow it!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>P.S. I'm publishing a lot more of my thoughts recently; I'd attribute it to living alone in a studio for the first time of my life!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>I've been reflecting on the last 5-10 years, where I've witnessed extraordinary achievements of peers in my proximity (including acquaintances and closer friends). For instance, a peer of mine in middle school didn't attend college and instead went on to become a successful influencer and trailblazer in his own type of videography (and has filmed videos for some of the world's most famous popstars). Peers from my high school with overlapping years have: become serial entrepreneurs of their own companies worth many millions, sold their company with a successful exit, published books that reached #1 on NYT best-seller list (and received among the biggest publishing deals for their category and signed multi-million dollar movie deals) , dated objectively famous heartthrobs, attended Met Galas, play professional sports - from competing at the Olympics to playing on the last SuperBowl winning team, received some of the worlds' most prestigious postgraduate scholarships, achieved twitter / instagram blue check verification in so many different ways (from music to sports), and many more.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Looking into the future 5-10 years, I know I can't begin to imagine the levels of "success" my peers will continue to achieve with the incredible compounding effect of time. These people will be leading industries and movements across the world. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"large"} -->
<p class="has-large-font-size"><strong>So dear future successful friends,</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I get it. If we were just friendly and more like acquaintances, you probably have dozens of us in your DMs and at least 1 or 2 negative experiences from people who have reached out to you transactionally and artificially after your achieved marks of success.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I also get it. You're hanging out with other similarly successful people. You bond with them more, because you have similar shared experiences - battle scars, triumphs, and all. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In reflection, perhaps so be it. You're busier now. I'm proud of you, I'm inspired by you, and I'm genuinely happy for your success! Our relationship will probably evolve somewhat - perhaps you'll have less time for spontaneous phone tags, crashing at your place or mine, hiking adventures over the weekend - but I just want you to know that I'm still here for you if you want a friend.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Love,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Kat</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>P.S. Life often has sinusoidal qualities. Ups won't always be up. Downs won't always be down. In ups, I hope you stay a solid person in your values and core. In downs, feel free to reach out to me to talk, listen, or just be. The external publications, awards, etc. only show the ups so downs often are "out of mind, out of sight."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>Dear potentially "successful" future Kat, </em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>hopefully ditto same for everything above for yourself with some solid day 1 friends &lt;3 </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>*successful defined here as societally-defined success, by whatever metrics the industry chooses!</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>**friends = tbh this is a range for me and I have no idea how to define this. Likely it includes people with whom I've been on friendly terms and shared same physical space for some time. We may have gone to parties together, to classes together, ideally have had some solid conversations and feeling of connection. Probably we've been there for each other through shared experiences with some sort of hardship.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Side thought: </em>I wonder, in a world where I feel achievement saturation, does the significance of achievement diminish? How much of the achievement saturation is due to the developments of people I've been lucky to surround myself around growing up vs the overall increase in opportunities and global awareness from technology? Perhaps to even think about this means I'm coming from a place of great privilege. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This morning on my walk to breakfast, the guy who stands by the first crosswalk en route (he washes people’s cars’ windows during red lights) told my friend (he’s Colombian and looks it) in Spanish that my backpack was open. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Indeed it was. My MacBook, almost all my cash, and my Android phone were in plain view of any passerby. As I turned my backpack to zip up the sections, my foot came close to stepping into a hole in the sidewalk. Immediately, another man (he's always at the same corner selling candy by the piece) and a woman who happened to walk by both started yelling "Cuidado!" at me - to make sure I didn’t fall into the hole or hurt myself.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In a country where the saying "<em>no dar papaya</em>" (translated somewhat to: <em>don't act in a way that gives others opportunities to take advantage of you, usually in terms of theft</em>) is ubiquitously known among locals and foreigners alike, in a country where I'm constantly walking quickly on sidewalks and taking Ubers as soon as the sun starts to set, in a country with the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth_inequality_in_Latin_America">second highest income inequality in Latin America</a> (a close follow to Haiti in first), I am astounded by these consistent acts of kindness.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>I believe humans want to be kind and are inherently good. </strong>I've had a few debates on this topic with friends in high school and college. I acknowledge that I've had a sheltered life growing up and still do today - but perhaps that sustained naivety could lead to a better world. People often act towards the expectations of others on them, regardless of an existing delta between their current state. Studies (both ones conducted with scientific rigor as well as ones conducted by my personal observations) show that when you treat someone as having a certain quality (e.g., kind, on-time, intelligent, etc.) in your actions and your words, then they often rise up to that expectation and strengthen those attributes. This is also a hack to better people around you through your day to day interactions - in all kinds of relationships (parenting, romantic, friend, work, etc!).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>another thought: I think I'm micro-blogging! It's sustainable, fun, and reflective for me - to look back on in the future and have a richer "memory."</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>XD</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>these last weeks, i've been more with my thoughts - by living in Colombia in a studio. first time i'm living in a studio on my own! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>when my SO came to visit for a week-ish and we shared space again, i realized i was so accustomed to being in my thoughts that i'd narrate commentary in my head even during some of our interactions.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>i'm thinking more, but i don't know if the quality of my thoughts are improving. that's the fun thing about being in your head - there are minimal feedback loops, just lots of spiraling thought effects. the more i think, the more i think! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
{"version":2,"isGlobalStylesUserThemeJSON":true}
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And friends, I care about how I show up!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>thought / thing learned about myself and realization of the expectations i hold prior to meeting people</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>examples:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>eating a carb or oil or sugar heavy meal </strong>-&gt; in addition to the time it takes to eat the meal, i often feel lethargic and low energy for hours after </li><li><strong>partaking in substances with friends at night hangouts</strong> (alcohol, etc.) -&gt; in addition to the time of the activity, i can feel lower energy, perhaps hung over, and lower productivity in the morning following</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>thought / thing learned for myself</em>: be aware and include calculation of the "after-effect" costs when choosing to partake in activities! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>consequentially, there are activities that <em>give </em>future time / energy in addition to the current time of the activity.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>examples:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>exercising in a fun way</strong> (for me: kite surfing, yoga, rock climbing, biking, jogging, tbh even feeling flow at the gym) -&gt; in addition to the time exercising, i often feel higher energy and endurance in the future = greater productivity = saves time when doing other tasks = "gives time"</li><li><strong>writing and reading </strong>-&gt; in addition to the time spent actively writing / reading, i feel like my thoughts and discussions in the future are more insightful with my written or read collateral. more insightful = more productive / higher quality conversations and thoughts = saves time = "gives time." &lt;- bit of a stretch XD</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Him</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>He throws 2 t-shirts, 1 pair of pants, and 4 underwear - all the clean clothes in his closet - in his orange backpack, the same one that once held his college textbooks. At times, he forgets his toothbrush and will buy one where he goes. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Me</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>I write my packing list <strong>days</strong> in advance on my graph paper notebook, dotted with handwritten checkboxes to give a satisfying mark when the item is packed. I rack my mind ten times over to make sure I have everything I need and nothing more to optimize space in my carry-on. My alarm to leave for the airport is named after a reminder to pack my chargers and toiletries.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Him</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>He's in charge of planning our Sunday bike ride along the streets of Bogota. We'll go rent bikes whenever we wake up and finish breakfast and he takes a last-minute Covid test for his flight the next day. The first bike shop is closed. The second one has only 2 folding bikes with chains that keep falling off. The third one is a 35 minute drive away - we take an Uber there to find out that the owners are out for lunch... for the next 2 hours. We walk around and he'll ask locals in Spanglish if they know of any other bike shops nearby. Finally, we find bikes! We're one step closer to partake in the Sunday ciclovía (finding the path is another adventure on it's own). </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Through it all, he's good at focusing on what really matters - spending time together.    </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Me</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>For our date, I reference my running list of tracked ideas I've acquired through the <strong>months</strong> from friend recommendations, Instagram inspirations, and online searches. The list is neatly prioritized and triaged to be the top experiences I want to do with him - of course calibrating from his past feedback on what he's enjoyed and what he hasn't liked as much. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Order hike-friendly food the night before to take on our trip, coordinate with the national park guide to meet us at a specific time and location, confirm car transportation with my friend, research the travel time including anticipated traffic to ensure we get in the park before 8am (we need to leave the park by 2pm according to the guide's advice), pack sunscreen and an extra water bottle in my daypack, check weather to ensure we're dressed appropriately. Post-hike, I have reservations for 2 at a spa and then a new restaurant with locally sourced ingredients and vibrant plating.  </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Him</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>He'll probably write his the night before. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Me</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>My wedding vows? I've been drafting them <strong>all my life</strong>.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Closing thoughts: Planning is a large point of differentiation between my SO and I. I've tried to paint a picture of how I can over-plan and how he can under-plan; and I truly believe there isn't a "right" or "wrong" approach. In re-reading what I've written, I feel like his approach can seem a bit more negative than mine which is not intentional. Fundamentally, I know he loves and cares for me, and I love and care for him. Perhaps a future iteration of this poem should showcase that more.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>i sit staring forward, avoiding eye contact with the family who routinely sang and danced to the traditional music playing from their well-used speakers to the audience of drivers waiting for the red light to turn green.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>thoughts raced through my mind when the young boy from the family made his walk from car window to car window on his way to mine. <em>did i want to promote this? if i gave him cash, would that perpetuate a life of street performing vs "better" alternatives? do i even have cash on me? how much should i give in order to actually make a difference in their lives? i just spent 30,000+ cop on a latte and breakfast. this Didi ride costs ~12,000 cop. i'm paying to these already well-off institutions without second thought but the same amount of money would make more impact to so many individuals i walk / drive by every day.  </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>he approached my window with his traditional hat held out, and i sat immobile, eyes still staring straight. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>my Didi driver gives the street performer boy a 200 cop coin.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>my driver's action led to new thoughts to swarm my head. 200 cop = ~5 cents in USD is absolutely nothing to me. but 200 cop, combined with the other coins that other drivers / passengers put into the boy's hat, means enough to this family standing on the street intersection performing their beautiful traditional songs and dance.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>from this &lt;2 minute interaction, i was brought face first to the <strong>importance of diversity in teams</strong>, especially teams that build products / services that serve a diverse population.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>when we have teammates from different backgrounds and experiences, this leads to corresponding better design and actions to serve more people. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>two more thoughts here:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>diversity is especially important in building technology (especially for consumers) because of the near limitless reach. and likewise for government? (i'm less in tune with government / policy)</li><li>in a pro-bono case at McK for helping homelessness in the bay area, one of the recommendations we had was to push for more people from homelessness / housing-insecure background to join causes in research and advancement. at that time, i didn't fully realize the importance of this push. now looking back, i understand it more.</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>for personal tracking, day this happened: 2/20/22.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This course for language learning is top! Going through the Spanish one in the next 1.5 months while I’m still in Colombia.  (Swahili is next!) </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are 90 courses, each ~7-10 minutes. If I do at least 2 a day, then I’m on track to finish!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Then I don’t have to use up my brain’s limited “RAM” (random access memory).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Side note: tbh the types of computer memory feel fairly similar to the types of memory I think of my brain as having, to be computationally efficient. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Further read on computer memory types here: https://www.enterprisestorageforum.com/hardware/types-of-computer-memory/ </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As humans, we supplement our memories with photos, videos, blog posts, written text, and physical items. These are like “keys” that return / trigger greater memories in our brain “dictionary.” Not 1:1, but you can read more about this function in computer science here: https://www.w3schools.com/python/ref_dictionary_keys.asp</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
