<p>source: a draft not-published post i wrote a while back titled </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"I want my name written on a bag</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>With black sharpie, quickly scrawled"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>the best jobs aren't on the market (long)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>the best talent aren't on the market (long)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>so what works for both sides?</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>referrals, network, knowing people </li><li>targeted outreach (recruiters / talent specialists / etc)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>thought on, how after ~2 months of exploring coffee shops, coworking spaces, gyms / workout classes, breakfast / lunch spots, etc; that i've only recently become much more in love with the building i currently live in! Plura Coliving @ Bogota</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Loves: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>11mil COP breakfast tailored to my dietary preferences (eggs, fruit, cappucinno, etc!) just downstairs - learned this ~2 weeks ago</li><li>gym is awesome - and i just learned that they have insane workout classes in the morning! for also a very affordable price</li><li>super sweet (free / included in rent) coworking spots all around - from the rooftop to the basement to the lobby area. good seating places and amazing wifi. super short commute ;)</li><li>the best spa in bogota ;P. free sessions in the sauna, steam room, jacuzzi - hot and cold throughout the week. very value massage / spa sessions as well.</li><li>the "noise-cancelling room" in the basement floor is amazing for pre-games / small fun parties ;)</li><li>haven't reserved the rooms in the coworking space in the basement, but this is something i think i'll try to do a bit more of... and just work from there sometimes in the week!</li><li>haven't used the "movie theater" room for projecting movies / shows, BUT maybe organize a movie night sometime with friends there!</li><li>4th and 5th floor has BBQ / outdoor patio areas. definitely are fun places to chill!</li><li>rooftop bar has amazing ambiance and views at night and during the day. great place for board game nights with friends or just to hang out and grab a drink.</li><li>free fixie bikes to borrow at anytime :). insane that i don't have to buy a bike or worry about where to rent a bike for the sunday ciclovias!</li><li>walking distance to awesome morning hikes (maybe do 1 more of this before i leave)</li><li>salsa and really good live music events in the lobby on some nights (thursday and friday?)</li><li>beautiful art throughout the building &lt;3 makes me happy</li><li>honestly the nicest people - from the waiters to the doormen to the other residents to the doggos who live with their residents!</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>"I'm grateful X happened, because now I better appreciate Y."</li><li>"Lesson learned."</li><li>"At least...."</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>"I'm grateful X happened, because now I better appreciate Y."</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The other morning, I was turned away from purchasing breakfast from a resort near my AirBnb in La Boquilla (a super beautiful area of Cartagena, Colombia - highly recommend!). The sun was coming up, and the corresponding heat was felt with every step I took while walking around the neighborhood in search of my first meal. Each resort I walked into either didn't offer breakfast, or didn't have breakfast for purchase for someone not living there. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Despondent, I walked back towards my AirBnb. I decided to take a slight detour and walk on the beach, where I found local breakfast spots! I ended up having breakfast overlooking the ocean with sand beneath my feet, a wonderful breeze blowing through my hair, and local music playing in the speakers. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My first thought when I sat down at the beach spot was: "I'm grateful that I got rejected from all those resorts and went through that scorching walk, because now I better appreciate this incredible beach breakfast."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I often don't realize how "good" I have it until I go through difficulty. Thus, I'm thankful for difficult experiences because they increase my appreciation for the world. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>"Lesson learned."</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Another morning, I woke up with my stomach hurting - in that bloated uncomfortable hurt feeling. The night prior, I had mindlessly snacked on countless "japanese peanuts" (they're these <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cracker_nuts">delicious flour coated peanuts</a> ). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In my hurt, my mind defaulted to the thought: <em>Lesson learned to not eat so much dense snacks right before bed. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In acknowledging what lessons I can learn from negative situations empowers me, because I feel more control of these situations and preventing them in the future :).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>"At least...."</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I was biking with a few friends in Bogota on these free fixie bikes that our apartment building lets us check-out. The bikes weren't the best... most of our bikes didn't have two working brakes, one of our bikes' seats kept falling down, and so on. One of my friends was vocal in his countless gripes - for him, he was comparing this bike to the very high end bikes he and his family had at home in Utah. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I chimed in, "All those points are very true. But at least we have bikes to use on this beautiful perfect-bike-weather day! And how they are free and so easy to checkout." I recounted my story of the weekend prior where my SO and I stopped by countless bike shops (and ended up finding one very far away which was a nuisance to borrow and return the bikes at) to finally find bikes for our Sunday ride (I didn't know our building had free bikes to borrow at that time!).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Call out: </em>It's not always conducive to use these "reframing" mindsets when interacting with others - dependent on the severity degree of a situation. For example, if someone is going through something pretty bad, and I were to say "well at least X," then this shows a lack of empathy and understanding. Instead, in those situations, people often just want to be heard and sympathized with :). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>others = friends / family / colleagues / work that needs to be done / etc!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>mindset shifts to: "i <em>get </em>to do this (and get paid for it?!)"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>where does this hold true? where does this not? if the validity of the statement holds true and is a growing trend, what are the next level implications in these spaces?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>thoughts in my mind :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Through my life, I've heard, held, and sometimes released nuggets of wisdom from books, podcasts, conversations, and more. Regarding romantic relationships, here are two helpful mindsets that have served me well, and one mindset that I grew out of.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Two mindsets on relationships that have served me well:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li><em>80-20 rule for greener grass</em></li><li><em>Your romantic partner doesn't need to be your everything </em></li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Both are fairly similar:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(1) The grass isn't always greener on the other side. Say you're in a relationship with person A who has 80% of what you want and lacks a 20%. It can be easy to focus on the 20% you're missing. It can also be easy to look for that 20% elsewhere. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Now say you find person B who has that elusive 20% that your person A doesn't have. I've seen many people leave their current relationship to chase this missing 20%. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Person B may have the 20%, but there's no guarantee that person B would have the rest of the 60% to even get to the 80% you have with person A. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Thus, appreciate the 80%. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(2) Correspondingly, it's absolutely <em>okay</em> to not get 100% from your romantic partner. Coming to this realization was at first bittersweet and then truly liberating. It seems like every Disney movie / blockbuster RomCom we grew up with paints the picture of a 100% perfect "Prince Charming" for the protagonist. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Again, I have many friends who've left their relationships because they couldn't get 100% of what they wanted from one person... Think of that! 100% of everything you could want from one singular person! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There was always something missing that they deemed to be more important than everything they already had. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Alternatively, a more healthy and sustainable* approach is to identify and love what you can get from your partner (acknowledging and appreciating that perhaps you can't get some of this from others) and then fill your other needs from others (family, friends!). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For instance, my SO gives me so much that I don't get from others in my life. (Examples here: extremely intimate sense of security, trust, support, physical connection, etc.) However, there are certain things that I want in my life that he doesn't 100% fit the bill for - and that's totally ok! (Examples here: certain deeper / philosophical conversations about various aspects of life, motivation driven by positive impact to the world, maximizing fulfilling experiences and optimizing for certain adventures.) Instead of fitting me 100%, he's pursuing his own things and I love him more for that. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>* people are dynamic- we all change as a function of time. This makes life more interesting, but also makes it unsustainable to get everything you want from one person <strong>all the time</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>One mindset on relationships that has not served me as well:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><em>Everyone looks the same at age 60</em></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In high school, my friend's mom told me and the rest of the 14 year old girls attending my friend's birthday party that <em>"Everyone looks the same at age 60, and so don't pick your romantic partner based on looks."</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My friend's parents did look "successful" in multiple ways - they seemed loving to each other enough, they were very financially well off, their kids (including my friend) were academically top of their class and top of the state in their chosen sports. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>So I took this advice to heart. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Freshman year of college, I got into a relationship with someone I didn't find physically attractive (nor would I think stereotypical society would find physically attractive). I was attracted to his ambition and how he seemed <em>different</em> with an untouchable quality that my past amours (who did<em> </em>look more stereotypically physically attractive) had lacked. I rationalized dating this guy with the advice I was given a few years back: <em>Everyone looks the same at age 60. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This led to an unhealthy relationship for various reasons (some due to this mindset, but also many more due to other factors that stemmed from dating a pathological liar 😅). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Once I left the relationship, I realized the following:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Not everyone looks the same at age 60 (this Instagram post illustrates my point: https://www.instagram.com/p/CamuUF2FE-9/?utm_medium=copy_link). There are some really fit, healthy, happy people at 60, and on the other hand, there are many people who become the opposite of that at 60. </li><li>Even if everyone did look the same at age 60, life is long! There's so much of life to live and enjoy instead of to just "bear" because "it doesn't matter in the end."</li><li>Physical appearance is important to me because it represents self-care and values. I believe that most people can be physically attractive by just eating healthy and exercising. My ex did not do either, and his lifestyle ended up impacting my own (e.g., it's easier to eat a cookie if he opens a pack of cookie dough every other day, it's harder to train for your marathon when he doesn't support you waking up early to run since he personally didn't prioritize exercise). </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:more -->
<!--more-->
<!-- /wp:more -->

<!-- wp:separator {"className":"has-css-opacity"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-css-opacity" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Feel free to try on these mindsets for your own life! Use advice that serve you, drop the advice that don't :).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>from good things / aspects of people / etc.: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>what we want more of</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>from bad things / aspects of people / etc.: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>what we want to avoid</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Mornings</strong> are absolutely key: I need to feel like I've accomplished something - whether it's writing a blog post or going for a walk with my thoughts. I just need about an hour or so of this to feel great for the rest of the day. The rest of the day, I no longer feel pressure of wanting to do something meaningful <em>for myself</em> and thus can focus on giving my energy to other causes.</li><li><strong>During the work day</strong>: I like my job! Going through the motions, I feel good when I get deep work in, and I feel accomplished when I progress with deliverables / projects at work. If I'm exhausted from work, I like to take a step back and reflect on how I <em>get to</em> learn all the things I'm spending my time on.</li><li>In the <strong>early evenings </strong>(~1-1.5 hr break from work): I like to get a workout in! There's a gym in the basement of my apartment so it's super easy to go work out, shower, eat something healthy, and then feel refreshed for the rest of my day.</li><li>In the<strong> later evenings</strong>: The standard activities I pursue are (listed in relative order of frequency): i) self-care (cleaning my room / dishes, listening to a podcast or music, writing more, putting on a face mask, lighting a candle, watching a movie / show, reading a book, phone / video call with a friend, etc.), ii) working more (either if I started my day later / wasn't productive enough during the day, or if there's just a lot to do at work and upcoming high-ish stakes deliverables due), ii) hanging with friends (group dinner, group sauna session, Catan / board games night, ping-pong, and sometimes coworking with friends which overlaps with ii)).</li><li>Also <strong>throughout the day</strong>, eating healthy food that gives me energy at appropriate time! And drinking enough water. </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Younger Kathleen is proud of current day Kat.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>I saw myself in the mirror. I saw my past self, my current self, my future self. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>In further reflection (post-trip): I've written letters to my future self for years. I've always been dreaming and preparing for who I want to become.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>My high school (and younger) self was the idealistic type that comes with a suburban youth vying for more in the world.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>In letters to my future self and in pondering midnight conversations with close friends, I wondered if my future self would become a "sell-out" or if my future self would make decisions that my-then-current self would be proud of.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em><strong>3/5/22, as I stared into my bathroom mirror, I realized that younger Kathleen is proud of current day Kat. </strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em> </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>answer: nicotine does something in a brain pathway to reduces appetite  https://www.npr.org/2011/06/09/137085989/the-skinny-on-smoking-why-nicotine-curbs-appetite </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>but no conclusive research on the same for caffeine: https://coffeeaffection.com/does-coffee-suppress-your-appetite/</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Up until a few years ago, I thought of "trauma" as a word with absolutely horrible meaning. It was something that the very unfortunate people of our world had gone through. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Then relatively recently, it clicked. I am carrying trauma from my current romantic relationship of my dreams.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here's a non-scientific, just-from-my-musings+a-bit-of-internet-research exploration on the <strong>topic of trauma</strong> from my romantic relationship experience.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>How it happens:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Going through a negative (other adjectives could include: stressful, frightening, distressing) singular event or multiple events that create a lasting emotional impact on the individual</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>An example from my romantic relationship: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In the first few years of dating, my SO had a habit of ruthlessly prioritizing his own goals over our relationship. As his SO, it became exhausting to accommodate and support his often changing personal goals that he valued over us (and also myself not seeing concrete results in many of these personal goals, thus not concretely feeling that the sacrifices were all "worth it"). For a few months during college, he'd be strict on his sleep schedule - waking up at 6am everyday to work out. Another few months, he'd be strict on needing to be in his room for most of the day to practice guitar - when he had ambitions to be a guitarist. After college, he went through a real estate + ruthlessly saving money phase where he needed to spend most weekends (and weekday evenings) in his company's office where he could work on real estate stuff and eat his office's free snacks as meals. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Through this recurring pattern, I grew in my feeling that my SO did not prioritize us as much as I prioritized us. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>For context, my SO and I met when we were both 19 in college (we're now 25). Our early 20s are a period of great change and personal discovery. I think this naturally created a lot of growing pains and corresponding trauma. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Also I want to call out here that I'm sharing an example of a personal trauma experience from the relationship. I know that my SO has his own, different experiences from my actions as well.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>How I identify it:</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>For me, this is when I notice I'm reacting much more strongly than how someone would "normally" react to a situation. </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Continuing in the personal example listed above:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A few weeks ago, I was discussing with my SO about where we'll live in 2022. When I suggested SF (where he currently is), he made an offhand comment of, "I have a schedule here where I wake up at 5am." When I suggested Austin (where his team is usually based), he mentioned his strong preferences (e.g., walking distance to a WeWork, not really caring about how nice our place is since he didn't think he'd spend much time there, etc.). After our discussions on location, I remember feeling frustrated, stressed, and overall in a worse mood - all these feelings to a magnitude greater than other stressful experiences in my day to day life. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>From these reactive feelings, I identified that my SO responses were triggers to memories in our past where he relentless prioritized his own goals over our relationship - and the corresponding negative feelings I experienced then. Even though my SO and I have both moved forward from those past events (and my SO's responses on the location discussion didn't actually imply the same pattern from before), my immediate assumption goes there - perhaps expecting the worse to protect myself from the hurt.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> As I started to recognize trauma, I became more in tune with my emotional and physical feelings. I noticed my overreaction to seemingly "normal" events because they were actually triggers for me showed up in a few ways (below listed in order of how easily I identify those overreactions): </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>My words and actions: <ul><li>Because I'm feeling stressed, I'll be more likely to react with my words and actions in a hurtful manner (e.g., withdrawing / not engaging, being more short and less kind / patient, etc.)</li></ul></li><li>My emotional and mental state:<ul><li>Usually after those actions come out, I'll look at myself with curiosity: "Why did I react like that?"</li><li>The answer to that question then helps me identify that I may be stressed / anxious / or some other negative feeling from the trauma.</li></ul></li><li>My physical state: <ul><li>When I continue being introspective and curious about my state, I'll often identify that my body also carries physical reactions. My shoulders may feel heavy. Parts of my body may feel contracted and tense. My breathing may be shorter. </li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"large"} -->
<p class="has-large-font-size"><strong><em>How I heal from it: </em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Identify</li><li>Communicate</li><li>See actions</li><li>Mental reframing </li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>By first being curious about my overreactions to events, I can identify triggers and then trace those triggers to past traumatic experiences. <strong>The first step for my healing is identifying the trauma and understanding the causes of it</strong>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>My next step is to communicate this to my SO. </strong>He is more empathetic to my overreactions once he understand where it comes from. Correspondingly, because he cares about me, he is often also more cognizant of what could be triggers and tries to avoid causing them when he can. Win-win for both of us!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The<strong> next crucial step</strong> in my long-term healing process is actually out of my control: it's having <strong>my SO show up in his actions deviating from previous trauma events</strong>. This evolves to a partnership healing journey: as he increases his frequency of showing up for me in his actions, it becomes easier for me to be more patient and have less triggers.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Lastly, I've found that deliberate mental reframing is helpful for my healing</strong>. I need to tell myself a new story around my SO's intentions and actions. It becomes less "risky" and thus easier to tell myself the new story when I've seen his new actions that have deviated from the past trauma patterns. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Concluding thoughts:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>From my cursory internet research on trauma, it does seem that the top Google results describe trauma similarly to my initial view on it (lasting effects from objectively really terrible events like rape, violence, abuse, natural disasters, etc.). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Perhaps the purpose of this post is to argue that less severe / seemingly-normal events can cause trauma as well, and there is validity in identifying and healing from these too. + offer a personal perspective on how my healing journey has been and share a potential alternative path to traditional treatments like therapy, medications, etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Please note, if you are facing more severe trauma and / or would like further resources on healing from trauma, this source seems really good: https://www.mind.org.uk/information-support/types-of-mental-health-problems/trauma/about-trauma/ </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Signing off with love,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Kat</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On a wall of 20 quotes, this is the one that drew me in immediately.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"id":3461,"sizeSlug":"large","linkDestination":"none"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img src="https://kathleenwritings.files.wordpress.com/2022/03/image.png?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-3461" /><figcaption><em>my chosen quote from a closing event at f*ck the small talk</em></figcaption></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In reflection, many of the fundamentally-shaping decisions I've made in my life were not accepted (instead, perceived as "absolutely ridiculous") by my peers at the time. I grew up mostly in city suburbs (Mississauga - suburb of Toronto; Clarendon Hills - suburb of Chicago) where conformity was king and risk-aversion was high. Friends thought I was out of my mind when I biked to / from hang outs crossing highways when they offered a car ride. I was looked at strangely when I held conversations with homeless people on the streets when we did a city trip. In college, my friends begged me not to throw away my life when I told them I decided to drop out of school to build technology projects in Europe and Africa. They gave me another intervention when I returned to school after my gap semester and declared that I was switching majors to Systems Engineering from Electrical Engineering. When I stayed on campus to scale my startup, my friends (my prior teammates) left to their well-paying large tech company internships - wishing the best for me and resigning their efforts to change my mind. My roommates continued to extend going-out invites to me throughout the week even though they knew I'd decline each time like the numerous times prior. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Looking back, each decision seems so obvious it was the right choice to make for my long term happiness. Yet in the moment, I was going through internal turmoil - deciding between pursuing an unknown route that I had only a faint inkling of where it may lead vs. continuing a path that everyone around me seemed so happy to take. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Where everyone zigged, I chose to zag, and this made all the difference. In the last half of college, I was intensely focused on my startup. After about a year or so, we finally caught some traction - which led to onboarding new users, winning awards and traveling for international + national conferences, and most importantly, increasing our real world impact on our mission to <em>Save Food and Do Good</em>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>By the time I left college, I was admitted to a social entrepreneurship fellowship in Colorado called Watson. After, I started a career at a top consulting firm called McKinsey. Then a secondment at One Acre Fund designing, building, and scaling last mile logistics for farmers across Kenya. Now a Chief of Staff team role at a startup I'm really enjoying. In reflection, by making the seemingly difficult and "absolutely ridiculous" decisions in high school and college, I've been able to pursue opportunities more suited to me than the standard paths most of my peers ended up taking. And as I continue in my previously-thought-of-as-non-traditional-path, I meet more and more similar people that inspire me and make me feel happy for choosing decisions that are true to me. The start was difficult, but the pay off is huge: I get to live a life that makes me happy with a community of like-minded friends who've done the same.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In our one brief life, the risk to <em>not </em>pursue what feels true to ourselves seems higher than the risk of taking the jump. (<em>Spoken through a place of recognized privilege to take these risks</em>.)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>s/o to Marilyn Monroe!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>i'm going to write a few posts related to my recent experience at f*ck the small talk. this is the first one.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:image {"id":3468,"sizeSlug":"large","linkDestination":"none"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image size-large"><img src="https://kathleenwritings.files.wordpress.com/2022/03/image-1.png?w=1024" alt="" class="wp-image-3468" /><figcaption>Pyramid of Conversationalists. cerca Kat's brain in March 2022.</figcaption></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sorting people I have conversations with to three levels, they'd be:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Base level - <em>doesn't actually listen</em></li><li>Intermediary level - <em>listens to reply</em></li><li>Expert level - <em>listens to understand</em></li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There is a direct relationship between how much I enjoy conversing with people and the higher the level they're at! Correspondingly, there is also a direct relationship with how close I am with the individual and the conversationalist level they're at :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>https://sive.rs/d1p </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(How to like people)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>adding here for personal tracking :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>when you don't want to do one thing, you can be productive with a different thing :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>reading books takes so many hours of my life. often, i feel like i take a lot from them for the next ~2-4 weeks or so afterwards. but then, often i mostly forget about them near-completely (except a very select few that stand out in my mind). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>thus, perhaps the marginal expense of taking the time + effort to write reflections post (and maybe during too?) reading the book would create a worthwhile additional benefit from that book.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>thought came about after I was asked about some of my fav books this year, and one book in particular came to mind but I couldn't articulate well what the book was about or why I really liked it - because it lapsed the ~2-4 week period from when I finished it! </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>more likely to take on opportunities</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>more likely to be hard working (still have something to prove)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(vs an established leader who's held the lead for a long time)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>(My example right now is writing :))</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Along the streets of cities in Colombia, I often see Venezuelan migrants asking for money to take care of themselves and their families. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><a href="https://www.unhcr.org/venezuela-emergency.html">More context from the UN Refugee Agency</a> on the current Venezuela that has been going on for almost 10 years now:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Ongoing political, human rights and socio-economic developments in Venezuela compel growing numbers of children, women and men to leave for neighbouring countries and beyond.</em> <em>People continue to leave Venezuela to escape&nbsp;violence, insecurity and threats as well as lack of food, medicine and essential services. </em><strong><em>This has become one of the largest displacement crisis in the world.</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When I hear migrant stories, I learn of doctors, lawyers, leaders in respected careers become taxi drivers, manual workers, jobless. I learn of families separated. I learn of beautiful human beings who are not treated as such - who become statistics and "societal burdens" without access to opportunity for fulfilling their potential for the world. And I know, there are millions of stories untold.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>All because of the macro circumstances created by decisions of a very select few in the country they were born in - not by choices of their own. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>With large Venezuelan migration to Colombia, xenophobia and racism towards the migrants represent a standing ideology of some Colombians (similar pattern to what I've seen when I was living in France and the US - and I'm sure exists in so many other countries). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here's a <a href="https://www.npr.org/2020/12/29/949548865/large-venezuelan-migration-sparks-xenophobic-backlash-in-colombia">quick blurb from NPR</a> to give more color on this:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>The message that Venezuelan migrants are no longer welcome comes from average Colombian citizens and powerful government officials alike. Last week, for example, Colombian President<a href="https://www.bluradio.com/nacion/venezolanos-que-no-tengan-doble-nacionalidad-ni-esten-regularizados-no-tendran-vacuna-covid-duque">&nbsp;Iván Duque</a>&nbsp;announced that undocumented Venezuelan migrants would not receive vaccinations for the coronavirus despite concerns from refugee agencies that this policy could lead to more infections.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-css-opacity" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"large"} -->
<p class="has-large-font-size"><strong>La Gran Colombia</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Dear love, be kind to your <em>veci</em><br>Soften that shell, look into his eyes: <br>You are not that different. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Do you remember la Gran Colombia - your pride and for some, your hope for a renewed future<br>The bloody few draw and redraw border lines with crayons<br>Forgetting Mother connected everything on this blue ball upon creation</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My love, you need the other<br>20th century - La Violencia después de Gaitan - he reluctantly opened his arms to shelter you from the bullets<br>21st century, you took on a new name <em>venecos</em> and the disgust that accompanied it, when you sought employment and security outside a government that offered none </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Child, you sit in your play throne.<br>Enough with the stubbornness, the proudness, the feigned ignorance<br>You can break the chain.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>What has been yours, has not always been yours. <br>The world changes quickly - as a function of minutes, hours, days, decades - it's all just time.<br>So please, be kind.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Same version below, but with asterisks and explanations</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Dear love, be kind to your <em>veci</em>*<br>Soften that shell, look into his eyes: <br>You are not that different. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Do you remember la Gran Colombia - your pride** and for some, your hope for a renewed future<br>The bloody few draw and redraw border lines with crayons<br>Forgetting Mother connected everything on this blue ball upon creation</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My love, you need the other<br>20th century - <em>La Violencia*** después de Gaitan</em> - he reluctantly opened his arms to shelter you from the bullets<br>21st century****, you took on a new name <em>venecos</em>***** and the disgust that accompanied it, when you sought employment and security outside a government that offered none </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Child, you sit in your play throne.<br>Enough with the stubbornness, the proudness, the feigned ignorance<br>You can break the chain.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>What has been yours, has not always been yours. <br>The world changes quickly - as a function of minutes, hours, days, decades - it's all just time.<br>So please, be kind.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*<em>veci = short-hand for "neighbor" in Spanish. Used in Colombia to also refer to friends / people you interact with. Used here also because Venezuela is a neighbor to Colombia.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>**<em>This Colombia (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gran_Colombia">La Gran Colombia</a>) was the most prestigious country in&nbsp;Spanish America.&nbsp;John Quincy Adams, then&nbsp;Secretary of State&nbsp;and future&nbsp;president of the United States, claimed it to be one of the most powerful nations on the planet. It included present-day Colombia, Venezuela, and other LATAM countries like mainland Ecuador, Panama, parts of northern Peru and northwestern Brazil.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>***<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Violencia">La Violencia</a> was a ten-year civil war in Colombia from 1948 to 1958 that is estimated to have cost the lives of at least 200,000 people. The conflict caused millions of people to abandon their homes and property.&nbsp;</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>****Research from <a href="https://osf.io/bcje3/download">here</a>, snipped copied below:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>"We get a personal view of migrants motives from interviews conducted by officials of<br>the Immigration Service, between 2011 and 2014. Colombians declared that they moved to Venezuela hoping for a better quality of life, economic facilities from the exchange system (subsidized exchange rates for remittances) to help the family back home, public housing and free education for their children. They could not get those benefits under the current policies of the Colombian government. They did not earn enough salary to buy a house, and the state does not finance them, along with the usual problems of the guerrillas and paramilitarism (insecurity) that force them to leave their homes."</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>*****Derogative racial slur currently used by Colombians to refer to Venezuelan migrants. Ironically, this word was created by Venezuelans for the same purpose towards the Colombian migrants. Source: Venezuelan tour guide from Medellin.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>"I have just three things to teach:<br>simplicity, patience, compassion.<br>These three are your greatest treasures.<br>Simple in actions and in thoughts,<br>you return to the source of being.<br>Patient with both friends and enemies,<br>you accord with the way things are.<br>Compassionate toward yourself,<br>you reconcile all beings in the world."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Source: http://thetaoteching.com/taoteching67.html</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>What I believe, from personal experience: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>In-person as the steady state isn't ideal (perks of remote work <a href="https://kathleenwritings.wordpress.com/2022/02/18/thought-to-self-perks-of-remote-working/">here</a>; overall I feel increased life fulfillment and autonomy, especially after building trust with my teams that I'll get the work done and be available when needed - incl putting in extra hours for critical deliverables)</li><li>Hybrid as the steady state isn't ideal (agree with most points why <a href="https://www.computerworld.com/article/3654214/the-trouble-with-hybrid-work.html#tk.rss_all">here</a>)</li><li>Strictly remote work as the steady state isn't ideal (drawback = less connection to teammates outside of work)</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Thus my take on what <em>is</em> ideal: <strong>Remote-First with Off-sites</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Remote-first culture:<ul><li>Predominant steady state is remote. Perks for employees and employers (incl: not needing to pay expensive office costs) abound.</li></ul></li><li>Quarterly off-sites:<ul><li>Few days each quarter for teammates to meet, co-work, hang-out and get to know each other outside of work, and have fun with new experiences! </li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How and why companies should adopt this for their employees:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>How:<ul><li>Account for corresponding costs in financial budget (e.g., remote work costs like work equipment; offsite costs - travel, place to host, activities)</li><li>Lead by example (leaders to champion this and to do it as well)</li><li>If the company is rather large: have someone responsible for community or remote experience or whatnot who is accountable for employee experience and organizing the off-sites. If the company is smaller: have a budget for off-sites per team, create a task-force or rotate someone from the team to plan each off-site.</li></ul></li><li>Why:<ul><li>Biggest reason is for employee happiness and satisfaction <strong>at work</strong>. Studies probably show statistics on a direct relationship between how happy / satisfied / connected employees feel at work with how that impacts employee retention, productivity, quality of work - both on an individual and aggregate level (network effect of happier employees = more happier employees; less happier employees = more less happier employees).</li><li>Cost-wise, this could be justified as X% savings from having an office</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Call-out of where I am in my life, and where I think the Remote-First with Off-sites model doesn't work:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Where I am in my life:<ul><li>I had ~2 years of structured, intense IRL professional job training after college prior to going remote due to Covid. </li></ul></li><li>For new joiners: <ul><li>I think it's a lot harder for new joiners to ramp up quickly and as effectively build some professional skills in a mostly remote model. If a new joiner is optimizing for learning (imo they should be ;P), here are some ideas to do so: 1) Join a default-in-person company with managers and teammates who are good mentors, 2) Perhaps in the remote-first (or even hybrid) model, the new joiner and the manager / teammate could spend a few months in the same place and cowork physically? + the manager should do more check-ins and teaching moments. + maybe look for more structured learning opps even outside of work? &lt;- <em>perhaps "being an effective manager in a remote-first world" could be an interesting separate blog post for me to think more on and publish!</em></li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Signing out,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Kat</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>In order of easiest to hardest to say during relevant times of stress </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>1. I’m hungry / getting hangry*.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>2. I’m tired / exhausted / spent*.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>3. I’m sorry, and I care about you and love you. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>(*Read: I have understandably human needs that are not met as the main contributor to this tension, it’s not personal, and I wouldn’t think of the situation as the same magnitude if my basic human needs were met.)</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The day prior and that morning, I didn't have clarity to answer that question. Among the bajillion unread slack messages and emails (i was on PTO last week) and the numerous flying priorities, I realized I was feeling slightly overwhelmed.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When my SO asked "what are you planning to get done today?", it prompted in-the-moment thinking and dialog that helped create greater clarity and focus for my entire day. I listed the three most important things I wanted to get done (and the corresponding deadlines I was working backwards from for this week) and acknowledged a few smaller tasks I needed to do to unblock others and push projects forward.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When I turned the question back to him, I'd like to think it helped him in a similar manner.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you have autonomy at work to prioritize your own time on a daily basis, I recommend giving this a try:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Ask this question with someone in the morning in a casual manner (over breakfast, while walking / commuting to work, etc.).</li><li>If you don't have someone to converse with, ask this to yourself out loud! There's a feeling of relief and accountability just in speaking the answer out loud. </li><li>Afterwards, write it down.</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Side note, if you have a bajillion things going on, answer the question with the top ~3 things you need to do to make your day successful. Prioritization and focus are important :)</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Cheers and onwards to completing those 3 things!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> <br></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>i think life is richer when we have both:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>time to have experiences</li><li>time to sit with ourselves in reflection</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>:)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>batch processes = minimize context switching costs</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>i've learned recently that minimizing context switching leads to deeper work = greater productivity = more optimal energy levels and feeling of personal fulfillment </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>When a coworker asked me my favorite parts of my months in Colombia:</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>My answer:</strong> Hanging out with my mom and sister. Best memories are belly-aching laughter over the dumbest "jokes." Immediate comfort and trust with the people I'm closest with and who know me best. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Probably my answer if younger Kat was responding:</em> Kitesurfing every other weekend at the most beautiful places. Horseback riding in Tayrona national park - cantering and galloping! Biking among the endless greenery of the mountainous Minca.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>2. When a friend asked me what I was looking forward to this next week:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>My answer:</strong> For our book project: picking up more interviews! I am so intellectually tickled with these discussions and learnings. For my daily life: my bike commute to and from the Wework office.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Probably my answer if younger Kat was responding:</em> Skiing in Tahoe </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>3. When a friend asked what I'm looking forward to now that I'm back in SF:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>My answer:</strong> Waking up every morning and going to bed every night with Jordan - my SO. There's nothing like the happiness of starting each day together and the warmth of ending the night together.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Probably my answer if younger Kat was responding:</em> Redwoods cabin weekend trip. Beach bonfires and friend gatherings. Hikes overlooking the sweeping waters. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>+ I've noticed that I really know what makes me happy nowadays and spend my time doing that :). My weekends are spent in beautiful nature-y spots with people who fill me with adventure, understanding, and laughter. I much less frequently (~1x/ 3 months) go out to bars or clubs, or drink when I socialize, because I generally get lower long term enjoyment from this.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>small self reflection of Kat at 25.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>I don't have to worry about what others think of my written thoughts </li><li>I get to partake in an indulgent exercise for myself - benefits: greater clarity of thought, time for reflection, documentation for myself in the future</li><li>I don't have to follow "rules" - for example, I don't <em>have</em> <em>to</em> implement feedback (though I genuinely appreciate it!!), I don't have to post on a specified routine schedule, I don't have to write on specific topics / have specific views.</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I think I'll continue writing in private (publishing not-so-structured thoughts on this unstructured blog at random intervals) for a long time. Maybe longer term if I find themes across my private blog that I'm interested in associating with my personal "public brand" - and that my awesome private readers find interesting as well, I'll write and publish in a more structured way to grow an audience!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In the meantime, continuing to sporadically thought dump here :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"className":"has-alpha-channel-opacity"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>An analogous to writing in private (/ smaller audience) - is how standup comedians perform in smaller venues to test their jokes and delivery before performing at larger more public ones. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Update 4/19: another analogy to this that I’ve read from book “Out-Innovate” is “tester markets” and “must-win markets”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Being back in the Silicon Valley / US, I constantly see millions of dollars being raised for ideas that seem so marginal in fundamental impact (many are friends' startups and I won't say their ideas here as examples, because I do understand there is still a valid marketplace for them and the founders and team members are really great people).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Millions of dollars are raised at insane valuations pre-product. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Money is plentiful, spending is plentiful.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But the impact in my eyes is relatively limited.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Vs. innovation in emerging markets. I feel like this is more exciting and actually impactful to so many more humans on this planet in more fundamental ways. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But those emerging market startups are working for years longer with much less cash injections that are also harder won.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>That disconnect frustrates me about the world.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>rant over :)</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Kat </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here’s a metric I use to gauge how intellectually tickled (and somewhat fulfilled) I may have found the conversation:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>* if I found a topic / thought I’m itching to write on this blog!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>quote from an awesome book i'm currently reading: Out-Innovate</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>more wisdom drops from Out-innovate!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>- quote from the marines</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>thought process:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>since college, i've time-boxed many sections of my life:<ul><li>summer internships - 3 months in NYC, Seattle, SF</li><li>social entrepreneurship fellowship - 3 months in Boulder</li><li>McKinsey - 2 years in a fascinating global lifestyle</li><li>secondment - 6 months in Kenya</li></ul></li><li>when i time-box my life (location, program, or career being the main proxy), I notice that my life was incredibly full. My weekends and many weekdays after work were fully packed with adventure - visiting new exhibits or nature spots, planning experiences with friends, saying yes to new things that lead to more new things, working hard and playing hard.</li><li><strong>however, i hadn't previously thought of time-boxing relationships in life</strong><ul><li>and recently, it hit me: all the relationships in our lives are already time-boxed without our say</li><li><em>with our families:</em> how many times will we spend with our family - the people often closest to us; know us most deeply; trust, care, and love us unconditionally - in our lives? this is morbid to think of, but if we were to spend in-person time with our parents 1-2x/year, and if they live to 90 or so, there's a chance we may have less than 50 of those in-person times left with them.</li><li><em>with my SO: </em>recently we've been spending nearly 24/7 together (perks of working together and living together physically). we haven't gotten sick of each other yet. when i came to the perspective that our togetherness is time-boxed, i realized i need to make the most of this precious time together - meaning for me: <ul><li>1) i want to minimize time spent being upset about things that don’t really matter. for the things that do matter, i’ll spend time communicating and working on myself to improve the overall quality of our time together.</li><li>2) i don’t want to fall into certain habits of comfort (analogous somewhat to taking someone for granted) we had when we were physically together in the past.</li><li>3) with one and two, consequently I feel more intense and more frequent emotions of love, happiness, and gratitude. </li></ul></li></ul><ul><li>because this period of our lives is not forever. i'll move to an emerging market to chase dreams of building impact. we'll have jobs and life roles where we aren't always spending this much intimate time together. our lives will ebb and flow and we’ll enjoy the journey through all its phases. </li></ul><ul><li><em>with our friends: </em>my SO mentioned something about potentially only having &lt;30 times to hang out with some of the good friends in our lives who are not in the same physical location. </li></ul></li><li>extrapolated, each of us being alive is incredibly brief. everything has always been time-boxed. when the time-box duration is less certain, it's easy to settle, take things for granted, love and live less fully. </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>we're here on earth so briefly. people tend to die with more money than time. say yes to invites from the people you love, the people that make you smile. make plans with people from that same group. and make sure they know you love them.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>life goes by quickly. let's keep trying to be the best person we can be for those around us!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"className":"has-alpha-channel-opacity"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>side note: my SO and I are planning on living a few months in various places in 2022. part of our rationale: we'll make the most of our lives through this method. we won't wait weeks to hang out with our friends in the area. we won't pass on those weekend trips.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>side note: there's a book called On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous. haven't read it, but on my reading list! mentioning because the title feels relevant :). also this feeling of limited time is also beautifully showcased in netflix movie Tick Tick Boom (I have seen this one - and highly recommend it!).</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>another side note: i now have a tattoo! by an incredibly talented artist in bogota. i think about it when i think about thoughts along this vein. not sure how to put the feeling in words. the tattoo is of a kite! it moves with my body. it's dynamic, as are the meanings i associate with it. such as: rising above - with a new perspective - to see what's really important, freedom, creativity, life is short!, beauty, childlike wonder, playfulness, curiosity, bravery, expression.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>peace and love,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>kat</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>last side note! i've mostly stopped eating meat again (~3 weeks in) - and this makes me feel visibly better on a daily basis. somehow even better than how i've felt in the past when i stopped eating meat. my body feels like there's more light throughout it. when i floss, my teeth feel more clean. i think i've started to grow a dislike for the texture (or just the idea?) of chewing meat.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And sometimes the result of these conversations inspires a blog post. Below is one of the sort - related to marriage, choice, and kids.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>On marriage:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On <a href="https://kathleenwritings.wordpress.com/2018/01/28/on-gender-issues/">Jan 28th, 2018</a>, I was questioning what marriage means to me.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Fast forward 4+ years, I've come to a more solidified personal perspective:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I don't want my life to change much before and after getting married. Emotionally, I've felt a deep and secure commitment with my partner since a few years after we started dating, and I think that feeling is shared. I have a choice* every day to love him, to be with him. He has the same. We don't need a signed paper to ensure that we'll choose each other each day, instead we have our actions in how we show up for each other. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We don't need a public wedding to profess our love to each other, we have our actions and words in the day to day. A new life event such as marriage may not substantially increase feelings of closeness, trust, love, happiness in the long run (similar concept as the hedonic treadmill).  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I'll likely follow the same time cadence as many traditional marriages - that I'll get married before I have kids** (late 20s or so) to add a sense of stability and security in raising a family. There's nothing wrong with the institution of marriage. I'm not necessarily afraid of commitment or logistical mental overhead (all the life things needed to do with marriage like paperwork and organizing a wedding). I don't have reasons for marriage that others may, such as: 1) being religious / other external societal pressure, 2) needing a green card / logistical requirement to stay in a country, 3) wanting to save money on taxes etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Finally, my perspective on marriage is personal. I have control in how I feel about it and how I act accordingly to it. That's cool!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em><strong>Note: </strong>I went to my first wedding last year! It was incredibly beautiful; and I am in wonder and awe of the traditions behind marriage in various religions / cultures. I thought that attending my first wedding would make me want to get married sooner - but that didn't happen. Attending my first wedding did form my view on weddings: that it's a beautiful celebration and get together with the people in our lives that we love. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>*On choice:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Early in my current romantic relationship, my SO and I agreed on the following:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If we "needed" to break up, we'd be happy for each other. Our logical thought process behind this:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>if we were to break up with each other - we felt like we were the right enough (on basis of holding similar values) people for each other, just at the wrong time.</li><li>if we were to be broken up, we'd support each other to date other people. <ol><li>the why: because we love each other, we want the best for each other</li><li>in dating other people, there'd be two outcomes (both having the result of "being the best for each other")<ol><li>if the new person for our SO was a better fit than ourselves: then this results in the best for our partner who we love and want the best for.</li><li>if the new person for our SO was not a better fit than ourselves: then likely we'd get back together later on with more appreciation and certainty of our relationship.</li></ol></li></ol></li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A call-out: we have broken up briefly in the past, but never followed through on dating other people - thus the second point above has just been theoretical! It'd be a lot harder in practice than in writing.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The above are if-statements that we have constant choices for (to stay together or to break up, if broken up to date others or not, if dating others to get back together or not, etc.). Because we want to stay together and know that the other also has a choice, then we make conscious (though by now these feel more habitual and less deliberate) decisions to prioritize the relationship, be there for each other, and be the best versions of ourselves.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Perhaps fundamentally at the end of my ramblings, acknowledging that we have a choice on how our relationship is (combined with the shared desire for wanting the best for each other), enables a higher quality in our interactions, greater mutual appreciation and communication, and less taking each other for granted.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity" />
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>**On kids:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I make larger life decisions based on "optimization" and "maximization." For example, I chose studying engineering in college (vs a strong contender of business) because I believed it's easier to do engineering in undergrad and then a MBA / business degree in graduate school then the other way around. I chose consulting after college (vs the 2nd contender of a PM role at tech companies) because I felt it's easier to do consulting first and then a PM role after (if I wanted to), vs the other way around (again assuming if I wanted to). And so on.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This mindset applies for my timeline to have kids as well. I'd like to have kids in my late-20s.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Why not earlier?</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are things that I want to do and achieve in my next few years that would be easier to do without kids (e.g., living in different countries, entrepreneurship, deepening and developing awesome friendships, etc.). Plus having kids is an irreversible decision - once you have kids, you don't have a choice to go back :P.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Why not later?</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I still have some solid years before my late 20s. Life is long but also short. Having a time box in my mind for life "pre-kids" helps me optimize my life till then. Furthermore, I agree that "things take up the amount of time allocated for it" (from Google, the more correctly worded Parkinson's law is the adage that “work expands so as to fill the time which is available for its completion”, which signifies that <strong>the more time people dedicate in advance to a certain task, the longer it will take to complete it</strong>, even if it could have been completed in less time). I've already measured out the life goals I want to start on prior to kids... If I push out my timeline to having kids, then I hypothesize that I'd achieve similar outcomes just over a longer timeline due to less urgency. Plus, I really want kids in my life - and I want to be a relatively young and energetic mom who inspires my next generation through being a living example (e.g., for my kids to see me on my journey in chasing my dreams so they will be more directly inspired to do so for their own dreams!). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>small thing - was really nice of him!!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Past</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In my romantic relationship, my emotional reaction in fights sucked. I'd get overwhelmed with a story that would spiral in my mind and throughout my body. Years later, I realized my body had similar feelings of "flight or fight" responses - I'd get tense, breathe shallowly, and not be able to think of anything beyond the narrative I held in my mind. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Correspondingly, I'd react emotionally. I'd fight in a way that was not effective to both parties. I caused unnecessary hurt to the person who loved me.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Recent tactical changes that has lead to more effective fighting</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol><li>Skip the superlatives - in an emotional state, I would often accuse J of "never" doing this or "always" doing that. Superlatives aren't true. Because of that, my argument becomes less valid and less helpful for everyone.</li><li>Don't bring every minor irk up. There are small things throughout life that he may do that are minorly bothersome, but are overall totally okay. In moments I spiral, I would often bring everything up (incl all these minor irks) and bring them as evidence into my overall negative story. These weren't helpful for either side. J would feel like he's failing in all these things - the quantity feeling insurmountable. For me, I wouldn't effectively communicate what's really bothering me, because the actually important things would get diluted by all these small irks. Instead, I've learned what is helpful is focusing on what's really important to me and the root of my upset feelings, and focusing on communicating that more concisely. </li><li>Do share how I'm feeling and why I think I'm feeling this way. It's easier to communicate than to mind read. Phrases like, "I'm feeling upset because X happened" or "I think I'm more irritable right now to things that I wouldn't usually care as much about, because I'm feeling exhausted." This humanizes the situation, helps J to better take care of me, and for myself to be aware of the truth which stops some spiraling.</li></ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Here are some helpful things I do to make the above tactical changes easier to implement and to prevent spiraling (a term I'm using synonymous to the flight and fight mental and physical state):</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Breathe deeply. Slow things down.</li><li>Take a walk with myself. Be more aware of how I feel. If I feel myself start to spiral , then I try to ground myself on truths like: "I'm breathing", "Jordan loves me", "I love Jordan." </li><li>Defect thoughts. Think about something else that could be more productive. Think about the lower half of my body - like my feet and my legs. &lt;- this is a tactic I learned from a therapist, and I think it does really help with grounding!</li><li>Write things down. Helps process and structure my thoughts and figure out what's really important vs what's not as important. Helps me think more on what my truths are.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Cheers to maintaining the highs and having less lows.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Kat</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Post script:</strong> Another learning I had this year was that people fight and express emotions differently. I didn't realize when J was going through emotions like frustration, upset, etc. because he didn't expressed them the same way I did. I'm now more in tune with how he expresses these emotions in the subtle ways. Seeing and understanding how individuals express emotions is powerful for me because I'm able to better react accordingly (e.g., being more patient, taking care of the other, backing off more). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>balanced between people and self</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>on people -&gt; what are the kinds of people i want to spend time with? why? what do i want to be doing with them? </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->
<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Quote from a friend who got it from a friend who got it from a life coach</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Been thinking lately of focus and hermit mode. For ~2 weeks, I felt like I didn't progress much in my own interests, projects, hobbies, whatnot. Instead, I was hanging out with friends - grabbing food, walking around, attending events. Nothing wrong with that - I just felt like I was doing those too much, at the expense of my personal progress and fulfillment. Thus, I'm going to try happiness from hermit mode this week.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>"People will always be there, your dreams will not."</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This quote created a feeling of comfort in justifying hermit mode. I believe it to be true. There are so many things going on all the time in large cities like San Francisco where I have historic ties with seemingly so many different friend groups. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Speaking of which, I've been thinking of how to optimize of this limited time I'm spending living in the magic bubble of San Francisco.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here's my initial thinking:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Meeting new people here IRL - there is a high density of interesting, diverse, relatively similar-aged people everywhere! I'll try to meet at least 1 new person each week. Whether striking a conversation with someone new at WeWork, my climbing gym, or attending a social gathering where there are friends I don't know</li><li>Finding and reaching out to people with emerging markets expertise or interests that are based here (entrepreneurs, investors, college professors, etc.)</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It's time to be more deliberate on how I spend my time. I think this will take me places to meet new people with shared purpose. So there's still social time, but perhaps more "productive" or fulfilling in some sense.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Furthermore, in conversation with my friend, I realized that ambitious / interesting people (people I want to be and stay friends with) want to be around other ambitious / interesting people. Wherever I am, there will be people like that around. It helps myself and my relationship with them when I ensure I have enough focus time to pursue my dreams now.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Side note, I am in awe of some beautiful human bubbles that make my soul sing. Here's a quick compilation:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Kenya: The Wonder House @Nairobi</li><li>Colombia: The Curiousity House @Medellin</li><li>San Francisco: The SF Commons project // Third Spaces, the Center SF</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Also, I was adjacently-into Effective Altruism communities while living in Kenya and Colombia. Looking to continue this in SF!</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Cheers,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>K</p>
